Review title: One Amazing Film, With A Mezmerizing Performance From Brandon Lee!
Review_body: This is one amazing film, with a mesmerizing performance from Brandon Lee!. It's visually appealing, extremely well made, with amazing performances all around!. Loved the score, too, it fit with the film well, and there's plenty of action to go around as well. Michael Wincott is, very menacing as the main villain, and was perfect for the part. The flashbacks were very cool, however i wished, i could see more of Shelley's character. The Directiing is outstanding!. Alex Proyas does an outstanding job here, creating lots of, dark atmosphere, great use of the rain machine,cool visuals, and keeping the pace,action packed, and engrossing all the way!. The film is very violent, but not all of it is bloody. We get several knives in the chest, knife in the hand, lots of gunshot wounds, some bloody, some not, hole through hand, 2 slashings, slit throat,2 bloody impallings, sword in the neck and a crow pecks a girls eyes out. The Acting is WONDERFUL!. Brandon Lee, gives an Oscar worthy performance here, he is completely mesmerizing, creepy,kicks that ass and, just thought he was too cool, his AMAZING AMAZING performance here, will always be remembered, what happened too him was a tragedy, and i for one will never forget him!. Rochelle Davis is awesome here, and is very likable,her and Brandon, had very good chemistry and is one of the best kid actors out there!, especially since she hasn't acted since then!. Ernie Hudson, is terrific as the Sgt., very likable, and very convincing. Michael Wincott, is great as the main villain, i loved his voice, and he was very menacing!. Sofia Shinas, is very good as Shelley, however, she didn't have much screen time, but was great when on screen. Overall a MUST SEE at all costs!. ***** out of 5

The CrowWhen it comes to homicides in the avian empire, fowl that fly in flocks called "murders" are your most likely suspects.And while this action movie isn't about birds of prey, it is about a bird-themed spirit that preys on evil.On the eve of Halloween – and their wedding nuptials – an up-and-coming rock star Eric Draven (Brandon Lee) and his fiancé are brutally slain by a gang of thugs.One year later, Eric rises from the grave. Donned in black attire, stage make-up, and accompanied by a crow, he seeks vengeance.However, a crime lord (Michael Wincott) and his mystic (Bai Ling) desire the powers of invincibility that the resurrected Eric possesses.Based on the comic book, The Crow is a bullet-riddled ballad of retributive justice filled with colourful criminals and a striking cityscape.As for The Crow's archenemy: it's old lumber, straw and clothes configured to resemble a farmer. (Green Light)vidiotreviews.blogspot.ca

Review title: An instant favorite! Lee is awesome.
Review_body: A Fantastic tale of undying love, and revenge. This is undoubtedly Brandon Lee's best performance, and sadly also his last. It also happens to be my favorite vengeance-themed film. This is perfection all the way, from the plot to the acting to the visuals and somber atmosphere. Michael Wincott is perfectly cast as the antagonist, and Brandon Lee is simply brilliant! The scene where Top Dollar (Wincott) and his gang opens fire on Eric (Lee) on the table is incredible!

It rained here in Wilmington, North Carolina the day Brandon Lee died. A buddy of mine called me early that day and told me that Lee had been shot on the set of THE CROW. I thought he was joking. He wasn't; the local news channels were confirming it. Not long before, another friend of mine, from out of town, had visited and we'd tried to find the location where THE CROW was being filmed. I was already a Brandon Lee fan and I loved the comic, so I was determined to see him in the flesh. On a dark, rainy day, we searched around until we found the black crow logo with an arrow indicating that the camera crew was somewhere downtown, and set off in search of Brandon Lee. My buddy grew tired of driving and searching and suggested we take in a movie (ARMY OF DARKNESS was playing, and we were both Sam Raimi fans). I insisted we keep on searching. Downtown, we drove past a group of filmmakers on a side street and I recognized Sam Raimi himself. I urged my buddy to stop. He thought I was "full of ****." But he stopped and we got out and watched Sam Raimi shoot second unit footage for THE HUDSUCKER PROXY. Later, we saw ARMY OF DARKNESS. I never did get to see Brandon Lee. I called the offices of Fangoria magazine and told them about the accident. They didn't seem interested (this was before the internet, and there was no way for them to confirm my story, I guess). Later, when the news broke that Lee had died, I followed up with another phone call. This time around, the Fangorians had heard the news for themselves and were understandably low-key. I hung up and walked to the door and looked out. Dark clouds were rushing past overhead, and raindrops were starting to fall again. I stood there with raindrops pelting my face and I closed my eyes and, before long, I began to cry. I'd been a Bruce Lee fan and had been shocked by his death; the shock of hearing about Brandon Lee's death was just as hard to take. Not long after, at the same hospital where he had been taken, I talked to a nurse who had been there when he'd been brought in. "He was bleedin' so bad they had to change the mattress," she told me: "It was soaked clean through." She went on, but I'd already gone numb. Sometimes, I still feel that way. It's dark out, now, so I'm going to go. It feels like rain.

Review title: The movie of the life of Brandon Lee.
Review_body: Some time ago, I became aware of the existence of this film, but I decided to see it because of its somewhat dark and interesting theme. It turned out to be the movie I saw on my Halloween night, and I'm not exactly sorry. The film is set in a dystopian future, in which the city is dominated by organized crime and the authorities seem incapable of acting and there is a group of thugs that annually set fire to several parts of the city on purpose, in the so-called "Devil's Night", just for the pleasure of destroying.In the film, a totally innocent couple are attacked and killed by criminals who break into their home. However, a crow magically in charge of taking Eric's soul to heaven decides to keep it on earth in order to give him time to do what needs to be done: find and punish the killers. It's a simple, direct plot, based on a series of graphic novels that I didn't know about, but it works reasonably well. A particular note, which made this film famous, was the sad death of the main actor, Brandon Lee, as a result of an accident with the film's weapons during a scene in which his character is hit by a bullet.From the cast, it is Brandon Lee who stands out, with a charismatic and committed performance. With this film, the actor achieved the most outstanding role of his career. In addition to him, Michael Wincott also deserves particular commendation due to the dark, grim and cruel portrayal of a crime boss. Sofia Shinas and Jon Polito also show up and do a satisfying job.Technically, the film has several elements of interest, mainly in terms of visuals and special and sound effects. The cinematography is suitably dense, sober and at times gives the scenes a pleasant charge of pessimism and negativity, as if we were inside a nightmare or hallucination. The props and sets help to create the desired atmosphere, gothic and a little threatening, but it is the visual, special and sound effects that deserve the most praise. The film also has good action scenes. The soundtrack, while not memorable, works reasonably well.

Lots of Crow projects have been attempted or proposed since 1994. NONE OF THEM have been any good or worth considering. There is something in The Crow (1994) that really worked and unfortunately has proven not easy to replicate.The Crow is visually dynamic with a rock n roll feel that underpins a tale of loss and sorrow. Take the loss and sorrow, twist it and then release the vengeance and the smiting!! It hits the balance perfectly.Much has been spoken about Lee's performance and this being his breakout role. I don't know about that I have seen all his other stuff and its ok but nothing that particularly grabs you. In The Crow he is perfect, but I think he, and the rest of the cast and crew hit the sweet spot, I'm not sure he could have delivered another performance such as this. Maybe I'm wrong and it is a shame we didn't get see it.This movie does deserve a full 4k HDR remastering :)

Review title: Not too good, not too bad
Review_body: I can't say I liked or disliked The Crow. The acting was good, but the story didn't appeal to me. I suppose the vendetta theme has been done so much that I have become tired of it. Also, sometimes it seemed the plot was hard to follow. It could have been a better movie, but it was just to simplistic.

"The Crow" may be the most important poetic effort in modern Horror. We get a romantic story from the grave that deals with revenge, rage, the occult (all about the crow), corruption, innocence, and more. All of these elements are glued together by Eric's motives in a poetic manner.The atmosphere is dark but extremely beautiful. You can feel the adrenaline in most of the important scenes. You could take a picture of almost every single scene. There's plenty of violence, amazing action sequences (the car explosion could be considered as one of recent cinema's most powerful moments), an endearing on-screen duo formed by Eric and the cop, sadness and fury when the flashbacks re-tell the story, etc.The Direction is flawless. The comic-book feeling is extraordinary and I can't think of any other movie (except for "The Dark Knight") where you can feel you are actually living the experience. The acting by Brandon Lee is timeless. Unique. The score is fantastic (loved the jazz tracks and "Big Empty" by STP). This is a poem of a movie. Watch it and enjoy the dark, touching, violent world of "The Crow".
Simple but really good told story of revenge and love, for me its is one of best revenge films with tragic end in real life of actor who had big future in front of him

It's interesting to ponder whether or not The Crow would have received such a strong cult following if not for Brandon Lee's tragic death in the middle of the filming. It certainly bestows a certain aura of gloom over the entire film, and keeping in mind that this is supposed to a dark and brutal story about lost love and need for revenge, this is in no way a bad thing.To answer my original question, yes, I think it would have become just as popular over time had Lee survived. Because it's just such a splendid film. It's also a movie that's hard to categorize. It certainly has elements of horror in it, mostly in the visuals and the general atmosphere, but calling it just a macabre horror story seems lacking. There are elements of fantasy and mystery in it, even thriller, but even those four genres don't define it completely. Luckily, over time people have come up with terms to describe it, and one of those, namely urban Gothic, for me describes it perfectly. It's a Gothic horror fantasy story given a modern setting and twist. It deals with the themes love and loss, both of which interlock. One fuels the other and vice versa. It's a story about settling scores, giving in to your need for revenge, eye for an eye, yet it treats such a theme with sadness and melancholy, keeping in mind the human underneath the monster.It's such a shame that Brandon Lee passed away so early in his career, because this film would have launched him into stardom. His performance is everything it needs to be. He can shift from a screaming madman into a lonely, heartbroken poet faster than you can blink and every scene he is in, he absolutely dominates. Luckily the villains are able to match his performance. Michael Wincott's Top Dollar is a great main villain for this film. He's just as crazed and threatening as Lee's Eric Draven, but in a completely different way. He's a monster because he chooses to be one, not because he has been driven to become one. The secondary villains are also a delightfully mad bunch of idiots, killers and nutjobs, fitting perfectly into their world.The Crow is an unforgettable experience. It switches between blazing action, subtle emotions and heart-wrenching drama with such skill that it's no wonder it has become so popular over the years. If you like dark films with mystical elements, then this is definitely worth a watch.

Review title: First time watching this most talked about film of 1994
Review_body: The Crow is a 1994 Gothic Thriller starring the late Brandon Lee as the title charcther. The story is about a young man who's fiance and him were shot to death by an evil guy. Sometime later and the young man Eric(Lee) comes back to life and seeks revenge.What drew me to this film was the performance of Brandon Lee who sadly got shot by the actor who played the bad guy in the movie as well as the special effects on how the director was able to being Brandon Lee back from the dead using a stunt double by using Brandon's face onto the stuntman. Not one scene was I going oh this is fake(then again the movie was set at night so that explains it). If you love violent movies then check it out. For me it's a once off as I found it way too violent and disturbing.

This is a movie which will mark a masterpiece of cinema excellence. Coming back from the dead is an experience no one wants to have. But when it comes to losing a loved one from a crime, the results is traumatic. The Crow gives the meaning of revenge and redemption. Brandon Lee plays in his final role as Eric, a musician whom he and his fiancée are brutally murdered. He gets to come back from the dead with a help of a magical crow. The Crow gives him power and he goes out for vengeance. The effects for this movie are excellent and the storyline is unbelievable. It is quite a shame that Brandon Lee didn't get to see the results of this film. A dragon wouldn't blend in very well in this movie. It is really good and the cast are fantastic.A great movie with tragic results. 4 out of 5 stars!

Warning do not read unless seen movie.This film is one of my favorite films of all time and believe it or not my favorite live action comic book film of all time. There are many but this one I love because it really touched me on a lot of levels but also it was one of the inspirations for my writing as well. This film was a phenomenon from some of its style in music and wear which is now common place today and still continues on. But also really helped the comic book movie genre to soar a little higher and become what it is today. Let alone really gave us another way to look at movies and appreciate the people that make them even more than before.There is so much I love about his film. The production value is just fantastic, to this day it still amazes me. I really love the use of darkness and the black color, which fits as the graphic novel was in black and white. This really gave the film the feel of it coming straight out of the graphic novel. The city that is constructed it's a beautiful mix of the gothic and noir, it an alternate America where it is one step but also one step away. There are a lot of great cinematography shots, one of the sequences I like is seeing Eric Draven running and jumping up on the rooftops, much like Daredevil and this was way before that TV show. But it just looks cool because it was Eric's way of taking flight in the city.The music in this film is great, this film has the best soundtrack and score I've seen in any film. There are just so many memorable tunes that really fit and help bring out the gothic noir landscape but also emotion. From the song "After the Flesh" in that Night Club battle scene is just exciting as it just one that just pumps out manic fast action. But another which is the "Return to the Grave" which is just beautiful as it is both a tune of love but also sadness which perfectly reflect the dilemma of the crow.The action is very good it's well choregraphed, it's not like wall to wall but that's because it's a bit on the realistic side. We don't really see Brandon do much martial arts except a few flips, use of the katana, and one move or two. Most of what he is doing is street fighting and gunplay which makes sense Eric Draven is a rocker not a trained fighter. There are some memorable sequences, like the fight with Tin Tin where he does the knife catch as it goes in midair, I know that wouldn't work in real life, but it was fun to think you could do it.But of course one of my favorite battles of all time which is the battle in Top Dollar's Night Club which is similar to the drug plant shootout in "Robocop" as we just see there are just bad guys left and right, up top to bottom all shooting the hell out of him. But Eric is just blowing though the bullets while wasting every one of them with his fists, guns, and the katana. He then says one of my favorite quotes from the film "You're all going to die." mess with "The Crow" you will.But most of all I just really love the story which is uncannily similar toward "Robocop". Just like Alex Murphy, Eric Draven dies a violent death and comes back in a different kind of form and is even plagued by memories from his past which contain the joy of the past but also the doom of the present which drives him on his avenger crusade. Though with Alex he was resurrected with science and technology, here Eric is resurrected by supernatural and mystical force which is a crow. This concept goes back to Native American mythology and spirituality on spirit guides and animal totems.The story is a bit of a wishful fulfillment fantasy as Eric along with his girlfriend have been victimized. This gives the possibility of what if they or even you ever got the chance to fight back. Everyday some of us deep-down feel that anger and rage over anyone that has been wronged or victimized or even become one ourselves and we have the primordial need to deliver justice one way or another.I even like that it does something different with the revenge story motif from putting a supernatural/fantasy element to it but also that the protagonist does have something to come back to in the end, where in most revenge stories they don't.The characters are great, really like the Devil's Night villains whom are guys you just love to hate. All of them are just really colorful and each have their own specialties and persona, from the four man crew Tin Tin, Funboy, and T Bird (played well by underrated actor Patrick Kelly) these are pyromaniacs whom are all completely insane that just want to do simply kill and destroy whenever they want. There is one scene where their playing this drinking game and they are each swallowing bullets. Yeah, I know crazy, but it shows how each of them doing what they've been doing for so long, none of them think even death can't kill them; how wrong they all are.Top Dollar (played well by another underrated actor Michael Wincott) this guy is complete psycho by his nature but it's one of a passive aggressive nature. This guy doesn't really have much rime or reason for what he does, though in the graphic novel supposedly part of his motive for getting most of the city firebombed was his sick way of honoring his deceased parents as it was in the graphic novel. But most of all this guy just seems to have no rhyme or reason causing anarchy, chaos, and destruction just simply that he's bored and that's his way of having fun.I really like the character Sarah played by Rochelle Davis whom unfortunately hasn't done anything more. I like her because she's a person that is wise beyond her years despite her age. She's smart and has a spunk to her. She is a person that is still dealing with the loss of two of her best friends Eric and Shelly whom were sort of her brother and sister figures or in another sense almost segregate parent figures. This makes her relatable because any of us that have suffered loss at a certain point in our life and make sense out of living in an existence without them.But of course, I really like the main protagonist Eric Draven whom is another one of my favorite fictional protagonists. This is a protagonist you really have a sense of pathos for, as we see he is a person that is suffering deep pain eating at him inside and out.He's a protagonist that is up there with other tragic protagonists like "Robocop" and "Darkman" because they have one thing in common, they are people that had great aspirations in life, only for those aspirations to be gone in one day. I like the emotionality expressed and the physicality we see it feels like how any of us would feel if we all had to go through with this. Really like his outfit from the black leather coat, boots, paints, and shirt, I wanted to don those.But of course his face paint with the black eye and lip makeup which makes him seem like a heavy metal rocker but also a supernatural being. It really fits since it represents Eric as a person now a dark shadow of whom he formally was. Really like how with "The Crow" alter ego he is sort of a dark mischief as we see him sort of joking around a little with the villains, sort of a poetic justice redirecting the awful taunts they threw at him before destroying his and his girlfriend's lives.There are also some really touching moments, from the scenes when he is remembering most of his past which we see as flashes. That reflects how we remember things, because it's never always specific dialog but visual moments in time. Those moments really deepen the emotional weight because they display what life is made of but also how none of us truly have all the time in the world for time passes by quickly; what seems like a long time will feel like yesterday.Another favorite scene is the reunion with Sarah, at first Eric doesn't reveal himself and we see Sarah is taking about how she feels about her life without both Shelly and Eric. Just as Sarah is about to leave, we see Eric finally show up and both hug. I'll admit that put a tear or two in my eye, as this is something, we all wish would happen for any loved on in our lives lost, but I felt that scene also reflected my feelings on the loss of Brandon. Down to that very final scene which was bittersweet but still to this day still makes me cry as it really felt like I was saying farewell to a best friend.Now this moment I'm going to get real, Brandon Lee he is one of my favorite martial arts stars, he really is one of the ones that inspired me into getting into martial arts and being a martial artist. I carry on doing what I do best and love in life as many more that have and had not seen his movies but all the same his legacy lives on and just like that final line in the crow he will never be forgotten.Rating: 4 stars

Review title: Dark and depressing, but very good. (10/10)
Review_body: "The Crow", which starred the late Brandon Lee, certainly was one of the best films of 1994.  Brandon Lee, in case you don't know, was the son of martial arts star Bruce Lee, who also died while making his last film.  The story for "The Crow" is familiar to countless people.  Lee plays a murdered rock musician who returns from the dead as an invincible ghost of sorts. Guided by a mystical crow, he searches the dark streets looking for the thugs who killed him and his girlfriend.Dark and haunting, "The Crow" succeeds, despite its obviously low budget. Director Alex Proyas certainly knows how to direct a film, despite the tragic death of the films star.The camera work in this film is excellent, as is the films story.  The film is also filled with countless symbolisms and many bizarre twists, such as the Crow appearing right before someone is killed (since in the film, it is seen as an omen of certain death) or each of the thugs being killed with the tricks of their trade.Not to be missed.

Review title: American director Alex Proyas' film 'The Crow' continues to enjoy its cult film status.
Review_body: 'The Crow' was American actor Brandon Lee's last film where has left indelible marks on all scenes in which he has featured. There are numerous reasons which might have compelled director Alex Proyas to choose 'The Crow' as a bird who helps a man avenge senseless killings. One should note that the crow symbolizes the perfect harmony between a bird and a human to wage a war against injustices. A crow is the best spirit animal associated with life's mysteries and magic. Apart from beautifully choreographed action scenes, it has a strong revenge story with ample scope for drama. In one of the major subplots, viewers are able to watch how a neglected child is able to get happiness when her mother realizes the mistakes she made by ignoring her. The cult film status accorded to American director Alex Proyas' film 'The Crow' is justified by all means. In 1994, at the time of its release it was hailed as both box office success as well as many critics' favorite film.It is no wonder that there is hardly any director who has artistic abilities to direct a sensible remake of 'The Crow'.This information should be taken into account to measure the overall success of the film 'The Crow'

Review title: Revolutionary for its Time, The Crow Feels Dated and Vain Today
Review_body: Like leafing through an old high school journal, this was difficult to get through without cringing at every bad line and self-absorbed thought. I'd recalled the dialog as being fairly pretentious, even through the rosy-red glasses of fond remembrance, but nothing could've prepared me for just how poorly the whole package has aged over the last decade and a half. Try as he might, Brandon Lee never comes close to getting over the hump as a serious dramatic actor, even in a mostly-action setting, and the half-baked revenge formula he plods through does little to challenge convention. Though its unique visual identity is still a strong point and the soundtrack remains gigantic, there's really little else to celebrate about The Crow in a modern setting. For its time this was a fantastic comic book adaptation, but given the strides made in that field over the last ten years it really isn't even a fair fight any more. Let it live on in your memories; modern viewings do nothing but disturb a settling grave.

It's amazing that a film so steeped in 90s zeitgeist also manages to feel timeless. Director Alex Proyas tells the story as a sort of Gothic tone poem, with the music and visuals creating a mood that hangs over you like a weeping sky. Brandon Lee, who was tragically killed during filming, is brilliant in what would've been a star making turn. Shifting easily between rage, compassion and humor, he transcends the typical comic book hero archetype.With its darkly beautiful visuals, pitch perfect soundtrack and excellent score, 'The Crow' remains a unique and genre defying masterpiece.

Review title: A tragedy within a tragedy; haunting & memorable
Review_body: When rocker Eric Draven and his fiancee Shelly Webster are tragically killed by a bunch of thugs; 1 year later Eric returns from the dead and guided by a crow (who acts as his link between the land of the living and the dead realm) Eric sets out to avenge his and his fiancee's deaths by taking each of the culprits out one by one...As a revenge-based film The Crow plays out exactly as any good vengeance based film should; it is short, action-packed and mercifully free of a lot of unnecessary exposition. Director Alex Proyas shows Eric and Shelly's backstory through flashbacks which in lesser hands could come across as cheesy, but in The Crow they do heighten Eric's pain and act as a driver for his revenge. Once Eric is back from the dead the film is fast-paced, exciting and packed with action and incident. There is also a touching moment when Eric saves the mother of a young girl he used to take care of when he was alive which was just one example of the film having some heart to it rather than just being a generic bone-crunching film.I thik what balances The Crow out so well is that not only is it action-packed, intense and fast-paced, but Draven's likeability also makes it a winner - you want him to get his revenge, you want him to help the girl etc. The fact that he isn't just doing it for himself makes it more of an emotional journey and the 2 elements moulded together make this a terrific film.Of course, the tragic real-life on-set death of Brandon Lee will always make The Crow a haunting film and perhaps it's for this reason that the film resonates with me more than some other films within the same genre. However, to me The Crow is still a brilliant film and, at least for me, a fitting legacy to an actor whose life was cut short just as he was on the ascendency.

The question is, would The Crow be the cult movie it is today without Lee's untimely death? Possibly not, although interest in the character was strong enough to generate a dire sequel with Vincent Perez in the title role, as well as a TV series with chop-sockey C-lister Mark Dacascos. What is certain though is that, like River Phoenix and James Dean, Lee entered the grim pantheon of fast-lived good-looking corpses and thus gained a morbid immortality which no doubt adds to his popularity among his adolescent, angsty fan base. It's a popularity significantly reinforced by Lee's eerie musing on mortality during his final screen interview just days before his death. "Because we do not know when we will die we get to think of life as an inexhaustible well," he said.. "It all seems limitless."

Review title: Very stylish unique approach to a revenge flick...
Review_body: 1st watched 6/2/1996 - (Dir-Alex Proyas): Very stylish unique approach to a revenge flick.  Brandon Lee is excellent in his last role and shows a presence not unlike his father's although the makeup sure helped as well.

Review title: Haunting, timeless classic. As good as films get.
Review_body: 31 Days Of Horror: Day 26Not technically a horror, I know, but Alex Proyas's The Crow is close enough to the mark, and a halloween seasonal film at that, so get off my back. Plus, it's one of the best movies ever made, period. Anyone who knows me well enough is aware that my love for this one veers close to fanaticism. Now the one thing I try not to dwell on when discussing it is the tragic accidental death of young star Brandon Lee on set, a result of a grave props error. Yes it happened, but it's not the distinguishing feature of it and if anything gives the film a haunted, otherworldy, aching vibe. Lee had a star quality that burned bright in his few cinematic outings, and he's a dark prince of fierce revenge and essential 90's grunge here, playing musician Eric Draven. On a hellish, arson plagued night before Halloween in an unnamed urban sinkhole, Draven and his beautiful fiancé Shelley (Sophia Shinas) are heartlessly murdered by a marauding band of street thugs. One year later, a mysterious crow lands on Draven's grave, a harbinger of resurrection. Draven is brought back to life for one purpose: revenge against the men who killed them. For two haunting hours, Lee is a hypnotic angel of death, thrashing his guitar at the heavens atop a cathedral when he's not laying waste to the inner city scum of a city rotting at its core, yet filled with a lived in, gritty Gothic grandeur that's a testament to the set design and cinematography. Lee had a special way with dialogue thats wonderful to hear, a brisk cadence and well spoken sincerity that stands out among the crass inbreds he interacts with for much of the story. Each of the gang members are more self destructive and psychopathic than the last: Skank (Angel David) a mumbling crackhead screw up, knife throwing Tin Tin (Laurence Mason), skeevy rape fanatic Funboy (Michael Massee) and their nasty leader T Bird, played by underrated David Patrick Kelly, who shows uncanny abilities in his final scene of reckoning and realization. Their leader is a terrifying machiavellan overlord named Top Dollar, and runs every crime outlet in town. He's played by my favourite actor, Michael Wincott with a devilish, nihilistic brutality, his trademark velvet over broken glass voice, and a sense of dark, almost Poe-esque mythology. Whether burying his face in a mound of coke, hacking off limbs of disloyal cohorts with his ornate sword collection or giving a hair raising monologue on social anarchy, he's a highlight of the film and a comic book villain for the ages. Along with his kinky sister Myca (Bai Ling, who he also bangs >:), and his suave first lieutenant Grange (Candyman himself, Tony Todd) he launches an all out war against Draven, rallying every lowlife, gutter rat and junkie with a gun to find him. Meanwhile kind hearted police officer Albrecht (Ernie Hudson) is on his case as well, and young Sarah (Rochelle Davis), Eric's friend, misses him and searches the streets for someone to care for her while her deadbeat slutty mother (Anna Thompson) does drugs with Funboy. There's scene stealing work from Jon Polito as deplorably scuzzy pawn shop proprietor Gideon, the black humored comic relief of the movie. There's such an organic, fluid energy to this film, every beat hitting the mark, the editing a precise symphony of image and sound that leaves you wanting more and keeps you coming back. The ethereal score by Graeme Revell is a mothwinged lullaby of mythic proportions accented by fitting work from The Cure, and every performance is exactly and perfectly what it needs to be. Not to mention the production and costume design, setting a mood of brooding tragedy, burning romanticism, dark emotional torment and surreal Gothic characters that should have their own action figure set. There's endlessly quotable lines in the script penned from James O Barr's comic book as well, from offbeat humour, to poignant poetry and all kinds of profane and threatening utterances. It's as near to a perfect film as one can get, and hovers around in my top five of all time. A classic.

Eric Draven (The Late Brandon Lee) and Shelly Webster (Sofia Shinas) have been murdered in Devil's Night by a vicious gang of murderers (David Patrick Kelly, Angel David, Michael Massee & Laurence Mason). A year later... A Crow brought Eric back to life to put the wrong things right here, because his soul is unrested. Eric takes revenge on those, you have murder him and his girlfriend.Directed by Alex Proyas (Dark City-Garage Days-I, Robot) made an familiar but terrific revenge fantasy thriller. This film works well thanks to sharp cast including:Ernie Hudson, Micheal Wincott, Ling Bai, Rochelle Davis (Her only film), Anna Thomson, Tony Todd, Marco Rodriguez and Jon Polito. Brandon Lee died on the set making this film, this could have been a breakthrough film for Lee but sadly this was Lee's last film.This film is Based on a Comic Book/Strip by James O'Barr. To Complete the film, Dream Quest Images manage to complete the film with digital effects to make Lee seems visible in the film. It's about 20% of the film actually used digital effects to complete the film for Lee's uncompleted role. This film was a Box Office hit and went on to be a cult success on video. Do not miss this terrific film. Followed by three sequels. a t.v. series & two made for television film, based on the t.v. series. Written by David J. Schow & John Shirley. (**** ½/*****).

Review title: This movie will infect your soul
Review_body: What can I say. Each day I find myself quoting The Crow at least a dozen times. Usually people just give me strange looks. Sometimes (like when I say, "I got stabbed! I shot the sonnovabitch! I watched the bullet hole close by itself. And then my business gets blown up real good. Other than that, my day sucked!") people call security on me.This movie is a one-of-a-kind. It's grunge, it's goth, it's dark, it's funny, it's touching and it's inspiring... even if it merely inspires you to slap mime makeup on your face and walk the streets at night yelling, "I guess it's not a good day to be a bad guy, huh SKANK?!!"Seriously, as Roger Ebert said, it's an experience. Even though the plot is pretty straightforward (rockstar gets killed & comes back from the grave to seek revenge), it's done in a way that keeps you riveted every minute. The same way "Peewee's Big Adventure" is just about a guy looking for his bike, The Crow takes the same approach of using a minimalist plot and coating it in heaps of style, music and surreal visuals. Except The Crow has a few dozen more murders than Peewee.What makes this film a visual feast is the way it stylistically mirrors the comic book that inspired it. Like the comic, it's very monochrome... almost black & white, but with some icy tints to it. It has a very wet look to it, making it seem glossy and muted at the same time. Like another favourite film of mine "City of Lost Children", it achieves a certain vivid appearance even though the colour palette is very limited.As far as action flicks go, this is quite a literary extravaganza. Quotes from Poe's "The Raven", Milton's "Paradise Lost", Thackeray's "Vanity Fair" and who knows what else, lend an air of classiness and antiquity to the film. And of course the movie generates its own memorable quotes. Like "Greed is for amateurs. Disorder, chaos, anarchy... now that's fun!" Paired with an entertaining script full of great zingers, the acting is first rate all around. Each & every character, no matter how large or minor, delivers a memorable performance. Of course Brandon Lee is the standout, playing the cold-hearted, vengeful killer but with a gentleness that makes you want to take him home to meet your folks. Conversely, the bad guys are brutal but so comic you can't help but love them.A word about Brandon's death... yes, it's true that he was killed by a malfunctioning prop gun during the apartment scene. But that reel of film was reportedly destroyed by the director. The movie still had several scenes that needed to be filmed, and the director compensated by recycling other scenes with some very interesting effects. For example, when Brandon punches the mirror, it's actually a double punching the mirror with Brandon's "reflection" (from another scene) digitally imposed on the glass. Tricks like that are not obvious, and they add a certain otherworldly feel to the movie. It also makes the film feel more fragmented and incomplete (in a good way), leaving more to the imagination. If you're like me and you hate movies that over-explain everything, the minimalistic presentation of The Crow will be right up your alley.Lastly, the music. If you were alive & remotely cool in the 90s you'll love the soundtrack. The Cure, Nine Inch Nails, Rage Against the Machine, Violent Femmes, Stone Temple Pilots, Henry Rollins, the list goes on...If you're familiar with the director Alex Proyas, you'll recognize this as possibly his greatest work (alongside "Dark City", "Garage Days" and some great, surreal music videos like Sting "All This Time"). The feel of The Crow is also reminiscent of director Frank Miller's work ("The Spirit", "Sin City"). And although I haven't seen it, I've heard the Batman film "Dark Knight" pays tribute to this film, particularly Heath Ledger's Joker who is hauntingly close to Brandon Lee's character. If you like artsy movies, this fits right in, reminding me of Jean Pierre Jeunet ("City of Lost Children", "Delicatessen") and the darker side of Tim Burton ("Sweeny Todd"). Maybe there's even a bit of "Blade Runner" thrown in.If you get a chance, see The Crow on a rainy night with all the lights off. Lose yourself in the mood, the music and the memory of Brandon, the greatest star who never was. Halloween is coming up, so get your favourite Crow costume ready. If you live in a sheltered town like mine, chances are nobody will recognize who you're supposed to be. Although quite a few people think I'm Edward Scissorhands who is also pretty cool, so whatever...

Review title: Over-the-top action film, I wanted it to be more dark and serious.
Review_body: I believe this film is overpraised all because of Brandon Lee's death. It's still a pretty good movie, but far from great. The main problem is that it's theme is serious, but it's funny body. Everything's over-the-too in thus film, homor, action, acting, etc. It's a fun watch, but I believe it would have had been a lot better if it was darker and more serious, like Batman Begins, The Dark Knight or Watchmen.

Brandon Lee reminds me of Heath Ledger as Joker and I think Lee would also be perfect Joker. Movie has dark vibe, mostly because it's always night and raining. It is such a shame that he died on set but at least his last film is unforgettable and he will always be remembered.

The Crow is a great looking, stylized dark comic book film that is nicely shot with a lot of action. This is unfortunate for star Brandon Lee and would be his final film role as he died making this due to an accident on set. Borrowing a lot from the horror genre, the movie has a dark atmosphere and has a Gothic/industrial music soundtrack in the background. The revenge theme is played out here as Eric Draven (Lee) returns from the dead to send his killers of himself and his girlfriend to hell. The fights are savage and don't come across as too slick or choreographed. The gunplay gives a nod to John Woo with double revolver shootouts. The supporting cast is good, especially Ernie Hudson. The Crow is followed by a sequel and a television series and would be a cult classic that would influence a lot of movies and pop culture in the future.

Review title: Not living up to its hype
Review_body: The Crow is an action and revenge movie. Eric Draven, with his girlfriend was murdered by four criminals. But their deaths was unjust and Draven, with the help of a raven, one who connects the living with the afterlife, Draven returns to claim revenge. And the punishment can only be death.Alone, Draven takes on the entire criminal organization of crime lord Top Dollar, whose gang killed him once. And it is easy, since Draven is already dead and can't be hurt. He is indestructible and invincible. Until Top Dollar figures out that it is the raven that gives Draven his superhuman powers.Not a very entertaining story, since it doesn't get any suspense until the final ten minutes, and barely then either. Draven, with his powers, is simply to powerful. There is no threat to him. What it is is an action packed dark story. The scenery is very dark, it is always raining and the Gothic influence is heavy. Visually it is interesting, but not very good either.Had Draven been vulnerable somehow, this could have been really good. Now, ironically, it is mostly known and interesting since lead actor Brandon Lee died in an accident while filming it. Had the accident never occurred, I believe this movie would have been forgotten long ago.I feel that it is a movie one should have seen. But it wasn't very memorable, unfortunately.4/10

Most of the people turned out to see the Crow after hearing that Bruce Lee's son, Brandon Lee was killed while filming one of the action scenes. Much like his father's tragic ending, he too had a film that was being made when he came to the same conclusion in his life. Much of the public had no clue who Brandon Lee was until he was dead. While the Martial Arts audience knew a lot about him, the typical American movie audience hadn't a clue. The same went for the movie. Not too many people knew what it was about or who the star of the film was. Because of the so called "mystery" and "conspiracy" behind his death, Brandon Lee's end made The Crow an instant Cult Classic.A story of revenge and timeless love, The Crow is an interesting film with a great supporting casts. Ernie Hudson along with others create well rounded and very dark cast which Brandon Lee does justice as the movie's star. Overall, his true life death makes the movie more real when at times, you forget about the movie's plot and know that somewhere during the movie, Brandon would have a date with death.

Review title: See it for its visual style and Lee
Review_body: 'The Crow' has two interesting things. The first is Brandon Lee's final performance, since this is the movie where he was killed in the making. His performance, may be because he was killed, is very interesting. The other reason to see this movie is the visual style. With a great production design and a very fine cinematography you almost have the perfect look for a comic book movie, what 'The Crow' is. The movie is dark, may be a little too dark at times, but knows its main characters and therefore chooses this great look.Still, for me it was not enough to like this movie. There were single scenes I did like but as a whole it wasn't very good. There is no story at all. Brandon Lee is Eric. He is killed and his wife is beaten and raped and dies in the hospital as well. According to the movie a crow takes your soul after you die. When the soul is not able to rest the crow can bring you back to make things right. Eric is brought back and it is time for revenge.It is not that I always want a story. Some movies have almost no story but are great anyway. This is not the kind of movie that can realize that. I understand when people do like this movie but it just didn't do it for me.

The Crow is an incredible action thriller that's fun, stylish, dark and emotional. Brandon Lee give an incredible lead performance, Ernie Hudson and Rochelle Davis are both great and Michael Wincott is a terrific villiain. Alex Proyas' direction is excellent, it's extremely well filmed and well paced. Despite some brief but poor visual effects, it holds up really well with great production design. The music by Graeme Revell is also great.

Review title: Classic film overshadowed by Lee's Untimely Death
Review_body: Terrific film that is often overshadowed by it's notoriety over Brandon Lee's unfortunate death. Based on the cult comic by James O'Barr, this film, adapted by splatterpunk writer David J. Schow, is true to it's source material, but director Alex Proyas, in his feature film debut, unmistakably leave his mark on the film. The story has Lee and his girlfriend are murdered by gang members, but Lee is resurrected as an avenging angel, or crow, who then seeks his revenge upon those who killed him and raped and murdered his girlfriend. Lee gives a strong performance in a part that easily could have been swallowed up under all the make-up, atmosphere, and action. With this as his final film appearance, it's purely speculative, but I really do believe this would have been his breakout film and would have made him a huge star. Besides Lee the film is bolstered by a strong supporting cast that includes Michael Wincott (who was all over the place in the 90s, but seems to have since disappeared), the underused Ernie Hudson, Bai Ling, Anna Thomson, the great David Patrick Kelly, Tony Todd, and Jon Polito. Production designer Alex McDowell also gets big props for his contribution to the film's moody fell, as does cinematographer Dariusz Wolski. Graeme Revell provides a terrific score that I regularly listen to to this day, but I think one of the major heroes of this film is the soundtrack, led off by the title song by The Cure. Back in the day I played this soundtrack endlessness. Some of the tracks, particularly the grunge ones, don't hold up so well (i.e. Stone Temple Pilots or For Love Not Lisa), but others like The Cure, Rage Against The Machine, Nine Inch Nails, Rollins Band, and even My Life With The Thrill Kill Kult still hold up. It's a killer soundtrack and is once again on high rotation in my car. The soundtrack alone should earn this film another star. But overall, this is a smart, scrappy, dark fantasy, that does deserve it's cult following.

This was a film that I only remember when it came out because of the controversy of its star, Brandon Lee, passing away during the filming. I never actually saw this film until after college and I did enjoy it. I got the chance for my second viewing to be in the theater I'm a member at as part of their Summer of 1994 series. The synopsis is a man brutally murdered comes back to life as an undead avenger of his and his fiancée's murder.We start this film on Devil's Night, which is an event in Detroit the day before Halloween. There are a ton of fires going on around the city, but we focus on an apartment that belongs to Eric Draven (Lee) and his fiancée Shelly (Sofia Shinas). They were supposed to be getting married on the following day, but they were attacked. Eric was thrown from their window, killing him. Shelly was raped and brutally beaten. Albrecht (Ernie Hudson) is there and he gets scolded by a detective for messing with his crime scene. On the way to the ambulance, a girl Sarah (Rochelle Davis) asks about the two who were attacked. She is quite close to them.It then shifts a year into the future. We learn through some voice-over narration that the crow takes the souls to the land of the dead. If something really bad happens, it can return it to the body to get vengeance. That's what happens here. Eric wakes up in his grave and returns to his apartment. He is quite upset about what has happened and decides to get his revenge.Those that attacked him are led by T-Bird (David Patrick Kelly). Working with him are Skank (Angel David), Tin Tin (Laurence Mason) and Funboy (Michael Massee). Eric's path starts with Tin Tin. It then leads him to Gideon (Jon Polito) and his pawn shop. When he blows it up, it draws the attention of Albrecht, who starts to look into the old case. On top of that, he also draws the attention of Top Dollar (Michael Wincott), Myca (Bai Ling) and Grange (Tony Todd). Top Dollar is actually T-Bird's boss and doesn't like what happened to Gideon's. He also doesn't like his men being picked off. Myca seems to know the lore about the crow and what is happening here, which means she might know of a way to stop him.Something that I remembered from the first time I saw this film was that it really feels like a comic book movie. That makes sense as it was based off a strip as well as being expanded into much larger form there. I will admit, I give the film a pass for some of its CGI look at the city since it has its roots in comic books.I do like the idea of this story. I know that crows are definitely birds that are associated with the underworld. There is a moment where Eric quotes Edgar Allan Poe's The Raven, which I thought was interesting. I know I've looked up what the difference is, but it is something that is escaping me while writing this. The lore that is used here that the crow can bring the soul back is good. The issue I had though was that I don't like Eric being invincible. This does get resolved late in the film, but I think I would have liked this to be explored earlier on.Since I've brought up how this is a comic book film, I love that they went rated R on this one. It is actually quite violent and I was down with that. The crime that is committed against Eric and Shelly is pretty heinous that the revenge he gets is quite justified. I like that he does mimic the same death with just different items. I almost would have liked to see that a bit more, but it does become problematic with some of the people he goes after.I do have to admit something here though; I do feel that this film has some pacing issues. I think that the film is too long for one thing. There are a quite a few scenes of Eric just brooding about what happened to him. I don't want all of them cut out, but we don't need as many of them as we get. I think that actually really hurt the film for me. I don't expect it to be all action all the time, but there had to be different things to do to break up the action if I'm perfectly honest. I do like how it ends and the stakes being raised for sure though.Something that I didn't have any issues with was the acting. Lee was really good here. He just had a good look about him and he really brought this character to life. I like the charisma that he had for sure. Davis was solid in her performance. She has a difficult role as she needs to act more adult, because her mother is an addict and she really has to take care of herself. I thought that she definitely played that pretty well. It was nice to see Hudson here. I thought he was good. Wincott, Ling, Kelly, Todd and the rest of the criminals I thought were all solid. Shinas has a minor role, but she was quite easy on the eyes. I would say that the rest of the cast did round out the film for what was needed.To move next to the effects of the film, I have to say that they're pretty hit or miss for me. The practical effects, like the blood and the deaths actually were good. I thought they looked pretty real which is all I can ask for. The problem comes from the CGI that is used. There are a few times that the crow was CGI and didn't look good. I can't fault it too much, but it did take me out at times. I won't hold it against the movie the city being CGI, as it has a comic book feel. The only real issue is with the CGI fire. I've said it before, this is actually an issue we still see today. I do think the film was shot well, which is definitely a plus.The last thing to cover would be the soundtrack, which I really liked. They did go heavy with the rock music and it fit. Eric was in a rock band before dying and I like that they embodied that. I also think it works because the city is dirty so it helps to establish that gritty feel.Now with that said, this film I did really enjoy the first time I saw it, but I do think after this second viewing my rating is coming down a bit. It does do some good things. First being that it's based off of a comic book, I like that they went with the hard R rating on this. The crime that starts this all is pretty heinous and makes the revenge work better for me. I like the lore that is used here, but I do think that they made Eric a bit too powerful for too long. The pacing of the film did have some issues for me, but I do like how things played out. There is just some filler that could be trimmed. The acting is good across the board, with a pretty solid cast. The practical effects of the film are good, but the CGI really isn't. Soundtrack of the film was also good and definitely helped to build how the film needed to feel. I would say that this film is definitely worth a watch, especially if you are into comic book films. I do have to say that this is above average for me though.

If there's one movie that will be forever known as the late Brandon Lee's best movie, it is this one. Sadly, the son of famous martial arts master Bruce Lee, would too suffer from a fatal injury on set, leading to his untimely death before this cult classic was released. What's completely astonishing though, is how well this movie was put together even after Lee's death. One would almost think that Lee only had died after the filming, but not so. There were several edits, body doubles and even CGI used to make it look like Lee was in whole film throughout. For 1994, that's extremely impressive. But this isn't the only outstanding thing to this comic book movie. There's very little to nit pick about.The story is about Eric Draven, a regular everyday man who witnesses the brutal rape and murder of his wife to-be and is killed off as well. This all happens during Halloween (or Devil's Night as its called) in a crime ridden city where buildings are set ablaze just for fun. A year later, Draven is resurrected by a single crow to take vengeance upon the people who took his and wife's life that same night. In the simplest of terms, it is a revenge story, but the execution is done in such a way that gives depth to each character on screen. Alex Proyas, who begins his directorial debut here, keeps a steady pace as well. Of course, the person who carries majority of the entertainment is Brandon Lee.Brandon Lee as Eric Draven gives a performance that feels natural. His delivery of lines are not over-the-top campy, nor are they boring. His voice allows the character to sound serious or kind whenever it is needed. The costume design is also great looking as well. It matches not only the Gothic tone, but also the whole design as a comic book movie. Attempting to understand Draven's case is Sergeant Albrecht (Ernie Hudson). Hudson is one of those actors who most viewers enjoy in whatever film he stars in because of how relaxed he comes across. The main villain behind Devil's Night is called Top Dollar (Michael Wincott) who also gives a performance that is precise with his delivery. He's an anarchist, so all he wants is chaos, thus creating Devil's Night.The violence portrayed here is another strong point. There's no plotting or brooding. All it is, is pure vengeance and no holds bar. It's taking care of business with no thinking which is beneficial to this kind of revenge film. That and the dialog used throughout each scene makes the revenge feel that much more justified. What's surprising, is how it feels like this is the movie that inspired other anti-hero films to do the same kind of theatrics. For example, having an outline symbol lit by flames? The Punisher (2004) and Daredevil (2003) performed those same types of moves during their moments of payback. The Crow (1994) is still the antihero that started it all and should be given respected for that.The special effects have aged rather well too. With most of the background being dark with either black or grey, it's difficult to see what was enhanced by computer and what wasn't. The crows themselves are hard to distinguish between actor and CGI. Dariusz Wolski's cinematography is neat with panning shots of the city that'll make the viewer feel like they are the crow in the sky gliding across the landscape. Wolski would later do all the cinematography for all the Pirates of the Caribbean films. The editing is also competently done considering it looks like Lee was on set for the whole movie even though he died during filming. The only thing that could've been slightly fixed was the music. Graeme Revell's score does contain a soft reoccurring theme, which focuses that on Draven's humanity and love for his wife with gentle flutes. Revell's music also contains saxophone, which is rare for an action film but it works. It makes it feel like a film noir in some senses. Yet, the score lacks any real action cues, other than tribal drums, which make it feel empty in some cases. Also, it's understood that the movie has a Gothic tone but including metal bands in a few scenes wasn't necessary either. Instead Revell could've included tunes that particularly enhanced them with more power and emotion. Other than that, there really isn't anything to truly be upset about. It's one of those rare, dark comic book adaptations that any comic book reader should watch.Although it was Brandon Lee's last film, it's one of his best. The action is dark, special effects look good and the actors pitch great performances. It's Graeme Revell's score that could use some improvement although it is still a special element to the film.

Review title: Brandon Lee was to the crow what heath ledger was to the joker
Review_body: Nearly 25 years ago the only son of Bruce Lees final film came out and became a sensation and changed the way comic book movies were aimed at mature audiences. The alt rock soundtrack along with an epic score by Graham revell that has been used for trailers for movies such as pearl harbor makes this movie a must own.

The Crow is a film that I knew I would like before I even watched it. Directed by Alex Proyas, who also directed my favourite sci/fi flick of all time, Dark City, works his Gothic magic here and shows us that not all fantasy/comic book films have to be immature.Whenever I talk to people about The Crow, they either love it (because it's apparently the new emo thing to do, just like Darko) or hate it because it was too dark. Both of these reasons are unfair to an intelligent and well directed film.Although the idea of revenge in films has been done to death numerous times before, The Crow takes a unique approach to the subject. This is mainly due to the main character himself, who is a favourite of mine. Well acted by Brandon Lee, who tragically died on the set of the film. Much like the death of health Ledger, one can only imagine what his career would have been like if he were still alive today.Alex Proyas is someone to look out for in his future projects, his weakest film, I, Robot is still pretty decent. I think he is underrated as is this film. It's a shame that they made so many crappy sequels that the original sometimes gets thrown into that bad mix. I mean come on, Furlong as The Crow? I can't take that seriously. As it is today, this film stands out from those and many other comic book flicks. It's definitely in my top 5 comic book adaptations and in a sense it breaks that genre, well before Dark Knight did. But not many people see that.If you haven't seen this one, pick it up now. It's Gothic atmosphere, great direction and acting will draw you in. The story of love, revenge and redemption is one for the ages.

Review title: "The Crow"- A Gothic masterpiece of action, suspense and emotion. One of the defining films of the 90's.
Review_body: "People once believed that when someone dies, a crow carries their soul to the land of the dead. But sometimes, something so bad happens that a terrible sadness is carried with it and the soul can't rest. Then sometimes, just sometimes, the crow can bring that soul back to put the wrong things right."Those are the words that usher us into the world of director Alex Proyas' legendary film "The Crow," based of course on the beloved comic book created by James O'Barr. The film is a defining masterpiece of its decade, and a dark and Gothic portrayal of action, romance and vengeance that thrilled audiences and remains a cult-classic to this very day, more than twenty years later. Though overshadowed by the tragic loss of its star Brandon Lee, whom was accidentally killed in an on-set incident, the fact remains that there's something special here. Something that cannot be stopped by the misfortune of Lee's passing. Something provocative and moving. Something that spoke to audiences when it was released in 1994 and still very much does.The film follows Eric Draven (Lee), a rock-and-roll guitarist who is slain- along with his fiancée Shelly- the night before their wedding in an apparent gang attack. One year later, he is brought back to life through the power of a crow- who are said to carry the souls of the dead into the afterlife. Now granted an array of supernatural (and superhuman) abilities that render him seemingly immortal, Eric stalks the night on a mission of revenge against those who destroyed his life. He receives help from Sarah (Rochelle Davis), a young girl who had befriended Shelly before her death and kind-hearted cop Albrecht (Ernie Hudson) in his hunt for retribution. What Eric doesn't realize, however, is just how far into the dark and criminal underworld he'll have to go, nor will he be able to predict the severity and intricacy of his search...I think a great deal of the magic of "The Crow" lies in the fact that while not particularly original and reliant on plenty of cliché and convention, it fundamentally excels at everything it sets out to do with a level of style and competence that is far beyond the standard Hollywood film. We've seen this story and these ideas before. But not told in quite this same way. The film isn't content with just giving us a standard visual palette... instead it crafts a complex and Gothic atmosphere that's striking and visually engaging, and combines different filmmaking techniques to create a world all its own. The characters aren't just archetypes... they're fully fleshed out and even the more minor of characters are given a great deal of establishment and development. The film doesn't just follow the standard path... but rather it gives us a stirring narrative where stakes are constantly raised and because of the supernatural elements at play, we can never guess what's going to come next. The original comic came from a very unique place, and it's clear that the cast and crew of the film are going above and beyond to craft a masterpiece.To build upon this, the performances are a phenomena and lend much to the story. Lee is a revelation, and injects not only plenty of pathos and agony into the role of Draven... but also a large amount of hope and joy. Conflicted though he may be, he's still willing to do the right thing by other people and to help them even in his war of violence and vengeance. Hudson and Davis round out our protagonists in nuanced and sensitive roles that very much compliment Draven's struggles and help to inject some heart into the narrative so that it never feels bogged down by the rampant darkness of the story. And our villains- including David Patrick Kelly, Tony Todd, Bai Ling and the extremely underrated Michael Wincott are all deliciously evil, yet still feel somewhat grounded and "real." It's a great rogues gallery for Draven to face off against with some top- notch performers behind them.And finally, the film is a complete powerhouse of visual storytelling. As mentioned above, director Alex Proyas seemingly builds and entire new world with the help of writers David J. Schow and John Shirley, in addition to his inspiration from James O'Barr's original comic. The colors are cold and stark. The designs sharp and vast. And the contrast in color and darkness is simply outstanding. Proyas takes inspiration from many sources and his slick, flowing camera-work perfectly compliments the twisted Gothic world that is crafted. He knows how to showcase both his actors and his sets for maximum emotional impact, and the film is never anything less than completely absorbing and wondrous to behold."The Crow" is by far and quite easily one of the defining films of the 1990's. With an impact still being felt to this day, definitive demonstrations of themes and visual nuances, stunning performances and a memorable message, it's no wonder why the film has maintained such a strong and dedicated following. And though its effects and ideals might feel somewhat antiquated or even dated by films that have gone on to successfully improve on the techniques used and defined here, you simply cannot downplay how big an impact its had on popular culture. It's a stunning work of art through-and- through and easily earns a perfect 10 out of 10.

Review title: Brandon Lee - A Great loss to the Movie world
Review_body: The Crow sadly turned out to be Brandon Lee's swan song, but if a movie was ever befitting such an honour, this was undoubtedly it.Eric Draven (Brandon Lee) was a rock star who was brutally murdered along with his girlfriend on devil's night. One year later he is granted superhuman strength and vision so he can seek vengeance on those responsible.This terrifically dark and Gothic style fantasy is truly compelling and charged with emotion. The action is used sparingly to great effect creating some fantastic scenes that are both visually impressive and brilliantly entertaining. The story, the direction and the performance from Brandon Lee are all excellent.The Crow is a great movie 8/10 R.I.P Brandon, you're fans miss you

Aside from the impeccably created landscape that the events of the movie take place in; "The Crow" works for two reasons: The villains of the piece are completely despicable, so we root for their comeuppance to be justifiably served, and also the avenger in this case is played by Brandon Lee. This perfect casting of both 'good' and 'evil' is crucial to the film's success. You could see that Brandon was such a genuine and emotionally honest performer, even though he was still just a fledgling in career terms by 1993. It helps that the lines are so clearly drawn, because we can then take total pleasure from the artfully constructed, gloomy setting.All of the main cast do well, but there is an especially wicked delight to be drawn from Michael Wincott's portrayal. On the evidence of this he deserves a much higher profile, because he's utterly magnetic at every point within the movie. All good confrontations need a memorable hero and villain - we get both here. So allow the darkness to envelop you, don't even think about entertaining any of the amateurish sequels, and let Alex Proyas and Co. take you on a gut-wrenching journey of dogged retribution.

Future flavours and concentrates abound for epic movies that would appear a decade or more later in various superhero franchise and still do. It's also riven by Noirish elements of some years precedent and consumes a significant measure of Goth/Punk music culture and stylisation e.g. The Sisters of Mercy, Siouxsie Sue, X-Ray Specs and Gene Loves Jezebel, none of which would have looked out of place on set. Shows its age a bit now but the themes are perpetual.

Eighteen years after the terribly unfortunate death of future star Brandon Lee and it still cannot be accepted any easier. Seventeen years after the release of The Crow and it remains the dark, stylish comic adaptation it was celebrated as. This film holds up remarkably well, the computer effects adding rather than subtracting from the story, which is by itself more than rich enough to carry the film. Here we have one of the most common and potentially powerful story lines in the movies: a dead soul returns to Earth (usually one year later) to exact revenge on those who put him here in the first place. However, thanks to the powerful storytelling of James O'Barr and director Alex Proyas fantastic direction, the film focuses not simply on the acts of revenge themselves but also on the protagonist's relationships with the people around him. Most effective of all is the memory element in which the resurrected Eric Draven must recall various timeless moments spent with his slain fiancée and the young girl they cared for. Here is where the film gets the bulk of its emotional material, which makes the acts of revenge at once both violent and satisfying.So much has been written about Lee's performance and the cutting short of his promising career. This is all true but to focus on this film, he creates a sympathetic, driven individual who must sacrifice his own desires to complete this mission he is sent back for. The supernatural element is effective without being too ridiculous, the set design is one of the best ever created and the acting carries the heavy scenes all the way, paving the way for a startling and satisfying conclusion. The themes may be familiar, but the style and substance with which it is presented on screen is unsurpassed. Watching this film, one cannot help but feel that heavy tone of elegiac sadness which hangs over the entire production. Of course it is because of Lee but also because of the story itself. When tragedy strikes, the best the living can do for the dead is love them. This is as emotionally powerful and moving as films get.

Brandon Lee stars as Eric Draven a rock star who was killed on the night before his wedding along with his girlfriend Shelly(Sofia Shinas) however a year later Draven rises from the dead and looks to avenge himself and his girlfriend's death. David Patrick Kelly, Michael Wincott and Ernie Hudson co-star in this dark yet romantic vigilante thriller. I remember reading about how Brandon Lee died on the set of The Crow and all the comparisons to his father and all that jazz, however despite Lee's tragic death, The Crow is easily his best work. (Keep in mind I haven't seen Laser Mission and Legacy Of Rage, although I have ordered Legacy on Amazon) Brandon Lee is an action star who I have always thought of as too much of a nice guy to really get down and dirty to take out the bad guys, this time this usual weakness actually becomes the film's biggest strength. Lee's nice guy approach to the madness that occupies his character works in creating more impact than usual. Also it helps that Lee speaks almost beautiful dialog when dispatching the bad guys. In fact there is one startling scene where Lee doesn't even speak and let's the bad guy figure it all out on his own, to which the bad guy says "Abashed the devil stood and felt awful goodness is..." This is a great movie. I can see why so many people like it, it is one of the few revenge movies out there that actually rise above guilty pleasure and provide a show worth seeing over and over again.* * *1/2 out of 4-(Very Good)

Alex Proyas's "The Crow" was an amazing piece of work. "The Crow" is on the surface a brutal and unforgiving tale of vengeance, that somehow transforms itself into a truly touching Gothic romance. And the tragedy of it all is that it was both a milestone performance and the last performance of Brandon Lee. Brandon totally commands the screen. He had true screen presence. Charismatic. Handsome. He was an excellent martial artist, who had the grace of a dancer. Lee gave Eric Draven a soul. You understand his anger and sadness. His relationship in the world of the living with Sarah (Rochelle Davis) is both touching and moving. Through Lee's performance you get that ultimately this path of violence and vengeance is really about his undying love for Shelly (Sofia Shinas). Brandon Lee will forever remain young in the movies. He would have been the next great martial arts superstars... and he would have become a gifted actor. There is sense of loss in this.

Review title: There only one Eric Draven and his name is Brandon Lee
Review_body: If Bruce Lee most famous for his yellow jumpsuit in Game of Death then Brandon Lee with his painted face gives us his best performance and the iconic Eric Draven in The Crow but just like his legendary father Bruce Lee the Devil one gain took him from us way too early when he died on set of The Crow and left us with one of the best superhero movie in the 90s.Fill with great atmosphere of a never ending dark city full of miserable people Eric Draven and his girlfriend Shelly live to the fullest of their life until a gang of thugs knocking on the door.Ressurected by an unknow force Eric now hell bent on revenge while link with a crow start to deliver street justice in the most gruesome ways possible.Brandon got the change to perfecting his skills as an actor in the role of Eric and he may not go full kung-fu in The Crow when most of the action is gun violence but again who need martial art when you already a bad-ass immortal being.There's rumor about Hollywood want to remake The Crow for the new audience with Jason Momoa as Eric and I'm maybe not very fond of the ideal but whoever put the picture of Jason Momoa as Eric on Imdb need to take a chill pill now

Review title: This is a movie the way I like'em
Review_body:
The Crow should be, hell is a classic (you can tell by the way it is done, plus they are making tons of sequels etc.) and it rightly so is one. It has got a good and fitting soundtrack, a dark town (very Blade Runner), a determined yet cool' hero, freaked out bad guys (I especially like Michael Wincott, he's made some cool movies, like Alien Resurrection and Metro (OK this wasn't like a Hit, but it was better than Murphy's other sh.t, like Nutty Professor 1 + 2, Doctor Dolittle and so on)). Plus the film has got a lot of emotion (greatly brought forward by the music of Graeme Revell as well), mysticism, a few jokes and good characters. That along with the good story, the good direction plus the good cast makes this really worth a look. I only wonder what is up with that editing, was the movie edited cause it was too violent or was it just badly edited (101 Minutes was printed on the package, but the ending credits started after 90 minutes (I guess they included Brandon Lee's last interview in the running time) . Well when I'm stepping on bad things here I might just as well mention the other thing. This film was not as exciting and I wasn't on the edge of my seat, hey but no film is perfect (that's why my highest vote is a 9 out of 10).
The thing I liked most about this movie was Brandon Lee (a pity he had to leave this world so early). He played a freaked and psychotic hero really good and cool. Plus he played the guitar pretty good and walked around as what most people though was supposed to be some kind of a clown. To me it was more like a dark, rock and gothic avenger, why, cause I'd like it that way. I think people who dress up like that and walk around have got balls plus they are original and I like them for that. That's also why I like Eric Draven as the Avenger. OK it looks cool too and I probably wouldn't have liked it if it would have been, like Clint Eastwoood, but what the hell.
8 out of 10
