Review_body: Watched The Crow Featuring an Amazing Performance from a Stellar Lead Brandon Lee(Showdown In Little Tokyo) as Eric Draven/The Crow . Also Featuring Ernie Hudson(Ghostbusters)as Sgt.Albrecht,Rochelle Davis as Sarah, Sofia Shinas(Terminal Velocity) as Shelly Webster, Bai Ling(Pen Pals) as Myca .David Patrick Kelly(Malcolm X) as T-bird , Jon Polito(Millers Crossing) as Gideon,Tony Todd(Candyman ) as Grange, Michael Massee(A la Folie) as Funboy, Laurence Mason(Joey Breaker) as Tin-Tin, and Michael Wincott(Alien:Resurrection) as Top Dollar, The Film Was interesting also great Characters arcs for being a Small story it was a great Revenge Thriller also incredible performance from Lee as the Vigilante the Crow it was great for being a Dark Fantasy Neo-Noir Superhero Action film One of The best revenge film.amazing Cinematography by Dariuz Wolski(Romeo Is Bleeding) , Costume design from Arianne Phillips(Attack Of The 50 Foot Woma), Musical Score from Graeme Revell(Street Fighter) ,Screenplay By John Shirley(The Specialist) & David J.Schow(Critters 4) and Direction from Alex Proyas(Dark City ) One Of The Best Revenge Films 9/10

Review title: A Classic Genre Role For An Immortal Hero...
Review_body: We'll probably never know what would've happened to the first movie in THE CROW series, if Brandon Lee were still walking around today. Unfortunately, it will forever be stained with the reputation as the film that ultimately led to his death, and because of that fact, even today it carries with it an aura of mystery and a powerful attraction for the morbidly curious. It's worth noting that it's also one helluva good-looking, well-paced Gothic drama.The graphic novel by James O'Barr, upon which THE CROW is based, was less the product of a dark and disturbed mind than the result of O'Barr metaphorically cutting himself wide open and just splattering his guts all over the pages. As a way of dealing with the shocking and untimely death of his fiancée, (yes, that really DID happen), this pitch-black drama is the result.Set in a bleakly nihilistic future, it's the story of struggling rock musician and artist Eric Draven, (Lee), and his girlfriend Shelley (Sofia Shinas), who become the latest victims of a brutal crime wave instigated by crazed kingpin Top Dollar (Michael Wincott). By the power of supernatural events and sheer force of will, Draven comes back from the dead and literally rips his way through the crime lord's minions to get to him. Of course, not a lot of this attracts the attention of local law enforcement, save the man who is probably the last good cop left in the world, let alone the entire city, Sergeant Albrecht (Ernie Hudson.) Witnessing all the carnage is a young girl named Sarah (Rochelle Davis) the narrator of the story, who together with Albrecht are basically the only friends the undead vigilante has. Directed by DARK CITY'S Alex Proyas from a pretty faithful screenplay by horror author David J. Schow and John Shirley, THE CROW was one of the innovative Gothic dramas based on graphic novels, that successfully paved the way for so many of the others that have come out since (FROM HELL, A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE, V FOR VENDETTA, etc.) All of them have their merit, but none have quite the oppressive feel for gloom and doom that THE CROW has. Much of this quality is due to the outstanding job on production design by Alex McDowell and the cinematography of Dariusz Wolski, whose pictures painted so evocatively with textures and shadows recall the best work of the late, great Conrad Hall.But great movies don't get that way based strictly on the technical aspects, and I do believe that if he had lived, Brandon Lee's rage-and-angst-filled performance as the anguished (and unendingly angry) Draven would've finally gotten him the notice, respect and the kind of work that he craved so much while building the foundation for his career. And because he steps up so intensely with his work, it makes the rest of the cast raise their game as well. Genre favorites abound here, from GHOSTBUSTER'S Hudson and Wincott, to DREAMSCAPE'S David Patrick Kelly and longtime vet and perennial heavy Jon Polito. Also helping it's classic cult status is a killer soundtrack that has to be one of the best "alterna-goth" collections in genre history (a close tie with RETURN OF THE LIVING DEAD and THE LOST BOYS.) This was the time when I either "discovered" or re-discovered bands such as The Cure ("Burn"), Machines of Loving Grace ("Golgotha Tenement Blues"), NIN/Trent Reznor ("Dead Souls") and Stone Temple Pilots ("Big Empty").Also cementing its eternally creepy cachet is the fact that it was one of the first movies ever to use "digital technology" to manipulate the image of an actor unavailable to "finish" his role, (the film was completed after Brandon's death.) Only the sharpest of eyes might be able to figure out where the real Brandon's performance ends and the "digital stand-in's" begins, but then again, why bother? This is his legacy, and even if it weren't, the movie deserves better than merely that kind of scrutiny.This is just one more classic that demands to become a permanent part of your library.

Review title: Beware the revenge of The Crow
Review_body: "The Crow" is adapted from James O'Barr's 1989 graphic novel. It's not the first movie made by Alex Proyas (his debut was an obscure arty post-holocaust film "Spirits of the Air, Gremlins of the Clouds" from 1989) , but it's the one movie that made him famous and promised a great things in the future from Proyas . Along with "The Dark city" it's still his best movie , despite it's been almost 20 years since it's premiere. At it's heart it's a simple revenge movie told with lot of mood . It has soul and it's one of best comic book movies.Alex Proyas is a former music video director and it shows here . The movie resembles an rock video . There is a lot of rock songs in the background , the main hero is an ex-rockstar , the whole movie feels like a energetic video clip. "The Crow" is a dark movie with black and white easily dominating the screen. It's not a black and white movie , yet other colors are lifeless , well fitting with the overall mood of the movie. "The Crow" easily draws you in it's world , into this unnamed city and it's residents. The Gothic architecture reminds of Tim Burton's "Batman". The grotesque parody of clown makeup on Brandon Lee's face feels strangely familiar to Heath Ledger's joker in "The Dark knight". There are more similarities between two actors – both movies are great , they both died in suspicious circumstances at the peek of their careers , both actors and movies gained a massive cult following.Brandon Lee gives a good performance . It's not as amazing as Ledger's and definitely not an Oscar material , yet it is obviously his best performance and proof that he had potential to become a real legend. The movie is dedicated to Brandon and Eliza. Eliza Hutton is a fiancée of Brandon . They were to have been married less than two weeks after the film wrapped. It's obvious that "The Crow" attracted attention in the media because of Brandon Lee's tragic death . The story about a youth brutally killed in his prime so ironically reflected events in real life. Keith David gives a good support as the experienced cop and friend of Eric. The action set-pieces are immensely exciting . Instead of typical summer blockbuster one – liners we have lines like : "Mother is the name of God on every child's lips," "Little things used to mean so much to Shelly. I used to think they were trivial. Believe me, nothing is ever trivial." Quite poetic.My advice – don't listen to all those rumors about Brandon's death or his father's , Bruce Lee death too . Just enjoy this movie . A well crafted arty entertainment. Watch this and don't waste your time on the lame sequels. I give it 8/10.

'The Crow' is not only a visual masterpiece, but also one of the best comic book adaptations. The story is simple, but effective and all the performances excellent. It's so sad what happened to Brandon Lee during filming.

Review title: Brandon Lee Giving His Final Awesome Acting To The World
Review_body: "Brandon Lee is awesome, his acting is brilliant, I'm sad that he died during the scene in this movie, but I'm happy that he giving his final awesome acting to the world with this movie, what a amazing acting, and what a amazing movie, I highly recommend"

Review title: a good film, not for the birds
Review_body: 'The Crow' was one of the popular movies during my years growing up. In that time, Metallica was popular, and there were a lot of goths. This film really appealed to them because it had the whole goth, dark style, the sadness/bittersweet love, and the music appreciated so much by that audience. This film succeeded very well in capturing the hearts of the young goth in the late 1980s and early 1990s.This film would probably be best enjoyed by those who grew up with it, because I think it has so much more meaning beyond its story and visuals. Done well, this film has a little bit of everything and there isn't any reason why someone watching it today for the first time would not enjoy it.

The Crow opens with a voiceover reading this myth: "People once believed that when someone dies, a crow carries their soul to the land of the dead. But sometimes, something so bad happens that a terrible sadness is carried with it, and the soul can't rest. Then sometimes, just sometimes, the crow can bring that soul back, to put the wrong things right."The Crow is mythmaking at its best. Eric Draven (Lee) is brought back from the dead to avenge the rape and murder of his wife and his own murder. While filming the scene where his character is shot dead at the beginning of The Crow, in order to return to life as an immortal Jesus figure, the cap from the blank hit him and lodged in his spine, and Brandon Lee died. The way Lee's death on set at that particular moment fit into the myth of the movie is just as much to do with the cult status of this picture, as its fantastic gothic landscape, exciting story, gorgeous score and irresistable central figure.Brandon Lee, being interviewed about The Crow, was asked about death and his character in the film. He said this:"Because we do not know when we will die we get to think of life as an inexhaustible well. And yet everything happens only a certain number of times. And a very small number, really. How many more times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood. An afternoon that is so deeply a part of your being that you can't even conceive of your life without it. Perhaps four or five times or more. How many more times will you watch the full moon rise? Perhaps twenty. And yet it all seems limitless."He died not long after. This was his last interview.

Is the Crow a great film? No but Proyas' masterful directing makes it a much better one. The Crow is your standard vigilante revenge flick with some odd improvements to make it different. The story isn't original you can catch glimpses of other things in there. However I do have to recommend The Crow.The Late Brandon Lee makes his exit on a high note. The movie is all too ironic for him because his tragic death matches that of his characters all most on the dot. Lee creates an interesting character. I suspect that had he lived he could have been more than just your action star.Proyas deserves all the credit in the world. He is the driving force behind this movie. He gives a Gothic feel and the visuals and camera work are absolutely gorgeous. Tim Burton get's praised for doing half of what Proyas does. He is our greatest dark film maker.

Review title: One of the best films ever
Review_body: Proyas's dark film about a brutally murdered man who comes back from the dead to punish those who hurt him and his fiancé'e. The book which is adapted from a comic is written well and directed very well by Proyas. I liked Brandon Lee a lot in the lead here, shame what happened to him. This Gothic suspenseful flick is done very well, great cinematography from Dariusz Woltski and i loved the songs used, great soundtrack. Michael Wincott is a great villain, and i thought the rest of the cast was decent as well. This early film from Proyas makes me anxious to check out I, Robot. This was an amazing film-- IMDb rating: 7.4, my rating: 10/10

The tragic death of Brandon Lee looms large over this film, however, it only immortalizes his performance in this fascinating film. The style and production design are incredibly unique and help give The Crow a distinctive feel. It does hit some familiar revenge story beats, though the story has enough dramatic heft to overpower them. The Crow is a touching, stylish take on the classic revenge story.

Teenage me loved this film. I mean adored it. Partly for the aesthetic and a lot for its soundtrack. The soundtrack still stands up, it's the perfect slice of 90s fused industrial goth rock. NIN, The Cure, Mary Chain and the still fantastically named My Life With The Thrill Kill Kult, it was rarely out of my tape deck. Much was made of the loss of star Brandon Lee during filming, an accident with a gun sadly taking him at only 28. This really played into its instant cult appeal and of course only fuelled the dark tone of the film. This film isn't depressing though, it's hopeful, celebratory and smothered in revenge. It's pretty simple. Good guy comes back from the dead on Devils Night, a year after his death, to avenge his and the life of his fiancé. Systematically working his way through a gang of druggy occult loving criminals, all whilst coming to terms with his new found post-mortality, through flashbacks so stylised they instantly date it like a pop video. Lee is the epitome of the screen hero and style icon, donning the iconic make up and leather within the opening quarter hour. I'll be honest, the plot is basic, ridiculously predicable and obviously far-fetched. That's not really the point though, this is comic book fantasy territory (based on original work), each revenge scene set on a different page, tied together loosely in world in perpetual darkness, where it "Can't rain all the time", but seemingly does. It's over the top, packed with humour, playful and totally stands up. Yes it's of it's time, but it plays to that strength, classic good and evil. Even down to the casting, Lee is every bit the poster boy, head gangster Micheal Wincott is the very opposite, so much so I've always had a vivid distaste of him, something about his face I really dislike, he might be a nice bloke off screen but I find him revolting. Granted there may be some of my teenage goth tendencies influencing me here, but I still love this and I'm glad I took the time to revisit it, after all "Real love is forever". Right, where's my black lipstick and eyeliner?
I watched this on VHS when it first came out when I was 23. I loved it. But now at 49, it's just pants. It's very badly acted, it has cheap sets and it's just not very good. Bottom line in 2020: 5/10

The crow, is a tale of loss and retribution, love and sadness, but not without hope or it's fair share of (dark and sarcastic)humor! The main character portrayed brilliantly by Brandon Lee, is sympathetic, poetic and sometimes even philosophical, which doesn't in any way stop him from being also a total badass. The atmosphere and setting are amazing. The film manages to create a desolate urban environment, where it seems to constantly rain, and be a perpetual night. We get sweeping and awe inspiring looks of the city rooftops, and of it's dark crime infested alleyways. The supporting cast also does a wonderful job of creating despicable villains who yet doing horrible deeds manage to be entertaining and never dull, and also some innocent characters who show that not all is lost and there is hope still. Dialogue fitting the rest of the movie is never altogether happy, manages to be impressing as well. It will leave you with many memorable lines that you remember long after seeing the movie. When there are quotes of John Milton and Edgar Allan Poe, but it's the original lines that stand out the most it should say something! The action scenes are top notch, can be a bit graphic if you don't like violence, but as with the dialogue, there are many scenes that are iconic and memorable. All of it is stylized, but strays never too far from realism. Soundtrack manages to fill the movie mainly with 90's metal and grunge, which is to say with music that feels as natural in this movie as birds singing in Bambi. I am not gonna talk about the story itself, cause I want everybody to see this film. It's a milestone and a blueprint of how dark fantasy should be handled! 10/10 cause I can't think of anything that I didn't like or felt it could have been improved on in this movie.

As everyone already knows, actor Brandon Lee, son of Bruce, was accidentally killed during the filming of The Crow. His character in the film, Eric Draven, makes a spectacular return from the dead, making the coincidence all the more eerie. Lee actually died when hit with live ammunition during the filming of a shoot-out, but the living-dead Draven is magically healed each time a bad guy blasts him. Sticks and stones won't break his bones, and bullets will never harm him. Evidently, a double has been used to fill in the scenes that remained to be filmed at the time of the accident, but the movie is so shadowy and Lee's features so obscured by makeup that it is hard to tell what was done after the star's demise. Some computer trickery was also employed. The comic strip-inspired, action-packed adventure is quite something to see. The Crow is an art decorator/production designer's dream and should have been an Oscar contender. The MTVish direction is of the cut-and-run variety, but that is understandable when you read Alex Proyas's credits. He has directed commercials for Nike, Swatch, Nissan and Kleenex. The story is really secondary to the showy style. Draven and his girlfriend are murdered by thugs who invade their inner-city apartment. On a dark and stormy night that follows, Eric steps out of his grave and goes for revenge. Wearing black lip gloss, straggly curls and white pancake makeup, Lee looks a bit like a mime moonlighting as Michael Jackson. Accompanied by a big crow, the vengeful Eric sets about ridding his neighborhood of the resident lowlife. The dark and disturbing urban fantasy about a boy and his bird turns out to be more Death Wish than Edward Scrissorhands.

It looks a little dated. Some of the visual effects are really poor! But it looks gritty which isn't the best look for impressiveness. It is the only style that this movie could have had and so it looks amazing. It is good to see no computer generated effects. The sound has a subtle mix that can be very active when required. I liked the sound design in general a lot except that the dialogue was a little too quiet (not badly prioritised but overall too quiet). This is a true gothic masterpiece. The story is amazing, the concept is unbelievable, the acting is spot-on and the gothic atmosphere is the star of this classic movie. There is such a tragic story behind the film with is mimicked in the brooding moody and tragic story on-screen. A rare classic movie with a beautiful gothic noir style.

Review title: A dark, textured tale of vengeance
Review_body: The Crow will always be forever remembered for the notoriety surrounding it concerning Brandon Lee's on-set death. Such a tragedy, for if he had lived, he undoubtedly would have gone on to even greater things. Because he was more than just a fine martial artist (inherited from Bruce), he had true talent as an actor too. Nevertheless, Lee's death added an additional layer of symbolism to what was an already excellent undead revenge tale. It elevates it to classic status.Although in some ways The Crow has a fairly standard revenge plot, its added considerable depth and intelligence, not only because the subject matter becomes intertwined with Lee's real life circumstances, but also because of a rich and accessible screenplay by David J Schow and John Shirley, and the excellent kinetic direction by Alex Proyas.Alex Proyas originated as an MTV director. Usually whenever I see directors branch out into feature films whose background consists of music videos I get apprehensive. About 80% of them turn out films that are all style and no substance to speak of. Joel Schumacher is a particularly guilty offender.Proyas is that rare exception where he can create an atmosphere that becomes substance. He first demonstrated this ability with The Crow, and then outdid himself with his next venture, the quite extraordinary Dark City. One of the most intelligent science-fiction films ever made.The opening shots of The Crow highlight a devastated city. The night before Halloween. Or Devil's Night as its called here. A city in flames. On this unholy night, Eric Draven (Lee) and his fiancée Shelly are both killed by a ruthless gang of street hoods on the evening before their wedding day.Even at this early stage, we know anything can and will happen. In contrast to the violence on display, a child's voice narrates. A child called Sarah (Rochelle Davis' first and only film). She tells the haunting story of how a crow can bring the dead back to Earth to conclude unfinished business.And that's what happens to Eric. The following year, Eric claws his way out of his grave. Reborn. As an avenger of the night. Ready to take revenge on those who robbed him of his life. With the crow as his guide.The Crow is one of the greatest revenge tales ever made. Second only to Sin City, an equally brilliant comic book to film adaptation. Proyas gets right into the heart of it with barnstorming regard. And delivers on every level. From the very second Eric rediscovers himself as The Crow, its just the launching pad for a dizzying, exhilarating adventure.Brandon Lee was perfectly cast. Even when he's buried under striking makeup, he embodies the role so completely that he becomes the living personification of an avenging angel. Something I haven't seen since Tim Burton's Batman.His rich, baritone voice helps no end. And Proyas does everything he can to ensure that Lee cuts a striking, intimidating figure. Some of the camera shots gloriously highlight Lee's frame against a backdrop of breathtaking sunsets and ominous city streets. When he swoops through the air and makes his presence felt, he feels like a comic book character made flesh. One that's stepped right off the printed page. Into our world.The Crow is very exciting. And the whole tone of the film is as thrilling as its possible to get from this type of story. The action scenes are handled with almost operatic reverence. And its a testament to Lee's abilities as an actor that he's not swallowed up by the gritty, neo-noir world Proyas has surrounded him with.But The Crow is not always about the next kinetically driven action scene. Some moments are more thoughtful. And allows us to plumb the psychological depths of Lee's character. His scenes with Sarah are both haunting and poignant. She was Eric's friend in life. And remains his friend in death. Davis made an astonishing debut. Almost as astonishing as Lee's. Such an assured and commanding performance from someone so young. What a shame she never had the film career she so richly deserved. Again, like Lee.And Lee's scenes with Ernie Hudson are rewarding too. He plays a police sergeant who slowly sympathises with The Crow, and eventually helps him to bring down the gang. Schow and Shirley craft some exquisite dialogue from these two characters, and its all delivered perfectly too:"Little things used to mean so much to Shelly. I used to think they were trivial. Nothing is trivial."The grand finale is worthy of epic status. A final battle between the living and the dead. All helped with Proyas' atmospheric direction, and Graeme Revell's chilling, resonant musical score. The finishing touch to a superb, modern classic.As tragic as Lee's death was, it granted The Crow a unique place in history, and afforded it an immortality. This is one film that shall never be forgotten.

"The Crow" will always be remembered not for its story of revenge from beyond the grave, but the tragic death of Brandon Lee, who was shot by a faulty gun prop (And giving conspiracy fans reason to believe that Brandon and his legendary father Bruce Lee were cursed). It's too bad, because this is an exceptional movie.Lee plays Eric Draven, a musician who is murdered on Devil's Night. His fiancée is raped and beaten before she dies in the hospital. It seems that his fiancée was trying to stop the violence in her neighborhood created by Top Dollar (Michael Wincott)and his gang. However, just because you're dead doesn't mean things are settled. A year later, Eric climbs out of his grave, seeking revenge on the guys that put him and his fiancée six feet under. All of this has to do with the myth of the crow, which carries the link between the land of the living and the dead.Eric has an advantage over the guys that he is about to kill: Nothing can kill him and nothing can harm him (When he gets shot, the bullet-holes close right up, as if they never happened). With the help of Sgt. Albrecht (Ernie Hudson), Eric goes to work.Things don't turn out completely cut and dry, especially when Top Dollar and his half-sister Myca (Bai Ling)cause a few roadblocks on the road to vengeance.Alex Proyas (Who would later direct "Dark City" and "I, Robot") created a film that is kinetic and energetic (With a soundtrack of songs from Nine Inch Nails and Stone Temple Pilots among others). A film that is fast paced, yet emotional at the same time. A fitting tribute to Lee, whose performance will be remembered for a long time.

Review title: The Crow — Revenge from beyond the grave on a human level and emotional
Review_body: The Crow is by now a cult movie. Although it's getting a bit old for some of its special effects, it's still excellent.The soundtrack, especially the music, is exceptional. It's edgy, dark, and the emotions it stirs get you in the guts. It's a mirror image of the story. The revenge theme, certainly isn't new, not even one from beyond the grave, but the angle chosen here, is quite different. It's touching.You get a great mix of action, emotional drama, ghostly romance, and human relations, often dark and twisted, other times simple or basic. The sets are very dark and strongly Gothic. The acting is not perfect, but still strong and just.There are a few mistakes, not big, but at times noticeable, like some bad sound pickups. However, they seem to make the film into some sort of archaic rendition, which really works to its advantage.I recommend it if you don't mind its age.

Review title: The Crow is a brilliant movie
Review_body: A story of love, murder and revenge all done in a beautifully creative way, the camera style used was stylish especially for the Crow POV scenes, the edited colouring used for the flashbacks was good and added some depth into them. The acting from everyone was great, Brandon Lee's role as The Crow was fantastic he really did a great performance since he showed the characters rage and sorrow for what happened. The plot sees a young couple murdered by a gang on a night called Devil's Night, one year later and a Crow flies down by the grave of Eric Draven who was murdered by them, he rises from his grave and follows the Crow to his old apartment where he then remembers what happened and soon puts on the make up, dresses in a black outfit and goes out to kill the people who murdered him and his girlfriend, a girl named Sarah who was friends with Eric and his girlfriend and a cop that was at the crime scene soon discover that it is Eric and soon he meets up with both of them, the gang soon come up with a plan to stop Eric since if the Crow is killed then Eric will lose his power and they can kill him but Eric will stop at nothing to kill them. The Crow is a classic movie that should be seen. 10/10

Review title: The best of the them all
Review_body: The Crow has reached an iconic high in the movie realm, mostly because it was the last movie that Brandon Lee stared him, as he Brandon died on set during the production of the film; his death was due to a gunshot. The gun was supposed to be loaded with blanks, but one life ammunition bullet was lodged in the gun that was then loaded with blanks. His death on set made the movie gross more than the producers could ever imagine and turned this movie to a cult classic.The movie is an adaptation of a comic book series of the same name, that was created by James O'Barr and it tells the tale of the life of Eric (Brandon Lee). Eric and his fiancée were attacked at their home, Eric got shot and he was paralyzed, and could only watch as Shelly his fiancée is savagely beaten and raped. The attackers finally kill Eric.But a year later Eric is resurrected by a crow, now he hunts the men that killed him and his fiancée, Eric is now an undead, unable to be killed or hurt (as long as he stays on course, which is revenge on those who killed him and his fiancée).The movie boasts of fast paced action, the movie adaption of the comic is seen by many to be near accurate. The movie's cinematography is engaging as we mostly are moving around with Eric in the night, the camera angles or light feed never make you wish that there were gotten from another shot or you needing more light. Then there is the score, the dark rocky score that brings you into the melancholy mood of Eric as you watch, the movie doesn't at any time take you to a high of good things happening then brings you back to the main dark theme Alex Proyas (the director, and also director of Dark City (1998) and I, Robot) made sure that from the get go of this movie you are introduced to a sad theme, a sad scene, a sad story and it the movie keeps to that till the end.The Crow goes places other hero movies don't want to go, no breather just darkness.The movies special effects were most rewarding and the story is very engaging a fit none of the other sequels after it has been able to accomplish, as more sequels were being released the worse the ratings they were getting, making this movie stand out the more.A remake of this said "untouchable classic" is being done, the argument is will this remake be as good as the original or is it just going to follow the way all the other sequels went. My take on this is, Hollywood filmmakers are now at the end of their rope, going back to remake movies or dragging them into trilogies just to make more money, the remake falls into this suit if you ask me (suit of not having an idea of what movie to do), because such movies like this should never be remade. That said, I will be watching the remake with high hopes, reason being times have changed, 1994 and now that is more than 18 years, enough technological advancement that could not be employed in 1994 will be used in this remake, I just hope it won't suck.www.lagsreviews.com

Why oh why did I put off watching this film for years and years, I have been missing out. I did the same thing with the Usual uspects and that turned out to be one of the best films I have seen. The Crow was dark, atmospheric and stylish. It was a real comic to film classic and perhaps dare I say it the best. Brandon Lee was outstanding in this, his presence on screen was amazing. I had only previously seen him in Showdown in little tokyo and Rapid fire and while he could obviously fight and do much of his stunt work, I was not overly impressed with his acting. In the Crow he gives his last and best perfromance in his best film and its a shame his blossoming career was tragically cut short I feel he could be one of the main action stars out here today. I liked the Crow immensly, I admitadly didn't think I would but this, like the Terminator is a true classic B-Movie which has become a cult classic and spawned inferior sequals and a sub-standard TV series that wasted the talents of Mark Dacascos. Anyway the Crow gets a major thumbs up. 9/10

Pulp Fiction? Forrest Gump? Nah, this is what should have won the Best Film Oscar in 94. The best comic book film ever made, surpassing even Batman and Superman, The Crow is one film that will remain eternal, and never age over the years. Its story may be simple, but it is executed with such style and heart that it will never become unfashionable, and although the sequels have so far been poor, this is unmissable. Action, humour, love, and a visual flare that only Burton can match, The Crow, as Brandon Lee's last film has a massive cult following and was hailed by many critics.Eric Draven, a rock musician and his girlfriend Shelley are brutally killed on Halloween by the members of a local gang. The case is never solved, but cop Albrecht stayed with Shelley in the hospital for the many hours before she died. He has gone on with his job in the stinking city, occasionally meeting with Sarah, a young girl who was friends with Eric and Shelley, whose mother is a waster and addict. One year later, Draven returns from the grave, terrified and tortured until he remembers what has happened. A Crow seems to look after him and he is invincible. He soon sets out for revenge, picking off the gang members one by one, on his way to Top Dollar, the leader. Although he tries to hide, he eventually shows himself to Sarah and Albrecht, and they work together. Soon Draven and Top Dollar square off, but The Crow has been injured, and Draven's power has gone.Never before has such a beautiful film been made. Only Scissorhands can equal this, but even it has a different style. The sweeping views of the city, a terrible place to be, are stunning, with camera angles the Matrix would emulate. The soundtrack adds immensely, both the rock songs, and the instrumental tracks, making the film all the more powerful. The acting is all immense, though understated and quiet for the most part. Lee gives his best performance and it is a remarkable one, going through the emotions of the character, as well as doing the stunts. Of course, this would cost him his life, tragically echoing the story. In fact, the story seems to have been cursed from the start, with creator O'Barr basing the story and character on the real events of his life-his girlfriend being killed and the emotions he went through. Davis as Sarah gives a strong performance too, and could have had the world at her feet, but vowed never to return to the set and has not acted since Lee's death. Hudson gives a career best, and Wincott gives his usual snarling effort, here it is superb and has not been bettered. All the other cast members are great too, the gang members each well drawn and acted to perfection.The story is told with such skill that you can't help to feel such sympathy for the characters, and Sarah's monologues are very emphatic. Draven is a strong character, getting a second chance to do things right, and saying that yes- scumbags who kill do deserve to die also. These bad guys have no redeeming qualities, and their deaths are satisfying. The script is also awesome, and their are many one-liners, and these are not stupid either, but have meaning. If their were only a handful of films from this decade which survived a war, or which could be used to show humanity, this would be one of them. Easily one of the best movies of the decade which should continue to be seen by all.10 out of 10

The crow has its slot in pop culture history for many a reason and is known by all in passing at least. Released at a time in the early onslaught of comic book films it arguably slightly suffers from the fact that it's fairly similar, visually at least to others such as the batman films released at the same time, however, it's more bold and brave with what it chooses to show, Lee delivers an exceptional performance and the slow, methodical pursuit his character, Eric ensues upon to avenge himself and his wife is enthralling to watch and feels pressured with the compressed time limit of one night ensuring a thrill ride of high octane action. Genuinely a fantastic film that should be more appreciated for its quality opposed to solely on set affairs its one in half I finally managed to see

Review title: A little overrated but overall very good.
Review_body: I don't know why it took me so long to get around to watching this movie.  A gloomy, atmospheric cult hit, this is one to watch at night so as not to ruin the effects.  It was quite good, but overall, I liked "Dark City", by the same director, a lot better.Eh, what do I know?  I'm as Goth as a chickadee.

"The Crow" is a 1994 comic book drama directed by Alex Proyas starring Brandon Lee and Ernie Hudson. This is honestly one of those few movies that personally mean so much to me. Over the years, I've always been rewatching it every Devil's Night - it became sort of a tradition to honour this absolute masterpiece. It's the movie where the lines between fiction and reality overlap in such a devastating way. To this day, the people talk about the tragic incident that cost uprising actor Brandon Lee his life. You can literally feel the pain of this loss in the whole production. It's dark, depressing and devastating throughout, not only by the heartbreaking premise, also by what happened on set. Some characters and dialogue might be a little cheesy compared to modern standards, but that's what gives this movie it's weird charme. It assembles a pretty decent cast and they're all delivering great performances. The atmosphere is packing from start to finish and perfectly captured by the phenomenal cinematography. The third act especially gets me every time, it's just beautifully tragic and gives me goosebumps, because it's so heartbreaking. All in all, this film is an outstanding comic book adaption, both stylish and original, creating a tragic drama that will haunt you for a long time, by both it's dark and depressing themes and real life tragedy aspect. As always, rest in peace, Brandon Lee. You're gone too soon.

Review title: An Excellent,Stylish And Haunting Comic Book Adaptation And A Classic With A Brilliant,Unforgettable Final Performance From Brandon Lee(RIP).
Review_body: The Crow is an excellent,stylish and haunting classic and one of the greatest Comic Book films ever made that's filled amazing direction,a brilliant,unforgettable final performance from Brandon Lee,a great cast,thrilling Action,beautiful photography,a terrific score and Rock soundtrack. All of those elements make The Crow a Cult Classic and a powerful movie experience.Based on James O'Barr Comic Book Series and Comic Strip and set in Detroit,Michigan,The Crow tells the story of Eric Draven(Brandon Lee),a rock musician who along with his fiancée Shelly(Sofia Shinas)were assaulted and murdered by a group of thugs on Devil's Night,the night before Halloween. A year later after the murder,Eric is brought back from the grave to get revenge on the killers who murdered him and his fiancée and wants vengeance at all costs.Released in 1994,The Crow is brilliant and powerful film that came out a year after the tragic death of Brandon Lee(the son of the late,great legendary Martial Arts/Kung-Fu Icon Bruce Lee)who died on the set after an unfortunate accident while making the film. Although Brandon Lee's death loomed over the movie,The Crow became a critical and box office success and also became a Cult Film thanks to Brandon Lee's final performance and is seen as one of the best Comic Book films ever made. The Crow is an amazing film that right from the beginning pulls into a dark,Gothic nightmare that is grim and gloomy and looks like a Graphic novel coming to life with beauty and ugliness but is also a movie that is Action-packed and visually stunning and when you see The Crow the first time it will blow your mind. The Crow is a film that deals with themes such as tragedy,death,revenge and love which gives the movie a sadness that surrounds the film's atmosphere as well as the characters which gives The Crow depth and substance. Another thing I love about The Crow is the style and look of the movie thanks to the beautiful camera work and lighting by Dariusz Wolski. Wolski's photography and lighting gives The Crow a great and unique look that is in the style of Film Noir and Dystopian with rainy streets and buildings that are in the dark with the movie almost giving the film a timeless quality that combines the look of Tim Burton's Batman and Ridley Scott's Blade Runner because with The Crow you as a viewer don't know if it's the past,present or future. The Crow is also in the style of Film Noir with the characters attitudes which are cynical and bleak with no happy ending satisfaction. The main character Eric Draven is one of the best characters in a comic book film because even though Draven is back from the dead and looking for revenge he has depth and sympathy while having good(Draven's time with Shelly)and bad memories(him and Shelly's murder)which gives Draven and the film great power because what The Crow tells viewers even when you're dead a person still has a memory. Eric Draven is a character who represents the dark and gloomy tone and when he is off the screen you can feel Draven's presence because he represents violence,death and darkness. Eric Draven is a incredible character that you will never forget and is a character that will forever be a Cult icon and a classic anti hero that is timeless and for the ages. The Action scenes in The Crow are fantastic and done with a great pace and style which is fierce and at times brutal but if you are an Action movie lover the Action will have you foaming at the mouth and will keep glued to the screen with Action scenes of intensity,great excitement and explosive thrills. The ending of The Crow is amazing, beautiful and bittersweet because with the ending you will feel happy and sad for Eric Draven. A great conclusion.The whole cast is terrific. Brandon Lee is excellent and unforgettable as Eric Draven,with Lee bringing depth,sadness and charisma to the performance. R.I.P Brandon Lee,you and your acting talent were gone too soon. Rochelle Davis is wonderful as Sarah,Eric's friend. Ernie Hudsen is terrific as Sergeant Albrecht,a cop that helps Eric. Michael Wincott is amazing as Top Dollar,a local crime boss. Anna Thomson is fantastic as Darla,Sarah's drug addicted Mother. David Patrick Kelly(T-Bird),Angel David(Skank),Laurence Mason(Tin Tin)and Michael Masse(Funboy)do great jobs as Top Dollar's henchmen. Jon Polito is outstanding and funny as Gideon,a pawn shop owner. Sofia Shinas is beautiful and memorable as Shelly,Eric's fiancé. Tony Todd(Grange),Bai Ling(Myca) and Marco Rodriguez(Torres)give good performances as well. The direction by Alex Ployas is brilliant and stylish,with Ployas always moving the camera giving the film a dark and grim visual style to the film. Amazing direction,Ployas.The score by Graeme Revell is terrific,haunting and unforgettable and adds to the tone of the film. Great score,Revell. There is also an amazing soundtrack with songs by Nine Inch Nails(Dead Souls),Stone Temple Pilots(Big Empty),The Cure(Burn),Pantera(The Badge),Rage Against The Machine(Darkness),Rollins Band(Ghostrider),Medicine(Time Baby III)and more. Fantastic soundtrack.In final word,if you love Action Films or Comic Book Movies,I highly suggest you see The Crow,an excellent,stylish Comic adaptation and classic that you can watch again and again and belongs in every movie lover's collection. Highly Recommended. 10/10.

Review title: One of the best comic book films ever!!!
Review_body: Even though I liked comic books when I was younger I wouldn't say I was deeply a fan. I was into the more popular, mainstream comics. I had never heard of The Crow comic when the film was released. Of course there was some controversy regarding the untimely death of the film's star Brandon Lee in an on set accident with a gun. I went into the film not expecting much. I was blown away by what I saw!!! To this day I believe it is one of the best films of it's kind ever.The story is basically a revenge story. A young guy named Eric Draven and his fiance are murdered by some thugs in their own apartment. Eric is brought back from the dead by a crow to avenge what was done to him and his fiance. It is a very basic revenge plot. He comes back fro. The dead and adopts the persona of the crow. The scene where he paints his face and dresses as the character is really great. The look of the film is up until that time the best representation of a comic on screen IMO. The look of the film is very dark and gothic. It fits the comic book vision perfectly. The soundtrack that is dominated by alternative rock is great. I bought the soundtrack and still listen to this day. Brandon Led is great as Eric. The performance is very sad and full of rage. Obviously, the fact that he died in the making of the film his performance has more weight. I think he would have had a really good career. The director was a veteran music video director and it shows. He blends the music and the rapid fire editing is done very well though the film is not confusing. The main villain is Top Dollar played by Michael Wincott in a very good but somewhat funny performance. Ernie Hudson plays a cop that had gone to the hospital to see Eric's fiance before she died and he befriends Eric. Understanding that he us out for revenge. There is also a girl named Sara that was very close to both Eric and his fiance that figures out that he is back. All of the action is very well done, the film is very fast paced but never tiresome. This mix of action and melancholy makes The Crow a great comic book film that has grown its reputation since it came out in 1994.Grade: A-

After Eric Draven(Brandon Lee) and his girlfriend Shelly(Sofia Shinas) are brutally attacked and murdered, Eric comes back from the dead a year later along with a black crow to seek revenge on those who have destroyed his love. This movie wasn't as good as I expected it to be. Sure, it was very dark and gothic just the way that I like it but I think there was a lack of character development. We never really find out what the secret is behind each character and why exactly they do the things they do and also the story was fairly predictable. And there also was too much action and fighting which isn't really my style. However, it had a few beautiful moments and lines that made me like and appreciate the movie for what it is."Buildings Burn and People Die But Real Love Is Forever". I would give The Crow 6.5/10

In "The Crow," Eric Draven (Brandon Lee) comes back from the dead as a Marilyn Manson-wannabe and exacts a brutal revenge against several criminals for killing him and his girlfriend. The plot is as simple as that, but the movie plays well because Brandon Lee's portrayal of Draven as a man consumed with insanity and rage is highly original. The movie works best with those scenes where Brandon Lee is just talking to the criminals before beating them to a pulp or killing them in highly gratuitous ways that impress even the head villain. Yet this film is also less entertaining when the movie shifts away from Lee's intense lines of dialogue to the card board villains (which are as two dimensional as any of the villains in the Karate kid movies or most of the Steven Seagal films), the cops that play the role of incompetent spectators (much like they did in the first Die Hard film), and the action sequences which for the most part come straight off the assembly line of most Hollywood action pictures. "The Crow" is not a bad film, but it comes across only as a competently made picture that depends almost entirely on Brandon Lee's bravura performance.

Brandon Lee's epic performance is left behind in this legendary movie in which he will forever be remembered as the very first "Crow." Eric Draven (Brandon Lee) and his fiancée Shelly Webster (Sofia Shinas) are killed just before they are set to be married. A year later, while visiting their graves, Sarah (Rochelle Davis) notices a crow atop of Eric's gravestone ("who are you, the night watchman?"). When Sarah leaves, the crow somehow resurrects Eric back to life. When he revisits his old place, he find himself to be invincible and paints himself. He goes on a mission to get revenge on the people who stole his life away.The plot of the movie is inspiring even though it's about revenge and murder. It makes a new hero, who is immortal, unless his crow is killed or damaged. The villains are played well and the characters are easy to hate, but you love to hate them. There is cool visual effects and memorable quotes that you'll probably be quoting for dozens of years after viewing the film.The cinematography is dark and with the constant rain you really get a feel of how the characters feel. The heroes Eric and Sarah are developed well and the friendship between Eric and Albrecht (Ernie Hudson) is wonderful due to the good chemistry. The only shame of this film is the real life death of Brandon Lee which caused him to be replaced in the sequel by a different actor and character.It's been 14 years since the movie was released, but I still love it like it was released yesterday. "Can't rain all the time."

Review title: Alex Proyas Brings Horror and Drama together..
Review_body: Although, The Crow may not be one of those must-see titles out there, and maybe it's a little too old, but this is a movie you just have to go and see. That is of course, if you like the idea of a man shooting criminals for being involved with murdering and raping his girlfriend. I'm not going to write a very lengthy review, but I'm just going to say this.. this movie's exciting.At first, it may seem that this movie just features a man smiling killing people and laughing every time he gets a wound and it heals, but this movie packs in a lot of humor, action, gore, and more. It doesn't feature any plot twists. In fact, the whole movie is about the man taking his revenge on others, but that's alright with me.Overall, I recommend you to buy this movie. No, not rent. Buy.

Brandon Lee stars as Eric Draven a murdered rock musician who returns from the grave to settle the score between the killers who killed him and his girlfriend Shelly (Sofia Shinas) Downbeat and tragic, The Crow while not the classic people say, is still a damn good movie. The Crow's actionscenes are very exciting and the movie is well-acted (Especially from David Patrick Kelly and Michael Wincott) making The Crow well worth a look. Brandon Lee gives the best performance of his (short-lived) career and performs stunts with effortless agility, Lee (who died because of a prop accident on the set of The Crow) definitely had a career ahead of him.

I've watched a lot of movies that are about revenge, and most of them are just action movies that don't really capture the darkness of revenge and the human soul in those kind of movies. The Crow is one of the very few revenge themed movies that is as dark as needed, and it doesn't exactly make revenge seem more glorious than it is. The Crow is brutal and violent, but there are also some really beautiful, comforting parts, which make the film stand out from the typical films of the genre.The cinematography is amazing, it's like a beautiful comic book. There's a lot of contrast, loads of black, but still surprisingly much colour. The palette is breathtaking. The cinematography is gruesomely beautiful, considering what they show and what they don't show, and how it's shown.The soundtrack is great, but a bit surprising here and there. Then again, of course such a goth classic would use The Cure in the soundtrack.The Crow is an enchanting, beautiful yet brutal movie, and it's definitely worth watching. Even if you don't care about the genre or a story, what happened to Brandon Lee should be enough to pique your interest.

When first released in 1994, The Crow came with a lot of baggage attached. Star Brandon Lee, son of martial arts legend Bruce Lee, had died during the production of the film due to a mishap with a prop firearm. The producers and director Alex Proyas, who had largely finished the film, elected to reshoot a small amount and utilize emerging digital technology to composite Brandon Lee into a select number of scenes as well as using a body double in some cases. When it hit screens in May, critical reception was largely warm. From then until now, I have stood as one of the seemingly small cadre of individuals who found The Crow, Brandon Lee's tragic passing notwithstanding, to be considerably overrated, full of style, but largely hollow at the core.For the most part, The Crow is a revenge film dressed up with mystical elements. One year after Eric Draven (Lee) and fiancé Shelly (Sofia Shinas) were killed in a violent home invasion, Draven is resurrected from his grave by the presence of a crow, which has seemingly returned his soul to him to avenge his and Shelly's murder. Draven runs into former friends along the way, including largely ignored young girl Sarah (Rochelle Davis) and police officer Albrecht (Ernie Hudson), whom he occasionally ponders life and death with. Draven's targets are a small group of criminals, led by T-Bird (David Patrick Kelley), who works for Top Dollar (Michael Wincott), the crime boss of Detroit. Draven begins working through T-Bird's crew to reach Top Dollar, but Dollar's girlfriend, Myca (Bai Ling), realizes the source of Draven's power is the crow, and Top Dollar plots to take Draven down.The Crow's key weakness is the shallowness of the characters. While it is hard to know whether some aspects of the film were affected by Lee's death and subsequent re-editing, but both Eric and Shelly are largely ciphers, revealed to us only via very limited flashbacks, but not given much depth or development. We are supposed to feel for them because the screenplay requires it, not because of any genuine interest in them. Without this identification with the victims, it is almost impossible to be involved in the film on a visceral level. There are moments when their plight is moving, but those are few and far between. The rest of the time, The Crow is not really anything special. Draven, seeking retribution for his death and loss, mows down each one of T-Bird's henchmen, using their particular vices or skills to make for stylish deaths (One is impaled on a half-dozen knives, another overdosed on a plethora of hypodermic needles filled with drugs). Some of the action sequences are well staged, but rarely are they exciting or involving.The film's villains are also a bit underwhelming. Wincott, as Top Dollar, has a terrific raspy voice that gives Top Dollar a degree of menace, but still comes up wanting as a memorable screen heavy. T-Bird and his co-horts are barely on screen enough to register, and since they are largely drug addicts, some of them flail about wildly and are almost caricatures, not characters. The film does provide some interesting moments as Eric reconnects with friends from a prior life, but those are just glimpses of a film that is more interested in sweeping camera shots and violent death scenes.The Crow is also not exactly an upbeat film. It was based on a comic series by author James O'Barr who tragically lost his family, and The Crow was an attempt by him to provide some catharsis to those events. The Crow mediates on life and death at times, but the oppressiveness of the narrative occasionally threatens to swallow it. I am hardly one to shy away from films with downbeat material, to be sure, but without the character foundation to provide support, the darkness of The Crow sometimes seems a bit much.Many gave Brandon Lee positive notices for his last performance in this film, and he is fairly accomplished in the role. While he isn't given a lot to work with, what moments of pathos The Crow offers are in many cases due to Lee's work. It was a shame and tragedy that he died so young, on the cusp of attaining stardom. The Crow was also the film that brought director Alex Proyas to the attention of American audiences, lensing the film in largely dark and dank environments, crafting an decaying urban environment that fits the narrative. Not many years after Batman, The Crow certainly appears to offer some degree of homage to the design of Tim Burton's breakthrough success. The Crow is a very stylish affair, but good looks without a strong narrative are nothing but pretty pictures.The Crow is not a meritless film, and some moments work, but for the most part it smacks of a film that attracted a great deal of attention due to the controversy surrounding it than for its substance. The Crow would go on to be followed by one theatrical sequel, The Crow: City of Angels, which would prove abysmal, and then two other, direct to video sequels that few people probably realize ever existed. The original film is the crown jewel in that franchise, but the praise is misplaced from my point of view, affection for a film that didn't really deserve it, while its lead actor actually did. The Crow is an unfortunate end to a career, and life, cut far too short.

'The Crow' - the final movie of Brandon Lee and his finest hour, and one of the best movies ever. Brandon starred as Eric Draven, a musician living with his fiancée, Shelley. Life for them was perfect, but on Devil's Night, everything changed. Eric was murdered, but Shelley was beaten and raped, and the last thirty hours of her life were filled with nothing but pain. Exactly one year later, Eric is brought back to seek out and gain his revenge on those responsible.The story is great, despite simplicity. The atmosphere is very dark and sad, yet also hopeful, bringing a message of eternal love. Brandon finally got to showcase his skill as an actor, as well as a martial artist, and he was brilliant as both. Despite numerous one-liners, the violent tone, and some great action scenes, Brandon was able to prove he was also a great actor.I could talk at length about how great this movie, and how much I enjoy it, but I won't. I will just re-iterate that it is an excellent movie, and urge you to see it. 'The Crow' definitely deserves a 10/10. Be warned, it is obviously not for everyone - it is the kind of movie that would scare children, and get disapproving comments from others unable to stomach the violence and drug use.

The Crow is the perfect film, it is up there with Donny Darko and the original, The Night Of The Hunter. The film style is beautiful with a strange elegance even when it is showing the grimy rundown parts of the city.
Brandon Lee was brilliant in the part of Eric Draven, the rock musician who was brutally murdered by thugs and brought back from the grave to avenge the rape and murder of his fiancee, Shelly Webster (Sofia Shinas.)
The Crow was also the last movie that Brandon Lee would make as he died during the filming through a tragic mishap with a gun. In fact, the movie was almost not completed. Alex Proyas did manage to bring James O'Barr's graphic novel to the screen.
The film has an almost fairy tale feel to it even though it's described as a superhero movie. Brandon Lee is at times ethereal, then terrifying as he takes revenge one by one on the men who murdered him and his beloved fiancee. The gravelly voiced Michael Wincott as Top Dollar, the head honcho was excellent, as was the rest of the cast. The music was beautiful and the visuals were stunning. The Crow is now one of the best known cult films and has even spawned several sequels and a tv series.
The emotional depth and strength in storytelling makes this a movie that once seen, will not be quickly forgotten.

The only bad part about this film is the ill fate suffered by Brandon Lee. But such is life! Anyway, as Dark Action-Fantasies go, The Crow is one of the best ever made. Considering that almost no one in this film is a major star, the acting is above average. The story line/script is coherent and logical, keeping a good pace throughout. And the action scenes, while not unique, are riveting. So if you like films that fit this genre, I highly recommend you see The Crow. It's far better than any Batman film ever made. That's for sure!

The gothic superhero, The Crow. Definitely worthy of its time and very worthy of a cult gathering. I suppose it became a cult classic immediately with the tragic death of Brandon Lee. You can tell Brandon was committed to the role and gave it his all, leaving a lasting legacy to 'The Crow' similar to Heath Ledger and the 'Joker'. Though to be fair, the acting when comparing those two roles is not even close.The story itself is just as tragic, as it is surrounded with loss and grief. A fairly run of the mill revenge story that involves picking off those responsible one by one. The action is decent enough. It's dark throughout and has that intense goth feel. Film noir of comic book heroes one could say.The overall film is slightly dated and could be due for a reboot in the coming years, but of course this would be of no disrespect to Brandon Lee's legacy. It would just be nice to see what they could do with some modern technology.

Review title: The best B movie ever made.
Review_body: There are movies you watch for their deep, spiritual messages, and there are movies you watch for the sheer, unholy, Christ-crushing badassery they contain. If you were to guess that this movie is of the latter persuasion, you'd be correct, and what a glorious, wonderful sight this was to behold.The Crow is the B movie to end all B movies. Let's not kid ourselves; that is what it is, and it doesn't pretend to be anything else. It's an old school, Halloweenish (the holiday, not the John Carpenter film) revenge flick with broad, straightforward, gleefully Satanic undertones and imagery - pentagrams, black coats, fire, the whole deal. It's not even exceptionally dark, either; these themes are all carried out with an exuberant sort of merriment, as if the film thrives on the dark itself. And I don't know about you, but I love stuff like this, so revisiting The Crow was a huge treat for me. The imagery I mentioned before is not really Satanic, being a mere stereotype and cliché, but it's fun, the film equivalent of running around outside on Halloween night with masks and fake weapons and the whole deal. It's a childlike fascination, and combined with the succinct, tightly woven little storyline, The Crow becomes much greater in the eyes of many like myself. There isn't anything too deep here, but there doesn't need to be. The acting is pretty subpar overall, although nobody can deny Brandon Lee's status as a Certified Badass. The whole thing has that 90s sort of grainy, underground feel to it, quality-wise, and it fits the storyline to a tee.If you only like polished Hollywood films or the "classics" of the olden days, then you won't understand my reverence for this film at all, for it isn't something everyone will agree with or even "get." This is just a damned cool movie, and all of its overblown cheese does nothing but lift it up to higher levels. This isn't a subtle or deep movie; it lays out everything right in front of you with gruesome, dark images and total sincerity, much better than the forced crap we get nowadays. The Crow is an honest, sincere little film, and I respect it for that.I don't hate anything about this movie at all, and I would say it is the best B movie ever, however bold that statement may be. The Crow is a huge, metallic spiked behemoth of a film, and it will roll over your ass like an angry battle tank. Superlative.

Review title: So gorgeous. So spiritual... I Cry.
Review_body: When Eric resurrects from the dead the entire mood of the scene is angelic and just powerful... I could shed tears from just some of the dialogue throughout...The Crow had people confiding in him! With that being said, Brandon Lee's spirit is all over this film!

Revenge is sweet, especially if you have already been dead for a year. Alex Proyas has made some amazing dark films, and The Crow is no exception. The eponymous bird acts like the narrator in Greek tragedy, guiding the un-dead main character face to face with those who brutally murdered him and his wife in a dark and forlorn city full of Gothic churches, dark streets, car-swallowing rivers...The film is hyper-violent, and so it is not for everyone. Even more disconcerting is the fact that Brandon Lee (son of Bruce Lee, famous for martial arts) was accidentally shot to death during his protagonist's death scene. A mix up with an uncharged bullet getting stuck and a live blank without a bullet being fired subsequently cost him his life, with the .44 Magnum seen in the film. I was in Wilmington NC a couple of years ago, and learned that the scene was filmed there. It sent a shiver down my spine, although Wilmington is a nice little town.The Crow is a tragedy in the Greek sense for many of its themes: the love for your soul mate, the inevitable justice of revenge, the drama of the high falling. I was wavering between a 7 and 8, but in the end, the vision of this film rises to the quality of one of a film that defines or re-defines its genre.

The Crow(1994) Review: I remember seeing this in theaters. I was amazed then and still amazed now. This movie does not get old. It is tragic about Brandon Lee. He will be missed.The Crow is a great movie. We start in a truly dark and decadent city on Devil's night, the night before Halloween. The city is filled with crime and run by a powerful syndicate lead by Top Dollar. Four members of the syndicate have a night on the town and murder two innocent people. However, the death was so tragic that a crow brings back one of the victims in Eric Draven to get vengeance for him and his fiancé. Anyone who gets in his way will certainly regret it.This movie works in many ways. One is the scene when Eric comes back from the dead. This scene was so very well done. He rises and opens the casket and then has trouble with his balance and is trembling, scared, and confused. Brandon Lee is great as Eric Draven. He has the look and charisma. For what it's worth, he seemed to enjoy this role.More goods is the acting on just anyone here. The one that steals the show is Micheal Wincott in a memorable and awesome role as Top Dollar. The Directing from Alex Proyas is great too. Ernie Hudson despite being type-cast as a cop is here and plays the role nicely. This movie also has a decent and fitting soundtrack.The Last Word: Excellent. It is tragic of Lee's death. However, his final movie is his best one. This is the Crow. Highly recommended.

I love this movie. I'm going to buy my own DVD of it. The acting is phenomenal, especially by Brandon Lee.This movie is about the tragic death of two young people, Eric Draven and Shelly Webster, a couple who was going to be married on Halloween. Instead, they are sadly killed by a bunch of thugs and sociopaths who were being evicted from their apartment. A year later, through a hypnotic crow Eric comes back to life to make them pay and answer for their crimes.Kudos to the cast, crew, and filmmakers. Two Thumbs Way Up! 10 out of 10 stars.

Review title: Whoever you are, watch it again
Review_body:
<The Crow> is one of my favourite films of all time. It is a perfect example of how emotion and character development can overcome all other things that may be lacking in a film. I feel the acting is perfect. Anyone who doesn't feel for Erik(and yes, Brandon's presence, fortunately or unfortunately makes that feeling for us moviegoers stronger) must have a heart made of lead.   WHAT I LOVE MOST OF ALL ABOUT THE CROW (besides Brandon Lee) is the fact that people can't judge what this movie is by its "cover". Who would've thought from watching the previews and hearing the plot, that this movie will make you fall in love with the concept of "love" and "soulmates" and the phrase "buildings may burn, people die, but real love is forever."
   This film was strong enough to create a whole underground neo-goth scene. I remember because I was 13, and no way did those black nail polish-wearing, black-haired, teardrop-tattooed, leather-pants-wearing guys come around until after that movie. At least in the Sates. I can swear by that statement.
   Those reading this have probably either not seen the film or have not seen it in a long time. To either scenario I'd like to say that you need to watch this film again. Hell, *I* need to watch it again. It will restore your faith in love. Seeing beautiful Shelly and Erik together, adorable, you'll want that soulmate of your own.Good luck and take care.
Sep

excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent,excellent............this film deserves many more "excellents" than this. <Excellent> is the term the Board of Teachers decide to grade kids before they reach 3rd grade. So , when I say "excellent", I mean "unabashed, blunt, yet innocent - magic."
In my opinion it's the greatest love story in a movie I've seen.One of my favorite movies of all time.The Crow.

I found this in my old stuff; a review from 5 years ago for this movie...though I already commented on The Crow; I feel this may be the most honest review for it:Once upon a time-not so long ago- Halloween was something more magical. Up until the early 90's kids were happy to be frightened because it was about being alive and honest, without the fear that evil truly did reign the Earth. It was optimism and how it related to human darkness.  Moreover it was about how "Goth" had come back in style, the education in literary background that came with it. There was a lot of culture behind black attire and make-up of this time- whether it was referenced to writers, music, religion, or just pure romantic love.That's where this film comes in. Its theme-"love conquers all"- is not about romance-but about true LOVE. This film is all about staying true to the essence of its theme. If you're talking about "love" during this time(1992-4), you're not talking about any "areas" around it- like romance, lover's quarrel, jealousy, self-doubt. It's not about enhancing the faces of your film's attractive leads; Brandon Lee's face is mostly covered in make-up and similarly Sofia Shinas is barely shown, but when she finally is it is only her face-she is more like an angel than an attractive woman. Point being that everything needed to make an action/horror film was there. But it's like the director wanted to show how he deliberately ignored these aspects and remained loyal to his theme.Sarah and Officer Albrecht are plot thickeners and serve to give the film a modern perspective, so they are shown as realistically as possible. But all the "bad"-guys are purposely unrealistic, they are shown as symbols for you to HATE-out of pure emotion. You don't want them in the slammer, you want their evil out of this world.This film is like a landmark in a temporary (American-I can't speak for other countries) pop culture between 1992&4. Kurt Cobain's suicide, Real World London, Live, Pearl Jam's zenith of pop influence, Nine Inch Nails, STP...this is the era when some young kids today (and older folks who passed by this era) complain we took ourselves too seriously. It was right before grunge supposedly"died" and before humour and obsolete issues came back into rap and rock; before new-wave "punk". Financial gain/monetary value was shunned during this short-lived culture, because it didn't have to do with human emotion. Incidentally the "bad guys" of this film aren't out for money, just for the glory of madness, anarchy, and hate.There is a line in The Crow where Eric tells Albrecht, upon fond reflection:"Little things used to mean so much to Shelly. I used to think they were kind of trivial. Believe me-nothing's trivial."
There was a little gap in pop culture history, reminding us how important love and classic literature was, and how youthful optimism and love could be combined with negative attitudes(like anger,sadness, and vengeance) to create a character everyone could identify with. This is the time when "nothing was trivial"-the "important" stuff mattered, a feeling to which music of the time consequently made a huge impact. Nothing was done without thought, so words could make you fall in love or cry.If there ever was a film that could reflect this confusing and beautiful revival of the Romantic Period, The Crow is the movie. It will take you back. This is the only film that I wish could've lasted longer.

The Crow (1994) D: Alex Proyas. Brandon Lee, Ernie Hudson, Michael Wincott, David Patrick Kelly, Angel David, Rochelle Davis, Ling Bai. Exceptional gothic thriller about a rock-and-roll musician who, along with his fiancee, is brutally murdered by gang members and then rises from the dead one year later for vengeance. Lee was accidentally killed on the set 52 days into the 58 day shoot; computer technology enabled them to complete the film, superimposing his face onto a body double. The film is loud and boisterous, but the acting (especially by Lee) is terrific and the cinematography conveys the dark, Gotham City-esque mood that works so well. RATING: 9 out of 10. Rated R for graphic violence, profanity, nudity, and sexual situations.
