Well it's not THAT bad, however I despise hype over a film that I didn't think was all that great to begin with. I think a lot of the silly IMDb hero-worship (you see written below) over this film was due to the fact that Brandon Lee died during the making of it, and that all the kiddies from all around the world wanted to emulate the Goth look with a little dose of Marilyn Manson on the side. Besides, I hate silly music videos and the angst metal crap on this thing, blew green snot.... In other words, it sucked... Still, some of the visual CGI cityscapes looked cool for it's time and the storyline didn't insult my intelligence any, so I'll be kind and give it an average rating.5 out of 10

Review title: Brandon Lee delivers his best performance ever.
Review_body: I had the opportunity to see "The Crow" at The AMC Hampsire Six Theatres in Hadley,Massachusetts.I found Brandon Lee's performance in the film different from his others."The Crow"is based on the best selling graphic comic that deals with the supernatural.Brandon is Eric Draven.A rock musician whom one night,along with his wife to be,is murdered by a group of vicious gang members who each Halloween celebrate Devil's Night in which they blow stuff up.A year later,Eric is brought to life with the help of a supernatural crow who throughout the film is Eric's guardian angel and his eyes.Eric is brought to life for one purpose only:Avenge his death and right what is wrong."The Crow" is one of the darkest films to come out since "Batman".The movie is Brandon Lee's best performance because I think the role he played really separated him from his earlier films.Don't get me wrong,I loved him in "Rapid Fire" and was hoping he would make some more martial arts films. I am not saying that this was Brandon Lee's best performance because it was his last. If that were the case,I wouldn't be reviewing this film."The Crow" deals with the supernatural and gives us a supernatural hero we can go for.What I liked about the film, is the fact that Eric doesn't want to be a hero.He is cursed and to remove that curse he must avenge himself and his girlfriend.The film is also about damnation which I consider really dark.After seeing "The Crow",I realized that on March 31,1993 we lost a really great actor."The Crow" is one hell of a film.

When people talk about how today Hollywood is finally getting comic book films right, they seem to forget this gem.The late 80's and early 90's saw the advent of Burton's "Batman" and Proyas' "The Crow". Both of these films share a lot in common. In the end, they showed fans that Hollywood could get a comic book right.....every now and then.Though drastically different from its source graphic novel in tone and story, the film manages to hold on to the "love is forever" theme of the O'Barr graphic novel.All the cast turn in great performances in spades. All the right elements clicked together from a great script written by David Schow and John Shirley, direction from Proyas, and musical direction by Graeme Revell and Jeff Most.It would be hard to mention this film without making a nod to the doomed lead actor, Brandon Lee. The film stands as a fitting tribute to where he was headed as an actor. He was not there yet by no means, but I think this film really set him apart from his famous father's shadow. As is, the film still plays well today. It was purposely not set in either a future or past world. It represents right now, no matter what year it plays. That is a mark of a very good film.

Review title: Graphic novelesque stylish flick that has stood the test of time
Review_body: Fantastic and fabulous film which has stood the test of time. Very dark and rainy throughout a la Tim Burton. Tragic loss of Brandon Lee during this beauty of a movie.

Review title: One of my all time favorite "dark movies"
Review_body: This is a serious guy movie. It is one of my top 10 all time movies.I anticipated this movie would be great after I watched Brandon Lees previous movie "Rapid Fire". It is set to happen all in 1 night, very few people appreciate the difficulty of shooting in near darkness. The acting and stunt-ing of Brand Lee is fantastic. The supporting cast was OK but they were not the focus point. This is one of those classic stories of hero seeking revenge. The Gothic setting for this is like Outlaw Josey Wales meets New York City at night.Like all real "Guy movies" they must meet 3 or criteria: 1. Action worth re-watching (fighting, shooting or blowing up) 2. A Hero you like (Strong silent like Eastwood, Badass like Bruce/Brandon Lee, or Tough Everyday guy like Bruce Willis) and a Villain you HATE 3. Story that ends in a "Hell Yeah" (Revenge is dish best served cold) + if there is a good soundtrack + if there is a hot chickThis movie enters in to immortality due to the fact that Brandon Lee son of a Legend Bruce Lee meet his demise in this movie.

A finely tuned revenge fantasy dripping in a moody and gothic atmosphere, The Crow is vivified by its grimly stylised art direction and witty comic banter. It feels so in tune with its graphic novel origins that the film itself plays a lot like a comic, structured around rigid story-telling, exceptionally action-packed choreography and a brooding metal soundtrack that drives home its themes of loss and hopeless injustice in a manner that is so artistically done.
Seen this about 20-30 times. Not just the movie that delves into the supernatural but the real tragedy surrounding it. RIP.

Review title: Gothic, emotional, well written and all around amazing.
Review_body: The plot might be your typical story about a man wanting to take his revenge on the people who wronged him, yet "The crow" not only manages to successfully put it's own unique spin on a tale as old as time, but also manages to get us invested in it even more with it's gothic atmosphere, kick-ass action sequences and the captivating performances given by the cast in order to bring these characters to life.

"The Crow" is absolutely one of the best comic book movies ever made. This is before we have other great comic book movies such as "Sin City," "The Avengers," or "The Dark Knight" Trilogy. "The Crow" is very much a revenge story of a man who lost the love of his life and now takes on a gang of thugs for all the things that took from him. Brandon Lee is the Crow and it is sad that he died during the making of this movie, and it would've been interesting to hear his thoughts on the movie if he was still alive today. He has given an amazing performance and this is the movie that he shall always be remembered. Ernie Hudson and the rest of the other cast did great for their performance. The cinematography by Dariusz Wolski is beautifully shot for its style of a comic book movie. Same goes to the production design of this movie, which it does look like a cross mixture between Tim Burton's "Batman" and Ridley Scott's "Blade Runner." I do enjoy Graeme Revell's score and the songs that were selected for the movie. Alex Proyas does a fantastic job for directing this movie as well as his other movie "Dark City." There is not a whole lot more to say except that "The Crow" is dark, edgy, and entertaining. I give this movie a 10 out of 10!

Review title: a little crap in a big toilet
Review_body: Well time to poo on another movie that deserves it, so time to take your rose tinted glasses off from someone who finally saw this movie almost 30 years after it's been made. Time flies. I think anything over a 3 star is insulting, yes the movie has a really dark atmosphere and it was unique back then as all there was at the time really was this and the Batman movies Tim Burton did. However on todays standards which let's face it most of it is just remakes and making women take over mens roles or make different ethnicities play roles because Hollywood is so brilliant and far from lazy this.This hands down has to be one of the most over rated films ever made that people talk about. I'm tempted to watch Citizen Kane and Casablanca how awful this was just to see what many consider the "Greatest" movies are.The story was about as deep as an adult movie, the director did an awful job, they just wanted to piece this together what they could and hit that hour and thirty minute mark because of course Brandon getting killed. This film shouldn't have came out in the state it's in. The production story for this movie is far more interesting than this movie. All the drugs and hurricane to name a few things it's amazing this even came out.Other than the cop who helps Eric and Keith David no one can really act in this movie. The worst is the little girl she's just as stiff as Shelly's corpse is in this movie. The scene where Eric screams as he comes out of his grave I laughed my head off. The little girl Sarah just murmurs through her lines like Summer Smith in Rick And Morty voiced by Spencer Grammar. It is on par with. Taissa Farmiga when she was in the first few seasons of American Horror Story as the girl who falls in love with Tate the Kurt Cobain looking kid in season 1. None of them can act their way out of wet paper bags.The only parts to the score I really liked were the more experimental stuff. The use of the tsiranapogh (duduk) was surprisingly fitting. It makes me want to listen to Tony Iommi of Black Sabbath record he did with Ian Gillian of Deep Purple the project was called "Who Cares". More thought went into that band name than the dialogue of this movie.How is that fluffy white cat still alive. Better yet how is it so white. I guess there is lots of rats to eat in that decrepit cityThe movie struggles to have a story, the script should have been worked on longer. I kind of wish they gave the crow a better outfit as it comes off as mish mashed together like when Tommy Wiseau did that scene on the rooftop where he had cargo pants, a muscle shirt and what looked like a blazer shouting I DID NOT HIT HER I DID NOT.. OH HI MARK. I kind of wish they were into bondage or something for something with more leather and spikes that looked more super hero than some poor kid who wants to go trick or treating because mommy is too drunk to bring him and his friends. This is coming from someone who despises all the over saturation of marvel and dc atrocities these days too. I don't get it why the girlfriend would want a white wedding dress, I mean aren't they "goth". I mean the woman is too pretty and skinny to be goth, doesn't look like she has drug or mental problems but to me anyways why would these two bother with tradition or so. Do they exchange gifts from hot topic on Halloween?The fights are poorly choreographed and or editedthe alternative rock in this movie is terrible as well. I bet you could find a better sound track in a dollar store.Why did Keith David sign up to be in this? Thankfully he still has a career which I don't think anyone else in this movie can say the same.Why is the engagement ring in some slimy pawn shop ran by a real life Carl Brutananadilewskii (Aqua Teen Hunger Force).The movie struggles to have meaningful dialogue between the characters, how is child service not called on Sarah too. What is she 12? She goes around on a long board in this dangerous city. Was that one of the buildings that burnt or blew up in what I imagine is Detroit. Any more fire and it might as well be Fallujah or. Kabul.What I hate about Eric is he's too confident to the point it's nauseating. He thinks everyone knows who he is as if he was the only one to get murdered in that slimy city. He comes off like some trashy social media influencer. Woah you don't know Chad he has like 10,000 followers on this site. You should totally give him the presidential suite of your 7 star hotel for free. He is so lame, so unlikable. I liked Brandon more in Showdown In Little Tokyo but this is just awful. I've said it in other reviews as I have a thing for watching so bad they are good movies but if Brandon's dad wasn't who he was there is no way he would have been cast for even a laundry detergent ad.The bad guy in this movie sucks, i can't take him seriously. He doesn't do enough to really be a bad guy and what happens to him is just lazy.Did I mention Eric sucks at guitar. I'd want to smash that guitar too or throw him out a 6 story building if I had him as a neighbor. Whatever the heck that noodling he played at first was made most 13 year olds in guitar center or other popular guitar shops look like guitar gods. They edited most of it out thankfully. I'd say he can't play guitar to save his life but it's a bit too late.This movie desperately needed a better director. The ONLY reason this movie is a classic is either Brandon's death which is why this movie is extremely over rated or possibly the dark atmosphere. Sort of like no one cared about Heath Ledger until he passed away after filming the Dark Knight if memory serves me right. If this movie came out and Brandon was still alive milking his fathers fame this would be in the same bargain bin as I Come In Peace (Dark Angel) with Dolph Lundgren.The final shootout and fight were just lazy, there are some faint bits of good cinematography but this movie is just awful. The only redeeming thing about this is the ending. But the damage is already done.This movie is horribly paced. There are parts you'll get bored.The special effects and the look of the movie and i feel if Brandon didn't wear all that clown makeup no one would remember this movie.Go ahead my mid life crisis friends and say this is unhelpful. This movie was borderline unwatchable. But at least the production team had fun partying and doing drugs the entire time.

**THIS REVIEW COULD CONTAIN A LOT OF SPOILERS. IF THE READER DOESN'T WANT THE POSSIBILITY OF THE MOVIE BEING SPOILED FOR THEM, THEN I RECOMMEND WATCHING THE MOVIE BEFORE READING THIS REVIEW. THANK YOU.**I down right loved this movie. It's just a shame that Brandon Lee had actually been shot while filming. Such a tragedy. This movie's story-line was deep. It had a Gothic-love type feel to it. Very awesome. The whole movie just gave me a deep feel of how important the people that you care about actually are in your life. When Eric's (Brandon Lee) love of his life is brutally raped and thrown out of a high story window, he is forced to watch. Then, they slowly kill him. It was on a criminal holiday known as Devil's Night. This little girl both Eric and his love (Shelly) were really close to, Sara, is now on her own to live on the street with a liquid morphine junkie of a mom.Later in the Movie Eric's soul is awakened, and carried, by a crow. He had unfinished business. The love he possessed was actually real. So the crow brought him back to get even for the torture of all three of them, that that group of people had done. He starts killing them off one-by-one; killing all who were responsible for the death of his lost love. I will not tell you any more of this movie, except that the fact that it is epic. The story-line was epic, the script was epic, the dialog was good, the actors did an excellent job of allowing viewers to connect to them, and the Gothic environment of the film. I gave this movie an "8". The only thing I thought they could've improved on was the ending. Otherwise it would've bee close to a "10". What can you expect though when a tragedy like Brandon Lee getting shot on the set occurs.

Review title: Remembered I haven't reviewed my favorite movie of all time
Review_body: This is without a doubt my favorite movie of all time. I saw it for the first time when I was about 12 in 1996 and really fell in love with the story, the atmosphere and the music. I cannot say anything negative about this. I'm just so sad that Brandon Lee didn't have a chance to become a star. Like River Phoenix, his life ended wayyy to soon. I'm glad though that this movie is his last one, he went out with a bang. (No pun intented.)

Film is an art form, and it's open to interpretation. An interpretation of The Crow that occurred to me after watching it the other night was that maybe the whole film was Sarah (the girl in the film)'s fantasy. It always struck me as kind of shallow to just look at this as a revenge film. Because, what makes Eric and Shelley such important victims? Are there no other good people in the entire city? The clear answer to that is that what makes them the most important is their connection to Sarah. They looked after her and were her friends while her mother was off doing drugs all the time. Then on "Devil's Night," they are brutally, unjustly, and senselessly murdered by some truly evil people. Sarah runs into a cop who does his best to comfort her. The world is an awful place.Then we get the title card indicating a year had passed. This is when I think the fantasy begins. Sarah continues to live in this city, and she has now befriended the cop she met a year earlier. A crow brings Eric back to life with divine powers, and guides him along a journey to bring justice to the world by killing his and Shelley's killers. Through the eyes of a young person this is as just as it gets. But it's more than just revenge. Eric gets Sarah's mom to quit drugs and start to be a mom again. Sarah is also able to say goodbye to Eric, a person who she must have loved a lot. Her fantasy also gives Eric and Shelley a chance to say goodbye to each other, to embrace one last time, bringing some closure to such unjust, terrible circumstances. The fantasy even hints that maybe the evil in the world will stop since the top villain of the city is taken down.This is just one interpretation, of course, and there's many ways to look at the movie, but I like to look at it this way. It makes it a bit more sad; a bit more beautiful, and also gives it a deeper meaning. If you listen to the final words of the movie, it does make sense. It's taken her a year, but Sarah did end up finding a way to cope with the deaths of her loved ones, and the evil in the world around her.As far as things like its visual style and acting goes, this is brilliant. I love its dark atmosphere. This is really the epitome of the early 90's. The generation X gloom, the grunge, the dark, the angst, etc. The late Brandon Lee gives a credible performance here, hitting mostly the right notes. And the great Michael Wincott adds to the enjoyment of this movie with his performance as the villain, Top Dollar. This is one movie that really is a must-see.My rating: 9/10

The fact that almost 1/3 of the movie was made after Brandon Lee's untimely demise is an accomplishment itself.  The plot is very standard, but the visuals are exceptional.  Detroit looks like such a sinister city, I'm guessing 90% of the film takes place during the night, which adds more style.  Make sure you see this movie, you won't regret it.

Review title: A gothic masterpiece of love, death, resurrection, and vengeance
Review_body: Alex Proyas gothic master piece of a man brutally murdered along with his fiancee, only to come back from the grave with supernatural powers seeking revenge for their murders.  This film will always be known as Brandon Lee's final and greatest screen role.  Lee was accidently killed during the filming.  Which only enhanced the legend of the crow and makes the film even more powerful.  I've seen The Crow and it's sequel many times and can't wait for the third installment, but know that none will have the mystique of the original.  Don't miss this movie.

If the question were put to you, would you "go gently into that good night"? What if you weren't given the choice and, instead, were left with the more grisly task of balancing the scales? Would you take it?It's Mischief Night, or Devil's Night as it's referred to in this film, in Detroit and the night before musician Eric Draven (played by Brandon Lee) and Shelley Webster (played by Sofia Shinas) are to be married. Then, thanks to their efforts to fight eviction for themselves and their fellow tenants, their home is broken into. The invaders toss Draven (Lee) through a window and send him plummeting to the ground three stories below and savage his bride-to-be. The first officer on the scene is Sgt. Albrecht (played by Ernie Hudson) and when Shelley asks about her fiancée, he spares her the truth and tells her he's fine. Then, when the latchkey kid that Eric and Shelley have taken under their wing stumbles upon the scene, Albrecht relays the lie once again. The child, Sarah (played by Rochelle Davis who also acts as the film's narrator), sees through the sergeant's reassuring fiction and departs soon after. Flash-forward one year, Sarah is visiting the graveyard where Shelly and Eric have been laid to rest and encounters a crow. After she'd left, the crow begins tapping on Eric's headstone with his beak. Then, that night, Eric emerges from his grave, shaking and traumatized. He returns to the apartment that he and Shelley once shared and finds that it is a ruin of the home he knew. While there, he begins experiencing flashbacks of the night one year before when he lost everything. Seeing the men responsible, who call themselves T-Bird (played by David Patrick Kelly), Tin-Tin (played by Laurence Mason), Funboy (played by Michael Massee), and Skank (played by Angel David). Still reeling from those memories, Eric grabs onto the frame that once held the apartment's only window and swings out and back in. He notices that he's cut himself on remnants on the window but, to his surprise, he heals almost immediately. With this new gift, he dons all black clothes, decorates his face in the style of a harlequin mask that was on the floor of his home, and sets out to seek revenge with the crow as his guide.I cannot adequately express how much I love this movie. The tone, the cinematography, the soundtrack, the antagonists. Everything about this movie is top-drawer. Fans of the graphic novel of the same name that inspired the film say that the master criminal in the film, known as Top Dollar in the novel and not actually given a name in the film, was far more ordinary than the evil genius Michael Wincott portrayed. Other critics say that the death of Brandon Lee gave this film a legacy it didn't earn, much the same way that critics claim Heath Ledger's death before the release of The Dark Knight added anticipation it wouldn't have gotten otherwise. As I was only ten when the film was first released, I was not aware of the film itself or Lee's death until much later. What I will say is that I cannot watch this film enough. Even so, if you haven't seen The Crow, shame on you.

WARNING SPOILERS??? I HOPE NOT!!!This is a KEWL movie. Much better than the sequel, with its haunting storyline and dark and dingy backgrounds. Brandon Lee played the lead character exceptionally well (he was killed in the making of this flick)Despite the graphic violence, drug-taking, vicious killers and rapists, the story is still great. It basically revolves around a young dude who is murdered by a bunch of pyscho maniacs. His bride-to-be is beaten violently to death. He is reincarnated to avenge both their deaths by killing the monsters responsible. The crow that follows him around is his third eye and the source of his 'immortal' powers.This is definitely not a movie for the faint of heart. We see the bad guys gettin their just desserts in the most violent ways imaginable, they are hunted down like animals and killed according to what tortures they inflicted upon our hero's bride before she died her slow and painful death. Of course, they deserve to die like animals, except our hero wouldn't even kill an animal like that!!However, despite the gratuitous violence and colourful uses of the 'F' word, there are still tender tear-jerker moments and a few humourous moments too.I recommend this flick to anybody who loves action flicks.

(The summary above only makes sense to true Crow fans...)Brandon Lee was remarkable in this. My only complaint is that he died. This was his film, through and through. He worked to bring it to existence, he labored to finish it, and in the end he paid the ultimate price for his art. He will be missed.This movie is a testament to how love breaches the gap of death. It is a love story, regardless of content. Many of the sequences of the comic are not present, for valid reasons, but I kind of wish they were...perhaps the "Jones Transfer" segment I mentioned would have been good for a commercial (or two.) Who can say?..I saw this movie immediately upon release and was pleased to see it. It is a fine example of a unique spin on an old idea. More moviemakers should take the cue from O'Barr, et. al., and climb out on a limb once and a while -- and make something different. Something that might not be great, but is far the more genuine for it.

Plot:A man brutally murdered comes back to life as an undead avenger of his and his fiancée's murder.Analysis:Before emo and goth style becomes mainstream, The Crow took a huge risk to choose this in mid-90s. It certainly has an influence from grunge style, almost like a Nirvana music video but it takes it a step further by doing something new, and inspiring many films that were released even two decades after this one.The movie is an adaptation of a very famous comic book series. Despite being some pretty good material, the story was changed almost completely by maintaining a certain core from the original, but also changing a huge part of it to make it more cinematic. After all, who would wanna see a very overpowered guy who doesn't sweat at all? No one. The Crow in this movie is in pain, physical and spiritual, he is not a random psychopath, his goal is revenge, justice that wasn't done back then when he and his fiancée were brutally murdered. David J. Schow and John Shirley managed to successfully complete the impossible task of humanizing the character and they made him almost relatable as the very tragic figure who's emotional and a human after all that was given a chance to fix the wrong that had been done to him and his beloved one. It's hard to say what I love the most about this movie, from the wonderful character to great poetic quotes and amazing interractions everything about this movie is top-level moviemaking and the screenplay is still over twenty years later one of the simplest and most awesome ones I've ever seen in a comic book movie. You don't need a very complicated story to produce something worth-watching, you just need to be passionate about what you're doing. Exceptionally paced, well-written, very intetesting and quite stylish, The Crow is everything you ever wanted.Alex Proyas has done some very good (Dark City) and some very bad (Gods of Egypt) projects over the years but he never did anything simillar to this one, probably because this is close to perfection. Amazing dark tone, fantastic camera work and unique style, things that made this movie even more memorable, incredible original scenes, well-executed ideas and a satisfying result that it was certain that it would become a cult classic. With every re-watch I really try to find things I don't like in his direction but I just can't, I really wish we could see more movies like this one, gothic, dark and awesome.Sadly, this whole project was marked by the sudden on-set death of Brandon Lee who portrayed the main character Eric Draven. Lee was fataly injured by a poor designed proped that costed him his life and made this film ever more sad and dark. Eric was a man that was given a second chance to fix the injustice that was done to him, too bad that Brandon can't have the same treatment from the universe. But despite his death, he managed to show what a wonderful actor he was and what a huge star he would be, by creating a memorable and unique character that inspired a lot of people and creators like Cristopher Nolan and Heath Ledger who crafted the final form of Joker in the movie The Dark Knight clearly influenced by Lee's Eric Draven. His performance was amazing and he will be missed.Conclusion:Everytime I watch this movie I get goosebumps by the quality and fun of this project. It's not just great everytime I think of it, it's also extremely entertaining every single time. It's not among the best movies every made but it's one of the greatest experiences you can have as it will be tons of fun and inspiring. Give this film a chance and you will be rewarded on every level. R. I. P. Brandon LeeRating: 9.5/10.

I like impossible equations that work. Hear me out - how about... a serious, dark movie about a guy coming back to take revenge from the dead. Eh... A rock'n'roll-dude, even, whose SOUL is carried on earth by a CROW, which acts as his companion throughout the movie. Yea, right... Well, you don't hear any "yea, rights" when this flick plays. See, THIS is what happens, when the director knows his sh*t, and you invest on the atmosphere - who says photography and lightning are trivial in an action flick? The result is just like the comic-book: almost looks like it (almost black & white), dark, and full of energy; looks like "a beautiful nightmare". And kicks ass!

I never saw this originally in '94 because I dismissed it as A. a martial arts film (and I hate those) and B. adapted from a comic (and I just can't get into those) and C. aimed at a teen/ goth/punk audience (and I am way too old for that). What a mistake! Finally a decade on, a friend heard me say how much I liked Alex Proyas' DARK CITY -- a neat sci fi film with a very different story but the same kind of dark fantasy look -- and couldn't believe I had never seen THE CROW and made me watch it.I have to say that I really think this is a very fine, well made movie and none of my preconceptions were remotely correct. The art direction is brilliant, with a wonderful and creepy Gothic fantasy look, almost but not quite black-and-white, set in a mysteriously surreal "Detroit" that is in some kind of alternate universe from the real Motown. Brandon Lee is really charismatic and haunting in the role of Eric Draven, and not merely because of the tragic incident surrounding the film. He was real star material and just totally inhabits this part.After seeing the film, I did read the O'Barr comic, which is very sincere and heartfelt, but I think the filmmakers -- in what is a pretty rare event -- IMPROVED the plot and characters while keeping all of the angst and atmosphere. They totally honored the character of Eric and the basic idea of the avenger, the memories of his beautiful girlfriend, and sense of overwhelming grief that inhabits the graphic novel. Where they improved the storyline in cinematic terms is in the treatment of the minor characters and villains. They really fleshed them out, and it enriches the movie and balances the storyline well.Bookending the film with quotes from Sarah (Rochelle Davis), the little girl who narrates and observes much of the story is an example of a good idea that doesn't really exist in the comic, where the little girl is called Sherri and only appears briefly. Even more so is the expansion of the character of Top Dollar, who again is a minor episode in the comic and more of a grubby hell's angel/drug dealer -- in the film he has been transformed into a complex and compelling crime-lord. Michael Wincott is simply amazing in this part, playing Top Dollar as a kind of depraved, satanic, renaissance prince, and clearly having a great deal of fun with this role, especially some wonderful and very clever dialog. The very, very sick (but quite sincere) love story between Top Dollar and his psychic half-sister is the reversed-mirror image of the pure and innocent love of Eric and his fiancé...a very clever idea.Wonderful music, great visuals, terrific acting..."The Crow" should NOT be missed.NOTE: I bought the "Collector's DVD". Don't bother. There is NOTHING worth looking at on the second DVD, some production sketches and posters, nothing special. The director's commentary (on the first disk) is interesting to listen to ONCE, but you can get that on the single disk DVD. There is a smattering of extra footage, but nothing you will miss. Save some bucks and just get the one disk wide screen version.

Review title: A beautiful, marvellous and poetic adaption of the comic with the same skills
Review_body: Brandon Lee, a triumph of an actor, earned his stardom from his film...and his life. I recently bought this film, knowing it appealed to many Gothic cultures and thought of this as something I may enjoy-and it was worth every penny. I enjoy perhaps every moment of this film, and it remains one of my favourites. The symbolic scene of The Crow's arrival from the grave shall remain in my head for years to come. How could I explain this film? How could I project such a legendary plot, I'll never know. The only thing I can honestly say is to see this film. Watch it just more than once and have it stay in your mind forever. Goth bless James 'O Barr for bringing us in the first place a story like this-an expanded poem in the format of a film. A horror-like film with Goth potential, anyone can enjoy ''The Crow''.

Review title: Death Wish in goth drag thats surprisingly soars.
Review_body: This is a real surprise. It's a very dark revenge fantasy that flies on imagination and a terrific performance by Brandon Lee. Director Alex Proyas's stunning feature debut is a stylistic masterpiece based on James O'Barr's best-selling graphic novel. Although it can be dismissed as Death Wish dressed up for the kids it can't be easily forgotten. I keep going back to this movie because Lee is genuinely sweet and tragic as a hero returned from the dead to exact revenge on a gang of speed metal villians. He makes you root for him. His work here totally wins you over (which makes his actual death all the more painful for people who love movies). And the villians are among the most colorful and evil ever assembled on the big screen. Michael Wincott and David Patrick Kelly lead this band of bad guys. Each set piece that leads Eric Draven/The Crow getting revenge up the bad guy ladder is sharp and adrenalized. Proyas's camera work and cutting are truly something to behold. Ernie Hudson's is memorable as a disbelieving cop who befriends Draven. For all of the stylistic guts this movie has (it looks very dark as well) it would not have won me over so much if it weren't for Lee's poignant work which is something very unexpected in such a dark and violent fantasy. Like such films as The Terminator and The Road Warrior, The Crow rises far above its B-movie trappings into a modern mythology of sorts.

I finally watched The Crow, and even though I was aware of its reputation going in, I was still deeply impressed by what a rich, well-crafted and darkly beautiful film it is. Violent and tragic, but also poetic and passionate. Certainly worthy of high esteem.Like many of the best films, The Crow draws energy from a very simple, powerful theme, but does not rely on just one character. Brandon Lee is fantastic in the title role, but I was surprised to discover a terrific group of supporting players, from the police to the villains. And the same goes for the story--there are small details written into this film that add extra dimensions. That's one of the marks of a well-written film--not just coasting on a gimmick, but telling a story that is clearly part of a greater world. The Crow has this quality in spades.The one other thing that I have to mention is that, while in many ways this film shares an aesthetic with Tim Burton's Batman films, i.e. darkly Gothic set pieces and so forth, it is impossible to look at Brandon Lee and not see how clearly his character design here influenced the Heath Ledger Joker in Christopher Nolan's The Dark Knight. It's uncanny. Beyond that, one can look at The Crow and see its fingerprints all over many other subsequent films. Very influential, this, and no doubt one of the best films of its type that I have ever seen.

Review title: One of the greatest comic book movies ever put on the big screen!
Review_body: This might be a very controversial thing to say, but I think that The Crow is one of the best films of 1994, it's after Pulp Fiction and Shawshank Redemption. One of the most tragic things about The Crow is that actor Brandon Lee died on set, he got shot in a scene that Michael Massee wanted to add in to make the story even the darker. Except the gun was not a prop, it had real bullets in there and Lee ended up getting shot. R.I.PSaying that, Brandon Lee's iconic performance as The Crow/Eric Draven will live on for eternity. First of all, this film is very nostalgic for me because I remember sneaking it into my mum's DVD player on the side of her laptop when I was around 5 and I remember watching 25 minutes of it and already being pretty scared. Some scenes had to be done without Brandon Lee because he had famously died on set, so they cleverly used light and shadow and/or special effects to cover up the fact that it's not Brandon Lee.The script is fantastic, the iconic images from it are also pretty creepy. It's one of those films like The Dark Knight or Inception that lived up to my expectations and exceeded them. Literally everything about this movie has a Gothic atmosphere, the set design is beautiful, go check it out if you haven't, it's one of my all time favourites.

One of the absolute best comic book movies ever and this was before there were seemingly dozens of them being made every year. Brandon Lee gives such an intense and emotional performance that is made even more chilling considering that he died while it was filming. A dark super hero film that will probably be re-booted at some point but it's got very big shoes to fill. Plus there's no topping this soundtrack filled with lots of ear- candy songs that you'll want to enjoy after the film is over. But avoid all the sequels, unless you're a die hard fan of the series.

Review title: The best movie of all time
Review_body: "Because we do not know when we will die we get to think of life as an inexhaustible well and yet everything happens only a certain number of times, how many times will you remember a certain afternoon of your childhood, an afternoon that is so deeply a part of your being you cannot even conceive of your life without it.Perhaps four or five times more?.Perhaps not even that.How many times will you watch the full moon rise, perhaps twenty, and yet it all seems limitless"Thanks to Brandon Lee I can remember this passage word for word,every time i watch The Crow i can`t help thinking what Brandon Lee was thinking when he was actually shot, i can picture how it happened.It is so very touching.The film in general is Top class, Brandon Lee plays the murdered revenge-on his-mind Eric Draven,and he portrays him well, it was a good touch that he was a Martial arts expert. I like the scenes where it freezes on pictures of Brandon.He made everyones life better (in the film) and he reunited a druggie mother with her rebellious daughter. The story of a rock star and his fiancee who are murdered on Halloween Eve, they were  sort of surrogate parents to Sarah the rebellious teenager.It was an all time greatest film and should be in the top 10 films of all time, it was once again like many others ruined by totally crap sequels, and now a second sequel is out i feel like puking.Brandon lee was killed during this movie and they should at least pay respect to him by leaving The Crow as an original, no sequels or anything.Because of Brandon Lee`s brilliant acting along with almost every other part of the film I give this first class film a 9 and a half out of 10. it would have got a 10 if Brandon Lee could have seen how much of a hit this film was.

The Crow is based on James O'Barr's independent comic book by the same name. Both the comic book and the movie are dark stories of revenge. The movie takes some liberties with the material, but is mostly faithful. The comic book has some beautiful illustrations, and the movie looks and sounds good (the music by Graeme Revell)...unfortunately, the story is crap.It's just a supernatural rock version of Death Wish. A man gets wronged by evil scumbags and kills almost everyone. The only difference is that while Kersey from Death Wish takes the law into his own hands, Draven is sent back against his will, to enact some kind of weird, divine retribution. And Draven doesn't even have a mustache...It's no surprise then that the movie is very violent (but mild compared to the comic book). It is a story about revenge, after all. People are stabbed, burned, slashed, thrown out of windows, impaled etc. One of the villains cuts out women's eyes. The same villain gets her own eyes pecked out by a crow. The assault on Draven and his wife is disturbing. There's some nudity in it. And the main villain is sleeping with his sister for some reason. Probably to show how evil and twisted he is. None of it made the movie any better. You could remove the nudity and creepy sex stuff, and tone down the violence a lot and still have a dark and gritty story. Just watch Nolan's Batman trilogy.The "land of the dead" must be a confusing place. Sometimes, just sometimes, the crow can bring souls back to put the wrong things right...but what happens to the people who are murdered by Eric Draven, where do they go? And what about Draven's wife? Where is she? Probably in the land of the dead. But, if she's in the land of the dead, why does Draven return? She shows up again at the end, and like Princess Peach from Super Mario, she's Draven's reward for murdering a lot of evil goombas.Maybe that's the idea? The land of the dead is the "first level" of the afterlife, and some lucky souls are sent back for a chance to reach the next level, where their beautiful wives wait for them. They just have to prove their worth by slaughtering King Koopa. But, what would happen to Eric Draven if he died in the church? Would the crow take him back to the land of the dead? What if T-Bird, Skank etc. Were there too? Awkward!Maybe I'm over-analyzing it? Anyway, it's not a very good movie, but then again, the comic book isn't very good either. It's a pointless story. Just some guy slaughtering a lot of evil people. There's no real message here...wouldn't it be more interesting if Draven came back and found out that some of the killers regretted their evil deeds? We have seen the "they killed his wife, poisoned his goldfish and made annoying slurping sounds last time they drank a soda at McDonald's...now, he's back" stuff before. It rarely ends with anything other than blood and death. I would love to see a story like this that ends with mercy and forgiveness.There are some good parts in the movie, like the scenes with Draven and the girl, and the last scene where Draven is reunited with his wife. It's just sad that those beautiful scenes are wasted on a crappy movie like this. It's also very sad that Brandon Lee died during the making of The Crow...rest in peace.Sometimes, just sometimes, I wish The Crow could bring me my time and money back.

Perfect atmosphere and stylization! Gloomy, depressing and extremely impressive. Perfect characters! The villain, his band and everyone else are all very charismatic, but Brandon Lee steals the spotlight. It's so sad that such a young (and greatly talented) actor isn't with us anymore. Perfect music! In particular, It Can not Rain All The Time stuck in my head. Perfect story writing! A classic straightforward revenge, but with a very effective emotional background. Perfect action! Although the pacing of the movie fluctuated slightly, The Crow is a perfect movie for me. Full 10 out of 10.

Everyone kept telling me how good the crow was. feeling left out i borrowed it from a friend. All the reviews on the front cover said "amazing" "better than batman" so on so on.I sat in and watched it one Saturday night and i loved it. The thing thats different about the crow is that it is just simple action. Guy gets murdered and comes back from the dead to get revenge on the people that killed him and his fiancé. See. No questions asked about why he comes back just straight to the point no boring points in between.The crow delivers something else that other action does not maybe because it's so much more darker and is a revenge story or a Gothic black fairy tale.And don't get me wrong you don't have to be a goth to like this. This film is perfect for everyone to enjoy."Brandon you rock" P.S don't watch the sequels i haven't seen them it just spits on Brandon Lee's memory."

Okay, I'm biased. I'm one of those weird people who love most things goth. While this movie also has a comic-book flavor to it, the combination is terrific, creating a mood of death-obsession and bittersweet purity. "The Crow" is a work of dark beauty; as swan songs go, it is also a triumph for Brandon Lee, who died tragically during the filming. A masterpiece of atmosphere, this film is one of my all-time favorites. It has its faults, certainly. For those who can't lose themselves in it, those faults will be glaringly obvious. For those who can, though, they're barely noticeable, if at all. As far as I'm concerned, spotless perfection rarely equals beauty or brilliance. Perfection is frequently boring and disappears from the memory. This movie is beautiful and brilliant, and it certainly leaves an impression.

Review title: It can't rain all the time.
Review_body: Superb action flick about Eric Draven who was thrown out of the window at devil's night and his fiancee, Shelly Webster, brutally raped and murdered. Bad luck for the killers because the soul of Eric has no rest untill they are all dead. Excellent dark setting. RIP Brandon Lee.

wow. just wow. this movie is so awesome. the dark atmosphere in the movie gives it such an awesome feel to the movie. the emotions are so strong in this movie, its deep and you feel it.the music for this movie works magic for the feel to it. Review title: One Of The All Time Greats
Review_body: Just watched this film for the first time in 2 years... my god, you kinda forget what greatness was achieved.It's got great story, superb acting (which is a major thing nowadays)... music... everything is simply awesome.Yes, one of the great love stories with such sadness... yet, action and revenge. This film has everything and cannot in my opinion be bettered. This is certainly up with the likes of BladeRunner and T1 for sheer atmosphere.Such a crying shame Brandon was lost during the making, kinda upsets me just thinking about it... still, he'll now be remembered in this timeless classic. This is the best comic book movie ever made. From the angles and lighting to the dialogue and action to the soundtrack/score this movie has it all. As a kid this film change my life as I never thought an action movie could be so deep and tragic and yet it's not depressing at all. Brandon Lee would have been proud of this film. There are many comic movie adaptations but none as gritty, gruesome or intriguing. This is a well produced gem of a film and should be left alone to be celebrated without the distasteful act of a remake or reboot. Eric Draven was the true Avenger.

Despite comments that proclaim this movie really deep and memorable the performance by the "late great Brandon Lee (as if he was a great actor or even as good as his dad)" this movie left a lot to be desired as far as I'm concerned. Now let me say right off, if you are a fan of the comic book (or other popular Gothic literature) you probably will like the movie or at least find it more interesting then I did. But I am reviewing this movie from the perspective of an action fan / experienced movie watcher and therefore I have no particular bias towards the genre.Anyway the plot is pretty standard. Guy is wronged by criminals who kill him and his wife and he comes back a year later to seek revenge. I guess this is slightly different cause usually the bad guys only "think" they kill the guy, but this time they managed to finish him off and he comes back to life (sorta). Still it's your standard revenge/action movie plot with little suspense actually cause he is invincible so there is no chance he will get hurt. So he kills abunch of guys and the action is so so. The biggest gunfight is pretty lame actually, the bad guys just keep shooting at him and the bullets have no effect...but they never learn and keep shooting, silly criminals. It has a predictable ending and there isn't very much mystery.The movie also has managed to pack a ton of clichés that any action fan can spot. The angry police chief, the helpful police officer who comes to the Crows aid at the end (only after being suspended, cause as we all know the cop can never get anything done while actually on the force), the girl who is gonna kidnapped by the bad guys at the end, the fight on the roof (sometimes on another perilous location, but rooftop is standard), the bad guy falling off and getting impaled, the climactic fight in the rain, pretty lame chase scenes (2), vigilante hero, rainy dark city (someone said think Blade Runner, I wouldn't give it that much credit, I would say think Split Second with Rutger Hauer), flashbacks to the original crime. There are probably a few more but those are just the ones off the top of my head.Anyway the movie is not nearly as original as some of it's fans make it sound. The characters are really 2-dimensional. It's kind of funny to hear people say that the movie is deep. It's really simple, the guy is killed he comes back to avenge his girl friends death and kill the bad guys. There are some attempts to have the Crow represent a Christ like figure (palms healing, touching the crack-whore and the drugs come out of her body and she turns a new leaf in life, the whole resurrection aspect (i guess)). Still that is only a few brief scenes, and besides when you really think of it, Jesus came back to life so that he could ascend to heaven, the Crow came back so he could kill the guys who murdered his girlfriend and ruined his budding rock career (btw his guitar solo on top of the building was really moving).So in conclusion you could do better. Darkman is essentially the same movie but is more entertaining and certainly has a more interesting directing style. The action here is pretty mediocre and the results are predictable (though I admit pretty much 100% of action movies are predictable). To fans of the comic I would recommend it (I guess, though I have never read the comic so I don't know how faithful a representation this is).One more thing. I love how he (and now on this site) people quote Edgar Allen Poe (who is much more worthy of your time then this movie)and give the quote "Suddenly I heard a tapping, as of someone gently rapping...at my chamber door". I guess for the makers of the movie they thought, "Crow, raven who will notice that it isn't the same bird? It sounds cool so let's just put it in there." Apparently not the fans of this movie.Zoopansick

Review title: you have to be objective, this is a bad movie
Review_body: Stop giving this movie a high score just because of the circumstances, does it all of sudden make this movie great? You know it doesn't deserve a 7.x on IMDb. It's a stupid, worthless movie. This fails on several, if not all levels. I couldn't even finish watching this cheesy movie, half of this juvenile trash was enough for me before I finally gave up being sadistic enough to torture myself with this.This has such bad and unconvincing acting, especially by the star of the film, Brandon Lee. A movie with a poorly executed story is made even harder to watch when the star of the movie couldn't act his way out of a house with no walls (therefore no roof, think about it). His wife got raped and killed, what is he supposed to be, angry or campy? Why is he making jokes as he toys with his victims? This is like a damn cartoon for 10 year olds. If the movie didn't take itself so seriously, then I wouldn't mind that performance choice so much. Everything from the script and the dialog was formulaic. How can anyone think this is a great movie? It's not 100% horrible, but it ain't Spider-Man, it's Elektra, enough said.

Review title: the crow is best movie ever made
Review_body: The crow is a great movie the acting is great a bunch of action in this movie the storyline was better good

Review title: Ahead Of Its Time And Has A Permanent Place In My Top 5 Of All Time
Review_body: My top five favorite movies probably change from time to time when one is bumped and another takes its place but The Crow is there to stay. No movie is perfect, all have flaws but this is as close as you can come to my idea of perfection. It is the perfect balance of haunting drama and violent revenge with a gothic atmosphere unlike any other movie of its kind. Years ahead of what most of us now think of as comic book movies this one got it right on the first try (perhaps never again but honorable mention to Dacascos for playing Draven honorably on the tv show) and Lee didn't just transition from martial arts movie star to something more he catapulted into a broader genre with a haunting performance which I have always though Ledger might have drawn some inspiration from years later. I'm a huge fan of comics and the movie adaptations but this one and Logan deserve a special place in the ranks as both managed to maintain a tragic sadness throughout while still being great action movies. The Crow of course gets extra points for having done it all in 1994! A must see for fans of drama, action, gothic movies or really just fans of cinema in general!!! If it had to be his final film it sure showed what he was capable of above and beyond great fight scenes!

Review title: WHY IS IT SO GOOD? LET ME SAY WHY
Review_body: I like to think that when it comes to films i know a thing or two, i have around 300 dvds and follow and collect on a few of them, I saw The Crow in 1994, i saw it 12 times on the big screen...yes 12, why 12? well i found many things about this film to bring me back time after time, the first few times it was the action and the way it way shot that brought me back but soon i looked deeper into the story and its background, it struck on points about life and how we treat it, there are interviews with the late great Brandon Lee in which he covers this point in detail but the just been that we only have so long here and we should not take it and people for granted. The Crow was made with little money and some say this was the cause or part cause for Mr Lees death as the set should of had more people working on the checking of guns used in the film and the safety of the crew, others would go into the curse of the Lees or strange plots to do away with him, but the truth will out although i feel they have it now, just a pure accident, the low cost of this film hardly ever shows through, its shot with flair and hits all the right notes when it comes to the music which helps drive the film, the rock soundtrack by many great bands and one of the best scores by Greame Revell which has been sampled by other films. The Crow is a film that you must see, nothing can be found to fault it and its easy to see that all who worked on this film gave it there all, make what you will of those that followed but this is timeless. R.I.P Brandon Lee

Review title: Fantastically grimy, dark, stylish..I love it
Review_body: The Crow is fantastic. Insanely stylish, violent, and atmospheric, this movie scratches The Batman itch until it finally releases. It bleeds style and vibe, with a killer soundtrack along for the ride. 9/10.

Review title: A Wicked Tale of Vengeance, Power, Blood, and a Crow
Review_body: The Crow is one of the best hero movies I have seen. I don't really know if the Crow is actually a super hero, but he plays a great one. This is one of the darkest movies I had ever seen. It has a dark sense of humor and plenty of knife-stabbing, gun-firing action. This a creepy tale of vengeance over a dead fiancée. A highly recommended film, however the subjects in this movie may be hazardous to the unstable. I gave this movie an 8. Perhaps a thrilling classic in film history. While there will be many seuqels to come, the original Crow will always be the best one. If you have any agreements or comments for me, please e-mail me at tylerripen@yahoo.com.

The Crow is a cult classic for several reason I think, but it is not made for everyone. Do I think it is a flawless movie? No. But in that sense, along with everything else to like about it, I think it's awesome as a whole.Plot- It's about a musician being resurrected by a crow, which then obligates him to avenge the murder of his girlfriend. If you're a majorly picky person when it comes to realism, just note, this is a fantasy movie as much as an action crime thriller. The story is told straight forwardly, with interjections of flashbacks and about one montage, with the main driving force being revenge. There are pretty funny moments, some twisted, and it all takes place within two days (I'm pretty positive) Has a good ending scene that will stick in your mind.Writing- I love it. I know there are rare moments, mainly with the little kid, where it's a fine line between cliché writing and bad acting. But there are definitely some good quotes to walk away with, a lot of natural conversation that isn't useless in terms of the plot. Always nice to have that.Acting/Characters- Brandon Lee is stellar in this role. It's a cool thing to see, for it appears he wasn't in many popular films that would allow him to actually act. In this film, he is full of life within his emotions, which makes every scene so good to me. The supporting cast is great too, minus the little girl. The bad guys are infamously stuck in my head after seeing them shout "FIRE IT UP! FIRE IT UP!" like animals. The main villain is very good too, unpredictable, and played very well.Quality- The production design is killer, absolutely original and cool. It looks like the darkest, most off kilter part of New York or New Jersey. The cinematography is sick, I'll never forget the scene where he finally finds his strength and runs across the rooftops in the night. The filming, the scenery, and the original soundtrack is so great in this movie- so original, and that's why I think it is considered a cult classic.Overall, if you don't like movies that have anything unbelievable in it, don't watch this. If you can simply embrace a movie for the good qualities, understanding it's fiction, this movie is super cool. It's so sad to see somebody absolutely knock out a performance (referring to Lee) and pass away on set. Anyways, this is one of my favorite movies, easily top 10, simply because of the genuine scenes and the unparalleled style. Try to find a movie like this before it's time, you most likely won't. I recommend it highly.

Review title: A Contemporary Classic in every way!
Review_body: When I first heard of Brandon lee's death back in '93 I didn't become so shocked until I took a glimpse of the film when it got released in th UK in 1994.It's extermely tragic not to mention speechless to lose someone who's career coincidently started to shine through. Only recently I watched "Dragon: The Bruce Lee story" and I started to shed tears wishing both father and son were still alive. Lets face it Brandon Lee's performance might've not been the best, but hey at least he would've done better than the likes of Keanu Reeves. I even considered Brandon Lee for future roles in films that would've elevated him in even further than his father. Even looks that could rival some of today's leading actors' (Johnny Depp, Ben Affleck etc).The film's demonstration of Lee's performance was equivelent to a like a starter cuisine. Although sad to lose such striking actor who had very little time to blossom, we can only imagine what roles would best suit him (Cyclops: X-Men, Johnny Cage: Mortal kombat, even a perfect cast for films like Lord of The Rings. I know that might sound a few and far between, but it's matter of personal opinion).Long live Brandon Lee (The body rests, but the spirit lives on)

Review title: Dark, Gothic and oh so good
Review_body: If one word could describe this film it would be dark. Dark is the absence of light, and throughout much of this film..light is hard to see.It begins with the tragedy that shapes the film; a rock musician named Eric Draven and his fiancé have just been brutally murdered by thugs. One year on, and Eric Draven's soul is having trouble resting, so a crow brings him back to the real world to put the wrong things right...queue one of the best films ever made.The cityscape plays a major part in setting the scene for this Gothic film. Tall looming brick buildings line desolate, garbage strewn, rainswept streets, a pitch black soulless sky hangs overhead, gunshots and screams can be heard echoing through the night. This is one town you DON'T want to be. Then we meet the locals; drug addicts, hookers killers, freaks, thieves, pyromaniacs and thats just the nicer ones.Eric Dravens transition from frightened, newly awoken victim to face painted, high flying avenger is both energetic and powerful. The film definitely gets better and better as Eric does his stuff and cleans up the streets. The film is violent as you'd expect, but also touching in some bits, such as when Eric speaks with the cop who was as the scene when he and his girlfriend were murdered. Also when Eric appears to a lonely young girl who he used to help take care of.Brilliant heavy metal soundtrack, cool action scenes, grizzly characters, far out camera work and unique execution methods make this film one that will stay in your mind. I've seen it many times since first seeing it 10 years ago, and it doesn't loose its power.I only wish people would recognise it for what it is, instead of giving it a cult status because it was the film where Bruce Lee's son was killed by a firearm accident.
I loved this movie! It had me on the edge of my seat, as Eric disposed of his murderers one by one! Gothic, dark, and creepy!

"The Crow" tells the classic tale, of a man having revenge on the wrong-doers of his life. There are a few twists though. For one the man is killed in the beginning of the film, hence having to come back from the dead, helped by a crow. Now we have a classic tale, with a touch of urban legend.This guy is completely twisted in mind and soul, as he mourns for his true love, that died with him. That's a dash of romance right there. Naturally there's villian. This villian is also a bit on the edgy side of the human psyche. With remarks as "My father once told me that childhood is over the day you know you're gonna die", he's not the guy you want crashing in at your birthday-party. Although intelligent and wise, you get the feeling that him dying, wouldn't be all that bad, for the world as we know it. Madness and philosophy is added. Then there's the whole enviorment, that Mr. Proyas can create. It IS amazing. The dark world, that makes the urban streets feel unsafe, and yet interesting. Reminds me of Blade Runner, but that might just be the rain.Time to sum up, people: We have our classic tale of revenge, tweaked with urban legend, the right enviorment, romance, madness and philosophy. That's kinda shakespeare, hence the 9, I'm giving this masterpiece.

Contrary to how it is categorized in most stores, this is a romance movie -- albeit a dark and disturbing one.  The entire purpose of Eric Draven's resurrection is to avenge his and his fiancee's deaths.  I've never seen a movie with such emotion and classic one-liners.Most people compliment Brandon Lee's performance, and rightfully so, but many overlook great performances by Michael Wincott and Ernie Hudson.  Both of them are good as supporting characters.  Wincott delivers almost as many classic lines as Lee.  Hudson is the perfect choice for the police officer -- showing his versatility (who would have thought Winston Zeedmore from Ghostbusters would be the one of the four to go on to a dramatic career?).Tragic in that it was Brandon Lee's last movie, and that he died while filming it.  This adds to the surreal atmosphere of the film, especially since its protagonist has been resurrected from the dead.  I first saw this film with an old girlfriend and disliked it because she MADE me watch it, but I saw it again 8 years later and realized what I'd missed.  Great film overall.

Review title: Among the Worst That Hollywood Has to Offer!
Review_body: I wish there were a zero rating on IMDb. The movie industry ought to have a "Toxic Waste" rating, the kind that damages our society with absolutely no chance of cleanup. Yes, I believe that The Crow is the Love Canal of movies...I can't believe this motion picture was directed by the same person who directed "Dark City." If I had seen The Crow (an earlier film) first, I would never have viewed Dark City, and that would have been a shame. The two don't belong on the same planet... They truly don't reside in the same universe. The only thing I can figure: The Crow came out of Hollywood, while Dark City came out of Australia.Regardless of what Roger Ebert says about The Crow (he called it "good" ?), to me it is the worst piece of ultra-violent dreck I have ever seen, even including "Narc," the only other film I've rated a "1" here. Both richly deserve a complete zero. I detect a pattern here: Both films' stories take place in Detroit. Moral: Never watch any film whose setting is Detroit! The Crow is genuinely scary to me, but not in the way you might imagine. I think the horribly ultra-violent spirit of the film, completely unrelieved throughout (no matter the insipid, unbelievably saccharine "good guys win" ? ending) contributed directly to Brandon Lee's death. How else can you explain something as bizarre as a "blank" movie-prop round killing someone during the filming of a motion picture? It is obvious to me that so many (way-over-the-top many) "blank" shots had to be fired at the (so-called) "hero" that this must have contributed to Lee's death. Someone said this film is a fitting memorial to Lee. Indeed. No further comment required.Even the music during the ending credits: "It Can't Rain All the Time," or whatever it's called, is nausea-producing garbage. The singer is horribly flat (pitch, that is). Just listen to it, if you dare; it is totally forgettable trash. Thank heavens it has been forgotten! I made the mistake of starting to play the comment track by the Producer and Screenwriter. I do wish English grammar allowed me to de-capitalize their titles. I think they are quite demented, totally out of touch with reality... I believe their warped view of the world has caused them to descend into the depths of self-aggrandizing insanity.People: Do not view The Crow, ever. Unless you like flirting with brain-damaging toxic waste. If you let any teenager view this film, it should be considered that you should be jailed for launching sociopathic violence on the rest of us.Thank Goodness I watched The Crow only once. I am hoping that Time Will Heal All Wounds.

Review title: cool action + cool special effect + cool soundtrack = cool movie
Review_body: This movie is really cool.  Brandon Lee rocks as Eric Draven, a tormented soul sent back to earth to revenge the death of him and his beautiful girlfriend.  Micheal Wincott is equally profound as the crimelord that ordered his thugs to take them out.  The action scenes are awesome, the soundtrack is ripping, and the special effects are cool.  This movie is very entertaining, with enough action and romance to satisfy everyone.  But stay away from the lame sequel.

14 years after its original release, and the movie still holds up well! This inspite of watching dozens of movies that have copied or have been inspired in different ways from Alex Proyas's excellent 'dark' superhero movie.Although the movie comes across very simple and straight forward, considering that we have seen all the movies that this pioneered, it still stands on its own for the wonderful portrayal of a back-from-dead vigilante out to avenge the destruction of his life. Brandon Lee, who died in a freak accident while this movie was shot, plays his resurrected character of Draven coming to terms with his new found powers with such fierce glee that it becomes difficult to disassociate the actor from the character. It's not that he is a good actor - it's just the physical grace he brings to his movements that makes the supernatural element of his character's presence more effective. Most of the movie plays out in the night (two nights a year apart from each other), something which Proyas had done in Dark City too before succumbing to the Hollywood machine. If seen these movies when they were released, it would be easy to be excited about the future of this promising director.The movie is a let down though when it comes to the supporting characters and the villain. As much as the Crow goes about executing his oppressors over one night, there is no sense of threat to him as he finishes them off with relative ease - although in spectacular fashion.For fans of cinema, the movie adds a lot to enjoy. It starts with a homage to Blade Runner. And references to The Crow are equally easy to find in later movies, especially in The Matrix. Or when relating Heath Ledger's Joker to Brandon Lee's Crow in a few key scenes. What a tragic coincidence that both actors died before their milestone performances were released.My rating --> 3 of 5

There are very few films that have combined the necessary elements of filmmaking as well as this offering.The elements I feel that are essential to create a movie that may achieve cult status and be respected by audiences and artists alike are a strong emsemble cast,direction, cinematography and a soundtrack that complements the theme.As for being a showpiece for goth,all elements are here-a man oppressed who after a tragedy rises against his oppressors and takes revenge in a dark and brutal manner using the forces used against him on his enemies.Pain is now his weapon.The cast is superb and everyone contributes by rendering fine performances.Brandon Lee is well suited to the main role and this time not only because of his martial arts skills.He has a strong on screen presence and although not being the most gifted actor,he is able to evoke the strong emotions of a man hell bent on revenge for the death of his fiancee.No other actor has been capable of creating believability for James O'Barrs character as is evident in the sequels.That is no sympathy call-just an objective observation.Micheal Wincott has a penchant for playing dark characters and it would be hard to imagine anyone else playing this role.The rest play well as dregs and are not too camp.The cast obviously could not do it alone and Alex Proyas mustered his team well to create arguably his best movie.I agree with other IMDB users that the sequels would have been more than mediocre with his influence.Cinematography is largely unheralded but it's role here in creating unforgettable images should not go unnoticed.The visions of a dark city were riveting and images from the crow's POV are easily remembered.Of great influence to O'Barr was music and the soundtrack is of world class.Every track has it's place in this movie.Moods are manipulated by each track and Eric's rage and deep set sadness is accentuated by the relevant track.The soundtrack CD is a definite must for all fans of the movie or of alternative music.It is easy to say that Brandon's death helped this movie achieve cult status.While this was an obvious influence especially considering the theme of the screenplay,I believe that cult status would have been achieved regardless owing to the elements discussed above.I believe that this was going to be the picture that would have launched Brandon to being a big Hollywood player.At least he had the chance to make a film like this.
