Awful movie not recommended.

As we sit in movie theaters today endlessly assaulted by comic adaptations many have overlooked or never seen The Crow, which is arguably the best film in the entire genre. Sure the effects are dated but the story and acting in this beautifully dark picture are leaps and bounds ahead of comic book movies today. As I just mentioned the style of this movie fits just perfectly with the characters and with the killer soundtrack that accompanies it. Some people say that this movie is overrated because of the death of Brandon Lee during shooting but honestly I first saw this movie years ago and I, first of all didn't know who Brandon Lee was or that he had died tragically due to an on the set accident. Brandon Lee in this picture simply put gives the performance of a lifetime it is just so powerful and emotional that you sometimes forget that it's a movie. It's simply not the kind of acting that is usually reserved for a comic book movie but more dramatic films instead. That is not to say the film lacks action, which there is plenty of but it's more than just that. The story is also very compelling because it poses the question to the whole audience of what they would do if they were allowed to come back, what would you do how would you view the world and all its changes since your departure and how would all your loved ones have moved forward without you? It makes you think about your own mortality because none of us know how much time we have left and we sometimes take for granted certain things because they seem small or trivial but as Eric discovers in the movie "nothing is trivial" and that's true. Under appreciated masterpiece

The Crow is my favorite movie. It's a mixed bag of emotions and it just takes you on one helluva' trip. The graphic novel was written by James O' Barr as a love letter to the woman he loved, after she had died. It is one of the most beautiful and violent books I have read. There are many differences between the graphic novel and the movie, but the main story and most of the characters stay the same. The greatest thing about the similarities is that they're both written by James O' Barr. This movie is very sad, it's very violent. This is the only movie I cry during every time I see it, and I've seen it twenty times. The Crow is a masterpiece of cinema and it contains the late Brandon Lee who sadly died during the making of this film. Watch this movie, it'll be worth it.

The best goth movie ever I love to watch it
Brandon Lee is so great to watch In this movie

Ever since i saw this movie i couldn't stop thinking about it. Its so powerful and so moving i didn't want it to stop. Brandon Lee delivers an amazing performance. I dread the day where remakes of the nineties becomes popular because i don't think anyone can ever deliver this kind of feeling and emotion. I also would like to recognize the religious similarities. Eric is Christ and he must take up the biblical quote "Vengence is Mine" and sacrifice himself to save all he loves. And finally to recognize how many unfortunate things occurred during the filming, Brandon Lee's death, the man who drove the screwdriver through his hand and the fires, it seems destined to have failed yet it only seems stronger. Incredible

Some how this movie works more than it should. Your standard revenge action comic book movie is much more with the great work (sad story) of Lee (what a good action star he would have made!), the villain (Wincott- the voice pipes on that guy!) , and the director / writer. You have touches of comedy that are a nice alt. to the regular dark tale one usually gets in these films. Check out Lee's little wave as he sends one bad guy off to his death in his car, or his quick little step/dance as he shot at by the cops, and even the one liners are not that bad :). The overall film is darkly shot- some say too dark- but I would disagree it allows the directly to use the low budget he had to greater effect and sets a timeless sorrow to this world the characters are in. The action scenes are over the top, esp one where Lee's Crow character takes on around 20 of the bad guys during a "bad guy summit" = the director hits it out of the park with the editing, music, and using Lee's physical ability to make this a stand out action piece. While it is not a perfect film if one looks for one of the better comic book movies they would do themselves a service by adding this to a short list of good ones. Long Live "The Crow"!

Review title: No film in a million years will ever top this! A Landmark In Cinematic History
Review_body: This film is absolutely phenomenal. Better than The Godfather, better than The Matrix and better than Die Hard! The Crow is one of the best films ever made. It is just like any other rubbish basic storyline. Man and his fiancée get killed. Man gets resurrected a year later and kills the people who murder him. But Proyas's sharp and exquisite directing and Brandon Lee's sensational role as Eric Draven (The Crow) has turned this film into one of the best films of all time! And its not just Lee who puts in a stunning performance. Michael Wincott - in my opinion a superb but underrated actor - turns in a superb role as the sadistic and menacing master criminal Top Dollar.Despite all of the violence and gore, it doesn't lead us away from the fact that this story is about true love lasting forever. Usually in films like this, they just mention the death of a loved one a couple of times and then it's forgotten and it gets boring. But in this film, Shelley (Lee's fiancée in the film) is mentioned a lot by Eric and a series of flashbacks - including the scene where she is beaten and raped by the villains in the movie, Tin Tin, T-Bird, Funboy and Skank - makes us realise just how much love they had for each other and we feel satisfied when Eric picks off each of the villains in an assortment of gruesome ways.The dark sets and characters all add to the gritty, Gothic atmosphere that just made me admire this film even more. It is also one of the only films i have seen where the cast has been chosen to perfection. If Lee was still alive today, I have no doubt that he would be one of the best actors around. R.I.P.My advice to anyone who hasn't seen this film. Rent it or buy it as soon as possible! You have no idea what you're missing.10 out of 5 Stars. Keep em coming Proyas!

Although Brandon Lee did not have many films to his credit, this one turned him into a legend. With witty one-liners, and eye-popping action, The Crow was his best work ever. Whether its the scene where he embeds a crow-like design in Tin-Tin's chest, or leaves behind a fiery calling card after sending T-bird to his death, Brandon Lee left his mark. I was also impressed with the film's cinematography. With black being the picture's dominant color, I felt it was a perfect fit with it's storyline. Michael Wincott delivered an equally impressive performance as Top Dollar, the evil mastermind behind the two grizzly murders. Brandon Lee truly saved his best for last. Rest In Peace Brandon.

After scrolling through about 6 pages of comments, I was shocked to find no negative ones at all. So I will fix that mistake right now. I gave The Crow 2/10 - 1 point is there because you can't rate a movie 0 points, and 1 point because it was dark and had a dark rock soundtrack, dark is cool. Other then that it just looked like any other B-movie shown on TV on a Tuesday night, some hero killing typical 100% evil bad guys, random cop with a moustache, random kid, all played by actors you normally see in different TV series. So its probably the tragic death of Brandon Lee that makes people rate this one highly, but to be honest - this movie is a complete failure.

I can only guess at the age and experience of those who, in other reviews of this movie, have dubbed it "the best movie ever". Viewers be forewarned: it isn't, not by a long-shot.What it is: a comic-genre film - and like most film versions of dark comics, it is enslaved to rain and shadows, candlelight and eyeliner aesthetics, pseudo-intellectualism and faux-poetic moments. It suffers greatly from an unbelievable premise (murderous super bad guys run wild in the streets, doing their will) and mind-numbingly dense dialog. I watched this movie just recently for the first time - and had to check all the background material on it because I just couldn't believe it was actually shot in the nineties - it is an eighties movie in every way shape and form, hearkening back to the days of the early Cure, Bauhaus, Souxsie and the Banshees, etc.The acting is flat all around (Brandon Lee spends the entire movie with his chin on his chest, glaring menacingly from underneath his furrowed brow) and what little there is of character is two-dimensional - a comic book view of the world, juvenile and meaningless, trying desperately to be "deep".If Brandon Lee hadn't died during production, this film would be regarded as nothing more than an amusing goth fantasy - and not the goth cult classic it seems to have become. I guess I understand some people's emotional attachment to it, but back when I was being goth and under the influence of nihilist aesthetics, my friends and I read Baudelaire, Sartre and Dostoevsky. To us, a film like this would be as intellectually an emotionally fulfilling as the popcorn you might eat while watching it. The "best movie ever"? Sorry. No.
After all this time I still miss him . Some people just go to young . See you again sometime

Quite simply, the greatest story ever told: A love story, about love so strong even death cannot stop it. Over a decade later, and I still quote Eric Draven every day. That's down to good writing in my book. When I saw this at the cinema, I was fighting back tears - because I knew I would never see it for the first time ever again! If Brandon Lee had not died on set, I don't see how he could ever have topped this film. He would have gone on to be a real star of course; his look, his talent and most of all his grace* would have ensured that. But this was the part he was born for, so how ironic is it that it was also the one he died for?*Watch the part where Brandon / Eric Draven walks into a room and vaults into a cross-legged position atop the table. It's so effortless most people don't even notice it, but if you or I tried the move, the result would be two broken legs!

I have seen this movie maybe five times all the way through, and i have to say that i enjoy it. But don't get me wrong, this movie is bad.....real bad. To start, the bad guys in this movie are absolutely terrible. T-Bird reminds me more of a high school teacher than a criminal. All Funboy does is sleep around. Skank is just a raving fool along for the ride. When i think about it, Tin-Tin was the only dangerous person in that group (because of the knives). Top Dollar, a criminal whose name makes no sense, is a weird dude who, what, wiggles around a sword? calls an Asian woman with huge lips his sister? kills women he sleeps with and takes out their eyes to do..what, exactly? Nothing about him either made sense or was in the least bit intimidating.The main character, Eric Draven, is (or was) a rock star with a pretty fiancée, Shelly. whenever he remembers past experiences with Shelly, he goes back to this sappy world of before when nothing could possibly go wrong and everything was set to candlelight. When he comes back from the dead, he, like other superheroes, inexplicably breaks into some makeup and paints himself to be weird. Whenever he says something, it's usually a quote of some book, and the effect is totally not there (e.g. his quote from Poe's "the Raven" in the pawn shop, or when he says "Mother is the word for God on the lips of children" to Darla - lame). And the SUBTLE interjections of humor could not possibly have occurred at more inappropriate times: when he dares funboy to shoot his hand, then laughs when it heals, it seems like he's showing off this ability that is only given to him for a single, serious purpose; and in the cathedral when he is shot, he stumbles a bit and drops an f-bomb (so badly done!)The smashing of the guitar on the rooftop was a little cheesy for my taste as well.

Review title: Not worth any of the praise it receives
Review_body: Terrible. Just terrible. There is so little, if anything good to say about this film. Poor acting, terrible script with childish attempts at wit, inconsistencies, complete lack of shock or confusion from any of the characters at seeing a man coming back from the dead. There's a reason Brandon Lee only did Martial Arts flicks before this, it's clearly all he was good at. Stephen Hawking could convey emotion and act more convincingly than this ham. Without a doubt one of the worst films I have ever seen. Don't get drawn into liking it just because it's a cult film and you think you'll seem cool if you do - watch it and judge it by its qualities rather than its style, and you'll see this film for the stinker it is.

Since i first saw the crow i've been in love with it. every scene and every message is utterly amazing to me. the tragic tale of james o'barr's fallen lover is put to fantasy and brought to life in the movie. also enhanced by the other real life tragedy of brandon lee's death during the filming. The crow starts with the brutal murder of two lovers eric draven and shelly webster the day before their wedding (halloween). legend has it that when you die a crow carries your soul to the land of the dead. but in some cases the crow can bring that soul back to make the wrongs right. a year after they were killed eric is risen by the crow from the dead to avenge shelly. The acting is amazing and the film is legendary. its a great performance on all terms. you get sucked into james o'barr's world and watch as he tells his tale of love surviving everything... even death.

Review title: One of my favorite movies ever!
Review_body: One of my favorite movies!  I can watch it over and over. It makes me feel really good to watch such an excellent film, but I can't help but feel a little sad as well because of the way it really ended.  This movie is truly a masterpiece.

The Crow is an excellent movie, I didnt find one sequence or part boring or dull.  It's ashame Brandon Lee died because I think this movie would have rocketed him to stardom. The Crow is dark and gloomy and violent everything that makes a good fantasy movie good.  All of the acting was good and I like the way the camera sometimes switches to the crows view and the cinematography is great. The music is loud and depressing and MTV-ish most of the time. Go see it and watch a visual masterpiece. Rated R for:Graphic, bloody violence,rape,profanity * * * *(out of  4 stars)

Review title: This movie is the greatest action movie ever made
Review_body: Fast paced, great action, perfect soundtrack for the film, excellent acting, toss in a bit of artsy spectacle, great movie all around. Makes you suspend disbelief, and there's not one scene that is lacking. If you've seen the sequel, please don't judge this movie before seeing it, this is so far superior it's incredible.

An excellent film.  The only shame in it being that Brandon Lee died for his art.  The film is dark and somewhat gothic, with some real poetic justice. A must-see.  Surely, one of the best movies of all time (and with a beyond-excellent orchestral score).

Review title: The most inspiring, dark and excellent film ever
Review_body: The Crow deals with life, death and love in such a way that even  the meanest critic will have difficulty finding faults about it. It contains many coutable sayings and light and atmosphere completes this film as the most perfect film ever.

Magnificent cinematography and a Gothic feel, coupled with a unique storyline, fantastic action scenes and bucket loads of raw emotion make this film a true classic. "The Crow" pulls you in to its disturbing world and doesn't let go.A killer soundtrack that really grows on you is the icing on the cake. If you die without seeing this movie, make sure you come back to see it.

Review title: A twist for the film noir genre.
Review_body: The Crow is a fantasy tale, plain and simple.  You don't see many dark fantasies however.  As the movie tag line says, 'Believe in Angels', and after viewing this movie, you will.  The dark, twisted, violent, and sometimes funny film takes the classic film noir sense to new levels.  The whole combination of lighting, or lack there off, the music, and the acting of Brandon Lee give this movie the added punch.  The use of flashbacks fill in the gaps in the story, so people will not be asking too many questions. Overall, the movie makes the viewer cheer for Eric Draven and scream for the demise of the criminals.  A perfect fit for anyone wanting fantasy, romance, and/or violence.

Review title: A masterpiece concerning the usage of violence in a movie
Review_body: A movie taking place mostly at night is exceptional. Even more exceptional is how the movie manages to mix a very simple, yet excellent background story with the display of furious violence, without becoming ridiculous. The good thing about this movie is that the plot is dominant over the action scenes right until the end unlike in many other films (where the plot is a mere excuse for showing as much action scenes as possible). It's the first movie glorifying violence that I thoroughly enjoyed watching.

This film is, in my opinion, the greatest film of all time.  Stunning performances all round (especially Brandon Lee, and the ever watchable Michael Wincott), amazing direction, these thrown together with a beautiful soundtrack (rivaled only by 'Romeo & Juliet'), and you have this near perfect film.If you haven't watched it yet, go to the video shop NOW and rent it immediately!

Some of the most intense cinematography and poetic irony ever.  As everyone knows, Lee died during the filming, and the irony of his character returning to avenge his own death should not be lost on the viewer.It is true that the plot of the movie is not on par with "American Beauty" or "The Godfather" but Proyas' directing and Wolski's cinematography are incredible.  The cast all deliver good performances with Lee's probably being the weakest, but still quite acceptable.  He had trouble displaying mixed emotions, but most of his scenes were very believable in part because of directing, in part cinematography.The action scenes range from beautiful and poetic, to intense and powerful, to bloody and fast-paced.  The only thing that could have made them even the slightest bit better would have been some consultation by John Woo.The character development is quite well done, although I wish we had more about Albrecht.  Sarah and Darla are developed well, Eric and his love of Shelly, and even Top Dollar is shown with emotion.  O'Barr's writing of the characters is very well done.I need to take a moment to comment on the score.  Graeme Revell made the most incredible musical score to ever accompany an action movie.  The passion and drama in the percussive action tracks and the aching strings in the introspective periods serve as wonderful punctuation to a great statement of filmmaking.Finally, the worst part about the Crow.  The sequel.  Do not even waste your time.  The only good part of the second movie is the recitation of the English dictation rhyme about counting crows.  "One for sorrow, two for joy," etc.Overall, because of a _tiny_ bit of acting and plot, I'm going to knock a half point off.  My score:  9.5/10  (Round up to 10/10)

well, i only saw this film recently and i was totally blown away by it. the story-about a man (Brandon lee) coming back from the dead to avenge him and his fiancees murder was good, and brandon lee was fantastic in his role as Eric Draven. its a real tragedy that he died so young and so full of promise. the freaky thing is that Brandon Lee had to be 'literally brought back from the dead' in computerised sequences to finish the movie. he was accidentally killed in one of the 'flash back ' scenes by a gun shot by the actor playing 'fun boy'. getting back to the film, i dont believe in praising an actor simply because their dead, but it does give a certain eerie sadness to the role.the loctaion, music and supporting acting was great and i definately reccomend it. its sad, funny, stylish and action packed. it really gives us alot to think about after weve seen it, if your into that, but even not, i havent met anyone whose disliked it (yet!)if you can go see it i totally recommend it. one of the best films ive seen in a long while.

Review title: This is one of the best movies I have ever seen
Review_body: The Crow is a powerful movie. The whole atmosphere, the actors, the camera and the sounds all fit together. I think that this is the film Brandon Lee always wanted to do and if he'd seen it he'd be very proud. Alex did a very good job. I can't say anymore, the movie itself will tell you."All the parts of the character are given balance on the screen."

Review title: Why I love this movie? (maybe spoiler)
Review_body: One night I was bored so I decided to watch some movies my friend lend to me. In that moment I didn't know that this night would be very special.This was the first movie which made me cry. And I've always been wondering how people can cry, while they are watching a movie. Now I know, how.I loved this Gothic style, which made "The Crow" very emotional and painful. I can remember, that someone called this a " dark fairy-tale for adults". And I agree with him.If I didn't know that this movie is actually 12 years old, I would say that it's kinda new. I can only imagine, how people acted when this movie was first shown in cinemas.Acting was brilliant, every character was so realistic. Seems that everyone perfectly knows what they're supposed to do. Expectually villains and Eric.One of my favorite scenes are when Sarah is looking for Eric in his old flat, and she screams in anger and frustration, that he doesn't care about her. But then, when she's already leaving, Eric suddenly appears and says : " Sarah, I do care." Strange, how three small words can contain such a big amount of emotions.And now I'm always remembering one of the most beautiful quotes : " If the people we love are stolen from us, the way to have them live on is to never stop loving them. Buildings burn, people die, but real love is forever." It's very sad, that this was Brandon Lee's last movie, because he really had a talent. His acting is stunning and definitely not shallow.This movie really deserves more than 7.4. 10/10

Review title: Buildings burn, people die, but real love is forever.
Review_body: In the spring of 1994 I watched in amazement at my glowing television to see the news that "The Crow" - the film which claimed the life of young Brandon Lee - was to be released in May.  The Crow is a visual masterpiece in which we learn that: even in times of great brutality and sorrow, love can conquer all things and survive beyond the grave.  This film is one of the best adaptations of a comic book to film, some other notables being Superman and Batman.  But never have the others been so raw in there presentation to the audience or as poetic.  This is the story of a rock musician (Eric Draven) and his fiance (Shelley Webster) who are to be married on Halloween but with one knock at the door their lives are shattered.  The Crow is the image of a soul brought back to avenge the murder of a loved one, a murder so violent that it haunts that soul even in death.  This film is truly not for everyone, it is violent and boasts that it is "Darker than the Bat" in reference to Batman.  The film will leave you with a feeling of closure and completion, that the actions of the evil of the world do not go unpunished.I recommend The Crow to everyone and for those who like the film I also recommend reading the graphic novel by James O'Barr.  This film will make you cheer and make you angry, and in that respect it accomplishes what many thers have failed in doing and that is enthral the viewer into the world that is created by the actors and the directors of the film.  Just before the credits role there is a brief note from Linda Lee Cadwell (Brandon Lee's mother) and Edward R. Pressman (the films Producer) it says "To Brandon and Eliza" for those that understand, this will be the image that will impact you the most.  Happy viewing. "Sometimes, just sometimes that soul can come back.....to put the wrong things write."

Review title: Most overrated cult film in cinema's history.
Review_body: While the film is rich in style and the visual effects are certainly good for its time, a very special mention to the miniatures work and the set pieces is due being fair. It is the screenwriting that falls awfully short to support an otherwise well put together film.The Crow is the perfect example of style over substance and while some films may get away with it because even if they're plot-thin, at least they manage to make sense. The Crow, dearly lacks it; sense that is.The amazingly presented neo-noir streets deserved better worldbuilding, we deserved more backstory to such a visually pleasing dark-fantasy. And sadly, said dark fantasy didn't manage to support a thin script to provide more visual storytelling. It is pretty to look at, but it really doesn't tell us anything extra, unlike similar films like The Matrix, or Blade Runner that added to simple, yet robust stories, have the aid of pretty kick-ass visual storytelling in numerous details that removed from said films, would have left us with yet another awesome looking film, but nothing else to support them.The film is often looked at through the lens of heavy nostalgia rain (pun intended). Plus the obvious awe and mysticism behind Brandon Lee's demise while filming it. Giving it an instant "cult classic" status, similar to The Dark Knight's because of Heath Ledger's death. However TDK's status is at least well deserved due to the film achieving something The Crow couldn't ultimately, rising above and becoming something more than the sum of its individual parts.4/10. Mostly because of its amazing visual achievements for its time and also because it has one of the best soundtrack albums to ever be put together for a feature film.

Review title: The Glory Days of the Goth Mall Rat
Review_body: If you want to watch a movie where the writers were goth teenagers smoking cigarettes in front of your local mall, then look than further; this movie is for you. Sadly, this movie did not age well. It is plagued with cringe-inducing one-liners, questionable plot lines and every angsty fantasy that lived inside the heads of black-eyeliner-wearing disgruntled teenagers. After the first 10 minutes of the film, you can accurately predict everything.I can see how this movie is a "cult-film". Especially since Brandon Lee tragically lost his life due from an accident that occurred while filming. However, as sad as that is, it does not make the movie better; if anything, it makes it worse for taking away Bruce Lee's son from us too early.

It's a shame this movie does not get the credit it deserves. "The Crow" is one of the best comic book movies ever made, and it still stands strong today. This is one of the movies that I see every time it's on T.V. and sometimes I pop it on DVD. Great hero, great villain, great graphics, (for the time and money spent) and yes even a great soundtrack! Not many movies can say that, I also feel very strongly that this was Brandon Lee's breakout film. It's a shame that the work that he did in this movie not only turned out to be his best work, but also his last. They were a number of sequels made after this but they were nothing like this one, this movie was and is one of a kind. VanMacho

Review_body: ...but hardly worth the two dollars to rent it. Review_body: I love this movie. I can never get enough of it because it is that deep and thrilling. Brandon Lee made this film with the last of his time on this earth and what a performance. Stylish, bleak, violent and edgy, The Crow is as sharp as its nails. Perfect adaptation of the cult comics has everything hitting dead center. Director Proyas has created a world of everlasting night and rain where everyone's a freak and the talent to survive is not about who's the strongest or the meanest. In the end the most lethal weapon is the power of love.Brandon Lee is Eric Draven, an ultra cool avenger, an angel of death and love. Risen from the grave after one year from the murder of his girlfriend and himself to set things right. He takes on the killers and washes away the scum like an urban downpour. Michael Wincott with his raspy voice is the ultimate bad guy. The Crow not only shows the way for Eric Draven but all the dark comic adaptations the same time. Believe in angels. This is one of the first movies I ever fell in love with, and eight years later my fascination with it has not declined an iota. Review title: quite possibly the best comic book movie ever made!
Review_body: This is a classic story of love and vengeance. A rockstar (who is played by Brandon Lee) and his girlfriend (who was soon to be his wife) are unrightfully killed. Soon after the rockstar was reborn by the power of a mysterious crow. Soon after he returns from the grave he realizes that he must get revenge on those who had wronged him. When he persues his killers he discovers that he is invulnerable to harm, and this then enables him to charge blindly after his killers, leading to intense gun fights, and well choreographed close combat sequences. On the other hand "The Crow" is not only about the violence,there are emotional scenes that are not only tear jerking, but heart warming. This movie is for those who are not only action gluttons, but also for those wanting an excellent story, and an emotional ride. "The Crow" receives about a 7 for acting, a 8.5 for action, and a 8.5 for the story.

Review title: The themes of loneliness and loss expressed with creative artistry
Review_body: I've heard a lot about The Crow, as well as the tragic story of Brandon Lee's death. But I never saw this movie until last week.What touched me immediately was the commitment of the actors to their character's emotions, particularly by Brandon Lee, Ernie Hudson (the police sergeant), and Rochelle Davis (little girl Sarah). I could feel the loneliness and pain of each of these three characters. These emotions are presented powerfully when superimposed against the fantasy storyline, and that is the art of this movie. We rarely see authentic and poignant emotion like this in real life. But I think anyone who has ever experienced loss and loneliness can relate to it.There are many moments in the movie when each of these three characters are abandoned, and then one of the other three appears unexpectedly to provide comfort. They stay long enough only to provide reassurance or hope, and then they disappear. So it looks like these fallen angels are, themselves, angels to save each other.How often in real life does such an angel appear at a moment of despair? In the movie, it happens, and it happens unexpectedly, and that is when any viewer who has felt despair in their own life can feel the joy when this happens, and the sadness that it does not happen in our own real lives. This technique plays loss and hope against each other. I'll admit I cried. This movie was created by deeply felt artists.I looked up the biography of James O'Barr, the creator of The Crow. Along with Brandon Lee's death, there is indeed tragedy sweeping across the real lives behind this movie. Coincidence or not, the creators of this movie have tapped into those tragic threads of life that are so rarely touched by other movies.

The Crow. An example of the a comic book which has been made into Art. Conversely, Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings is an example of Art being made into a comic book.I haven't watched this one for well over 10 years. I was first struck by the resemblance to Blade Runner in the opening scene - sweeping over a dark, dismal cityscape with flames billowing from buildings. The constant rain, the trash bestrewn streets and gutters, the decaying buildings, the denizens....you can see the influence of Ridley Scott's early masterpiece here. But The Crow is no mere imitation of a work that is itself unique and insurpassable. The Crow seems more to me like a sister film, a film with similarities of visual style to Blade Runner, but a film with a spirit of its own.Brandon Lee somehow imparts an energy and a passion and a belief to the role of Eric Draven that comes across as true. On this basis it is easy to enter this world, it is easy enough to believe that this man has indeed come back from death, not as a ghost, but as flesh and blood, to exact bloody retribution on those who cruelly cut short the life of the woman he loved. For it is not so much his own death that consumes him. It is clear enough that the rage which drives him is the dark side of the bright fire of love that burned within him, while living, for his beloved.His performance gives the film its power. And while the characters are most certainly symbols, they are real too, they are flesh and blood and personalities. The film enfleshes these passions of the soul - love, rage, hatred - hatred of darkness and hatred of light.Although the setting, the city is nameless, we do not need a name and do not even wish for one. Somehow, the police procedural aspect, the typical foot-slogging, persistent and good-hearted beat cop, typically harangued and periodically bawled out by his arrogant, suit-wearing superior nicely grounds the film in a reality with which we are very familiar, if only from countless television shows of the ilk. It works well, and not for a second did I think I was looking at card-board cut-outs of people.This is a great film. It belongs, with a small minority of other films, in the realm of Art. It belongs in the pantheon, along with The Odyssey, with the Lord of the Rings (book), with Handel's Messiah, with the statue of David, with the Sistine chapel......and so on. By no means is it without its flaws, its faults. Among them, I would NOT include the straightforward plot. How many films with twisted, convoluted plots do you watch over and over and over once the mystery is untangled? On the other hand, I ask you, fans of The Crow, how many times have you watched this? It has raw power. You may know exactly what's going to happen, but you're hanging on by your fingernails to the last frame.It's beautiful.

first off to the "haters", Just because you think that the movie is all hyped up and that its a bunch of wannabe Goths, listen here, I saw this movie when I was 13 and let me tell you that I can still watch it over and over again and notice something that I had not noticed when I first saw the film. If people base their overall opinion on The Crow based on either of its' sequels, they will miss how good The Crow starring Brandon Lee is. City of Angels was a shameful attempt by some writers and producers to capitalize on the original and the stigma attached to the film created through Brandon Lee's tragic on-set death.The Crow should have been Lee's 'breakout' film. His role as Eric Draven should have stood out for the effort Lee put into that, rather than the tragic circumstances inexorably tied to it.The Crow has some endearing qualities, and leaves some lasting impressions and images firmly implanted in memory. From the intentionally dark and dreary settings of Detroit to the soundtrack, The Crow stands on its' own as a truly great - and greatly under-appreciated - film. The story distinguishes itself in such a way, that even some unoriginality is forgiven. What I mean by that is, the revenge theme in movies was nothing new or unique. Avenging a loved one has been done several times and in several different ways. Sometimes this mechanic works, sometimes it doesn't. In The Crow, it works. In other words; some elements in the movie, though unoriginal, are still conveyed in original and intriguing ways.The Crow is original and inspired work. That's the bottomline.Brandon's role wasn't necessarily 'Oscar-worthy'..But, it was believable and presented with emotion and authority. He commanded that role, and the scenes he was in(which is most of them). He was (and is) Eric Draven. One can only guess where this role would have taken Brandon Lee had he lived. My guess is to bigger and better things...come to think of it, maybe that's where he ended up? Depending on what you believe...
If you haven't seen this movie, I'd recommend at least renting it. I own the Collectors' Series DVD, and it is permanently part of my collection.Last note: Really a crying shame City of Angels was ever made, and especially given the fact it involves some of the same people from the original. They seem to thoroughly undo every bit of good they did with The Crow. Please, do yourself a favor; pass the sequels by. There is only one The Crow.

Review title: My favorite movie of all time
Review_body: What can i say? Simply that it is one of of those rare films that appeals to goths, grungers and those who into the alternative and the occult. The late Brandon Lee plays a murdered rocker who comes back from the dead with the help of a crow to inflict revenge on those who killed him his fiance a year ago. After applying black and white face-paint and a black costume he begins his killing spree. The fact that Brandon died during the making of a film increase the dark, surreal atmosphere that remains throughout, and the excellent storyline and special effects make this a brilliant film. Why it got a measly 7/10 I don't know, but i highly suggest you see it

Review title: This is the best movie ever!
Review_body: Basically this movie is about at as bad-ass as it gets. Brandon Lee plays Eric Draven, a young rock guitarist who is beaten and killed the night before his wedding, along with his fiancé. The next year he comes back and gets even with the guys that killed him. This movie is dark, in a way that it feels real. Instead of letting the love surpass the anger of the overall movie Lee keeps it going. Not only that, but he choreographed every fight scene, and let's be honest, the son of Bruce Lee would not steer us wrong! I would also like to point out that the cinematography is very unique too. The film makers obviously stayed away from "happy" colors. They primarily focus on black and blood red. This just adds to the the strength of the movie. The message of the movie is one that can be appreciated. While Lee's character is killing the "bad guys", he himself is not romanticized as a good guy. He is still killing, and the film makers did not try to make him look like the every day hero. Like I said, this movie is just to bad-ass for words!!!

The Crow which is directed by Alex Proyas is a very good movie about this man Eric Draven (LEE) who comes back on Devils night and wreaks havoc on the people that killed him and his girlfriend. This movie ultimately caused the death of the star Brandon Lee the son of martial arts superstar Bruce Lee but was it murder or accidental i am still trying to work it out but Alex Proyas won't talk about it he should get it out in the open it might resolve it all this movie is worth seeing though **********/10. This movie will be a movie that will still be around in another 10 years and one that you can watch as soon as your old enough. a classic movie that will never let down on the action a must see

Review title: Gives the watcher the chance to use imagination.
Review_body: in the past, the crow has been given some scrutinizing reviews. and while the movie is not perfect, seeing as none ever are, the total look and feel of the movie give the watcher such a sense of what is happening to Draven. It is obvious that very little is known about the happenings on that fateful night or about eric and his future wife, but this allows the watcher room to imagine and take from his/her heart things that make it what it is. I for one took memories from my life and from past experience and imagined them much stringer in Eric Draven. This gives Eric the character that he was 'lacking' in the film. We all know that what happened was awful, there is no doubt about that. So why should we use up another hour of film explaining something we already know?All in all, The Crow is a very moving film and is full of action for those not looking for a moving experience or the poetic style of the film. I recommend it to anyone who wants to think more about the evil in todays world, grin at the almost constant yet tactful irony, and applaud as Eric wreaks havok on the evil ones.

Review title: wicked but in a very good way
Review_body: It's a fantastic film, it does a good vs evil with an evil good person better than I have ever seen before or since and I consider it as close to a romantic epic as I can bear although it is actually nothing of the sort. Justice and particularly revenge, the real theme of the film, is a dish best served cold and it's hard to get much colder than the dead.The atmospheric soundtrack stood out as so excellent that I noticed it in the background even though the film was completely absorbing and it complemented the film perfectly.The Gothic look and feel of the whole film was superbly integrated with an alternative present day setting and every character was brought to such vivid life as to be loved or hated with passion.

The film portrays a young rock guitarist who comes back from the dead to avenge the murders of himself and his fiancée. Even as a kid I always enjoyed watching it, as I found Lee's Crow to be easily watchable and I couldn't help but sympathize with the character, thanks to Lee's performance. He truly shined as the character, and captured what James O' Barr worked hard to create in his graphic novels. The atmosphere of the film was damn perfect, and even though some of the dialogue was a bit hit-and-miss(Mainly Rochelle Davis as Sarah), the cast worked and went great together. Michael Wincott as 'Top Dollar' was easily one of the best villains interpreted on-screen, and had some of the best dialogue and scenes besides Lee. To touch up a bit about Brandon Lee as The Crow, the way Lee portrayed the title character was what made the film so great, with his powerful yet gentle charismatic presence, he made one of the best superheroes to ever hit the screen. The action in the film was alright, but without the film's good performances, it might not have carried as well. The direction of the film was practically flawless, and everything clicked just fine. Alex Proyas as director of the film was a fine choice.

It's do bad that Brendon Lee died because he is amazing. The effects and action are brilliant without being overdone.The combat is so realistic. The soundtrack is a work of art. It perfectly captures the mood of each scene. The scene were lee "suits up" in his ruined apartment is arguable the best moment in cinema. The visual style of the entire film just perfectly fits. Its dark and bleek and exciting. This is one that no one can afford not to see.

This was an absolutely captivateing film for me to watch, it filled me with every emotion you could possible think, Hatred for the bad guys, Triumph for the good guys but mostly sadness for the loss not only in the film but for Brandon Lee who obviously never got to see what an amazing actor he really was, It was as if life was imitating film and its just terribly ironic that an engaged, much in love couple get killed in the film and Brandon himself was only two weeks from his own marriage and that he died on the exact set in which his character (Eric Draven) did. I obtained the "Making of the Crow" book and read it from cover to cover that to captivated me and it is well worth a read for all those that enjoyed the film.We may never no the true circumstances in which Brandon was killed but i do know that he was aa special actor with an emotion and a passion for what he did you could tell that from the emotional portrayal of love and loss in the crow.

The Crows RevengeThis movie begins on a dark night in Detroit. The Crow , Shelly Webster (Sofia Shenas) and Eric Draven (Brandon Lee) are engaged to be married the next day on Devils Night, Halloween, the night of fires, vandalism, and crime. Unfortunately that day never came for them. Shelly was raped and murdered for trying to get a petition to help rid the neighborhood of people that weren't contributing to society and that were making it worse. Eric was also killed. One year after their deaths, Eric came back to life as the crow to seek revenge for Shelly's death. The crow makes Eric somewhat invincible to getting hurt or killed while getting the justice that is deserved. The theme of this film seems to be revenge and justice. I feel the directors of this film, Daniel J. Schow and Alex Proyas, are trying to show that even in the darkest of times and bleakness of the night justice can prevail. One must fight to make it happen though. Although Draven was turned into the crow, he still had limitations to his invincibility. The crow followed Eric around the city and was there at the times that Tin-Tin, Fun Boy and T-Bird were brought to their final doom. If the crow was hurt Eric was inevitably hurt also. Justice doesn't always come easy and it's something we have to be willing to fight for. I'm personally attracted to this film for several reasons. One being the way justice is served, another being the love between Shelly and Eric. Eric loved her so much that he was willing to die for her and bring her death to justice; their love as to die for. This film also has a certain attraction to it because it is somewhat of a thriller. It keeps us on edge and captivated. The darkness and costumes bring a certain mysterious quality to it also. Brandon Lee's skills as an actor also bring an attraction to the film.

I really love the late Brandon Lee in this movie and I find it very tragic that he was unable to continue his career. I really loved 'The Crow' because of its kind of unclear vision of good and evil. On one hand, Eric Draven is the good avenger getting justice on the druggies/gangsters, but then on the other hand, the way he does it has a slight insanity to it and he NEVER hands them over to the police. He kills them. So, the line between good & evil is there, but a bit less recognizable. For those who have read the graphic novel of 'The Crow,' (which I had the pleasure of reading) it is true to the book in most ways, and the changes that WERE made were minimal. For example, the comic showed that Eric and Shelly were killed on the side of the road after they had some car trouble, whereas in the movie, they were murdered in their apartment. That didn't really bother me at all, and even if you are a strictly by-the-book person, I think it should still be okay. I recommend this movie to anyone who can tolerate excessive cursing. ;)

Review title: A moving piece of cinematic excellence
Review_body: The Crow is my all time favourite movie. Just last night I watched it for about the fifth time this week and every time I watch the film I learn something new about it and I can understand it better each and every time. The movie is excellent, the special effects at the start are a little below par, but this in no way affects my view on the rest of the movie.I was shocked to hear about the death of Brandon Lee when he was filming a flashback scene in the loft where his girlfriend (soon to be wife Shelley in the film) and himself were murdered callously by 4 evil men under the orders of Top Dollar. I was saddened that he had died so early on in his career, because this film paved the way for an excellent future career. It was very coincidentally that he played the part of someone that was to be killed, then he had been accidentally killed by a faulty prop gun.There were two main scenes in the movie that really moved me. The one where he comes out of the grave screaming because he has realised what has happened to him and the other being where he enters the loft where he and his girlfriend were killed only to be reminded of what had happened to him with the aid of moving flashbacks. No other movie has ever done this to me before and a great deal of empathy is needed for Eric and Shelley (the two victims). And as Brandon once started in his final interview no compassion is needed toward the culprits and how they finally meet their demise.The cast is excellent and without a doubt no other person for each role would be suitable other than what was set. The cast was chosen to perfection. The screenplay and how the background sound is often heard at very certain parts of the film is also brilliant. It is a film that I am proud to have in my collection and I am sure that you would love the film if you are into a love story.Alex Proyas (the director of the film) is notorious for the darkness in his films and in this it doesn't go a miss. But things soon brighten up and happiness is restored when Brandon gains revenge for their deaths. There is also a small amount of dark comedy in the film coming both from Eric (when he returns from the dead) and from the culprits which Inflict badly upon Eric.The flashback scenes are especially moving, when you see what life was like for both Eric and Shelley together before they were taken away so suddenly. Life was perfect, and they were about to be married but one thing that we learn from this movie amongst other things as that the majority of us think of life everyday as being trivial. The film also is focused on a girl (Sarah) a friend of Shelley and Eric whose mum is friendly with one of the culprits of Eric and his girlfriends demise. Eric soon sets the mother on the right path and the screen brightens up when we see this happening.Overall the movie is excellent 10/10 overall. The cast overall 10/10 and my recommendation for this film if you haven't yet watched: 10/10.

Review title: An absolutely beautiful film that everyone should see at least once.
Review_body: This film is so amazing, I can't remember how many times I've seen it. You don't have to be interested in a particular genre of film to watch it, because there is something for everyone in this film. Romance, action, gory bits, humour, drama- you name it, The Crow has it. The tragic circumstances surrounding this film and Brandon Lee also add to it's allure.Basically, it's about a rock star named Eric Draven, his fiancée Shelley Webster and the little girl they take care of, Sarah. When a ruthless gang of thugs viciously murder both Eric and Shelley on the night before their wedding, Eric comes back from the grave to avenge his fiancée's death by going after each member of the gang that killed her, and to say a final goodbye to Sarah.An extremely moving film that I would recommend to anyone who has a heart.

Vigilante movies have been around for God knows how long. The idea of vengeance against those that do us wrong is a driving force in cinema. But most of the time we get a horribly predictable movie that follows a set formula. And then there is The Crow. In its own, stylized way, The Crow puts to rest all those other vigilante movies, and creates a new form, one that leaves the viewer pleased, and never disappoints.Since the first time I saw this movie, which was about the time The Crow: City of Angels was released into the theaters, I was fascinated by the look of this "Gothic tale of unrequited love and the scorn of a soul burdened by the torment of great loss." I had only seen the movie once, on HBO, but fell in love with the story. I never really got around to renting it, but if I saw it on the program schedule, I would set time aside to watch it.Now that I am older, and I own the first three (The Crow, The Crow: City of Angels, The Crow: Salvation) I have been able to view it and truly grasp the masterpiece in its entire form. From the soundtrack, to the pop culture references, and even the references in pop culture. It shows the true greatness of comics that become great movies (Sin City and Hellboy being two others.) The story and the acting are terrific and the all out vengeful nature of Eric Dravin is what captures my attention the most.Let's not forget the plethora of colorful characters with the "jolly pirate nicknames." From Tin-Tin to T-Bird, Skank to Funboy, and (my personal favorite) Top Dollar. The charismatic villains and the even more charismatic hero (anti-hero to be exact) truly shine in this masterpiece.However, this movie is also very tragic. It would be the last movie Brandon Lee would ever make. He was killed in an accident while filming. Like his character, he was to be wed to his fiancé in just three weeks after filming was to be wrapped up. He follows the mysterious death of his father, the martial arts legend Bruce Lee.All tragedies aside, one of the greatest movies ever made. Followed by an "all right" sequel and then two more, "less than mediocre" sequels after that, the original stands true. The best "Crow" movie out there. The original, the best, The Crow.

Review title: Was great then and still is now...
Review_body: This movie captivated me both as a youngster and now as an adult, and its a timeless (albeit cult) flick. It's got everything; a little fantasy, some action, romance in the form of vengeance, and the necessary good guys vs bad guys needed in any good story. The special effects are still decent after so many years, the acting is spot on for what each character needed, and the cinematic quality for me captures a nostalgic look at the 90's goth/rock culture. I'd also argue that this movie is what sparked the "Hot Topic" fashion fads that were seen throughout the late 90's and early 2000's. Clearly people identified and/or loved this movie.

The Crow had all the makings a of a brilliant, unforgettable movie: A great lead actor, a great concept, and a brilliant soundtrack, but somewhere along the way, it went horribly wrong.The original concept for the film (a victim rising from the grave to wreak hideous revenge on those who wronged him), had it been stuck to, would have given this movie the potential to be unforgettable. If they had stuck to it, and not heavily dragged out the storyline, I would have found the film far more captivating. It was also tainted by the hideous genre of 90's Action Films, which somehow infected the story, embellishing what could have been a good ending, with explosions and cheap stunts.Had this been made in a different time, or had a different script/story writer it could have been brilliant. Its still a great movie though, and because I so desperately want to love it, I can ignore the slander that has infected the amazing storyline! All in all...five out of ten

Review title: An incredible gem of a movie!
Review_body: Sometimes a movie comes along that is just perfect. To me this is one of those movies. It has a good story, great characters portrayed by excellent actors and most importantly; heart and soul in bucket loads. Do not shy away thinking it is just another cult film because of the tragic circumstances of Brandon Lee's death during filming. One overlooked tragedy is the aftermath for the young actress Rochelle Davis who portrayed Sarah. Devastated by her friends death she left the movie business and what could have been a great career. I usually cannot stand child actors but she does an amazing job in this movie. As does all the other actors. Michael Wincott and David Patrick Kelly have their best villain roles in this film. Great visual effects, almost no cgi. They do not make them like this anymore.I love this movie.

Review title: Good for a Last Picture from Brandon Lee
Review_body: I see that the movie shows a release in 1994, but I saw the "The Crow" in New Jersey (USA) the summer of 1993. Where and when did "The Crow" come out if it was originally released (by the official IMDb date) in 1994? Why would it sit on the shelf for almost a year?It has become a cult-classic but still has not only dark humor but an estrange ending. The love story was powerful along with his friendship with the homeless little girl. I recommend it to others that want to see Brandon Lee in the movies as one of his best."The Crow" sequels sucked very much. Again Hollywood trying to capitalize on a good original screwing up those that follow.

I think one my favourite movies of all time will always be The Crow. I was 10 the first time I saw it and I still watch it sometimes. It's one of the most visually stunning movies I have ever seen and they pulled it off more than 20 years ago without all the CGI technology we have today. It's a work of art in every frame. Story wise it's full of pain and loss, and the movie captures it so well that it always puzzles me how they could make such a dark and depressing story so beautiful and exciting at the same time. And then there's Brandon Lee - the actor of the main character who got accidentally killed on the set by a malfunctioning firearm. This fact alone makes the movie even more interesting as the movie itself questions the nature of death. This movie influenced me in such a way that I started to appreciate the beauty of all dark and scary things we experience. Most people usually look away when experiencing something negative, but I am always driven to understand it and appreciate it if nothing can be done about it. It's very interesting how art can change our personalities and the things we like. The Crow is the suppressed rage of poets and artists everywhere burning their oppressors on a dark wind-swept night and it's one of those movies that got many people interested in the goth culture and elevated it into a whole new level of popularity. At its heart it is a simple revenge movie; a soul drawn back to a corrupt living world to punish those that killed him and his fiance, but the way it's portrayed sets it apart from similar movies. It's a dark journey in a post-industrial hell-scape in search of those who wronged him. If you're looking for something dark and beautiful, this is it.

Review title: Cult Classic will forever mark an epic moment in film..
Review_body: This film's dark love story of revenge takes you on a self exploration deep into the realm where grief meets rage. When life meets death to soon, the bond of loves hold defying logic to make things right. A story of tragedy told by a cast and crew going through tragedy with the death of Brandon Lee during the filming.... cult classic to the end.

I truly enjoyed this movie! Although the main character died in real life, this movie was well written and well thought out.The idea of someone you loved dying in such a violent way then you returning from the dead to avenge that wrong is wonderful.The power of love can do many things. Love that is true will live forever. Through life and on into death. Eric shows his love so openly that it almost makes you feel the pain of loss.The acting was well done and proves that even a "dark comic" can be made into a really great film. A truly wonderful movie!

I have seen this movie many times and still I can not get enough of it. Yes, this shows the darker side to life, but the message is clear. DON'T MESS WITH LOVE! I wish Brandon Lee hadn't died and he was able to make more (yes, I have see the sequel but it is not the same without Brandon Lee). To say that this movie is bad is saying nothing is right within the world. Life and Love will always be connected no matter what anyone tries to do. Sarah was also a very good character to add, and I liked how no matter what was done, their was always a decent officer of the law. I liked the way each victim was taken care of based on their life. Also, by The Crow letting Darla live, he showed that he really was not a bad guy, just someone out for revenge to those that almost destroyed and them alone.

The Crow is a very dark romantic film, the character of Eric Draven is very demanding and yet Brandon Lee manages to play with a believable passion. The film is a must see for anyone esp if you a fan of underworld and the matrix. After watching this you can see why thousands of teenagers paint their faces white and call themselves Eric!!!Its about a beautiful couple - Eric and Shelley who get murdered. Eric Draven comes back from the dead to avenge their deaths and the only way he can do this is by a series of flash backs that haunt him. With the help form a young girl who he and Sheeley were friends with and a police man who looked after the case first time around.
